subdebateinfo.title: International Air Services: Benefits to Tourism

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Sport and Tourism. Could the minister inform the House how the government's new international air services regime will provide a boost to tourism, particularly in regional Australia?

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Sport and Tourism; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for her question. I know that she has a keen interest in tourism. Australia's tourism industry is one of the big winners from the government's decision to further liberalise international air services. In particular, the tourism industry will benefit from more flights, which means more seats, which means more marketing of those seats internationally, which means more competitive airfares and innovative new travel products.

answer.para: The new arrangements are also great news for the development of tourism in regional areas of Australia. We are looking at the number of tourists to Australia doubling in the next decadeâthat is, 8.4 million tourists arriving in Australia each year. It is good to see that we are taking some initiatives now to spread the benefits of that growth to our regional and rural parts of Australia. The increasing number of overseas tourists is looking to some of Australia's unique attractions, and many of these are found in regional Australia. This aviation decision builds on the government's initiatives to boost regional tourism, such as our regional tourism program extended to $16 million as well as our domestic tourism campaign, which is under way, for another $16 million.

subdebateinfo.title: Member for Leichhardt: Disclosure of Interests

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister, and it goes to his code of conduct. Prime Minister, do you recollect that your code of conduct says:

question.para: Ministers are required to resign directorships in public companies and may retain directorships in private companies only if any such company operates, for example, a family farm, business or portfolio of investments . . .

Prime Minister, does not the company which Mr Entsch is associated with qualify under none of those circumstances? Is he, therefore, not in breach of your code of conduct? In that case, why don't you dismiss him?

talk.start.para: âHe is not in breach, and I do not intend to dismiss him.

âMy question is to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. Minister, in March you ordered an urgent investigation into a certain type of fire door in response to concerns about the safety of consumers in high occupancy buildings. There are nursing homes in my electorate which might use these sorts of doors, so could the minister inform the House on the progress of this investigation?

âI thank the member for Deakin for his question and, in particular, for his concern about the nursing homes in his electorate. I am sure the nursing homes in the electorates of a number of members, particularly in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, would be concerned. For only the seventh time since 1974 the Commonwealth is going to exercise its mandatory powers of recall, and it is going to exercise those under section 65F of the Trade Practices Act. Up to 4,500 fire doors are to be recalled from around Australia. The recall will have priority in nursing homes, hospitals and other buildings where the occupants need help to evacuate in the case of fire. These buildings are particularly located in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales.

answer.para: We have ordered the suppliers of the fire doors to identify buildings as a matter of urgency and replace or repair doors and bring them up to appropriate safety standards. The costs, which are significant in this case, are to be met by the suppliers. In this case we are determined to protect consumers. We will constantly use our Trade Practices Act powers to force recalls where in particular cases goods are provided that are a danger to the users of those goods. In this case the CSIRO seized three doors from the actual buildings where they were located and tested them. They failed to meet a one-hour standardâin fact, they were burnt through after only 15 minutes, which is an obvious concern to disabled people and elderly people, who may not be able to evacuate a building quickly. Therefore, we have ordered the recall. We expect action to take place immediately.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
âThere were 20 questions.

âMr Speaker, as you know, many members on both sides of the House are concerned at the plight of two Australian CARE workers, Pratt and Wallace. My question to you is: would you consider using your high office to sponsor a motion in this parliament that may be voted upon by all members, calling for the release of Pratt, Wallace and the Yugoslav national, which might be transmitted to the Yugoslav parliament?

âI will consider the request from the member for Chifley. I should, however, point out that I have been impressed with the action taken by both the minister and his department in this instance, and I believe that is a view shared by all parliamentarians. The member for Chifley may not be aware but, in fact, I used the opportunity, when I had it, to speak directly with the Speaker of the Yugoslav parliament in order to use what influence I had at that level to get him to intervene on behalf of the aid workers. At the time we were being denied diplomatic access to them. We were subsequently granted diplomatic access, and I took the liberty of writing to the Speaker of the Yugoslav parliament expressing my appreciation for what I presumed to have been his intervention. I will further consider your request.
âMr Speaker, under standing order 150, would you please write to the Treasurer reminding him of, and requesting an answer to, question No. 465 that was placed on the Notice Paper by me on 8 March?
âI will act on the member for Prospect's behalf.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Low and Middle Income Australians

talk.start.para: â I have received a letter from the honourable member for Lilley proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The failure of the Coalition-Democrat tax deal to adequately protect low and middle-income Australians from the adverse impact of the GST.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ

talk.start.para: âIt is my pleasure to propose this matter of public importance relating to the failure of the coalition-Democrat tax deal to adequately protect low and middle income Australians from the adverse impact of the GSTâand I do so not just on behalf of the parliamentary Labor Party but also on behalf of the 58 per cent of Australians who reject the GST and the 30 per cent of Australians from the coalition who support the coalition but reject the GST. There is overwhelming public opposition to this tax. This is a tax we do not have to have, it is a tax that Australians do not understand and it is a tax that Australians cannot afford to pay.

speech.para: This is a debate that distracts us all at a vital time for this nation when there are fundamental things at stake which demand our attention. It is a debate that has gridlocked this parliament and poisoned our political climate. In the past week we have seen incursions by illegal immigrants and we have seen a dramatic erosion of our external trade account. But what has the government been doing? It has been playing with birthday cakesâthe menu of John Howard's birthday cake. It need not be so.

When the Prime Minister declared that this miserable, unfair, inefficient tax was off the agenda for all time, Australians believed him. We all recall him saying `never, ever'. Australians were entitled to have that trust honoured. But this man has the courage of his prejudices: he will pursue this unfair tax no matter whatâirrespective of public opinion, irrespective of what all Australians say, irrespective of the third of coalition supporters who oppose the GST. This Prime Minister has forfeited all trust on tax reform. He must be reminded that he ruled this tax out for all time, and the public believed him. He has brought it back, the public oppose it and he continues.

Also, the public believed the Democrats; they believed the Democrats who promised that no tax in the form of that which is presently proposed would ever, ever receive their agreement. The Democrats said that they would `keep the bastards honest'. What do we have? We have a bastard tax. That is what we have from the coalition-Democrat deal. We have a tax that nobody wants. The Democrats made 16 pledges to the Australian people and not one of those pledges has been keptânot even the pledge to completely exempt food. None of those pledges have been kept.

This is a bit like the story of Little Red Riding Hood. Little Red Riding Hood wanders off to grandma's house. There we have grandma. Little Red Riding Hood comes in and says `Oh my, Grandma, what big ears you have'âand you can just see it now, `All the better to hear you with.' `Oh, what big eyes you have, Grandma.' `All the better to see you with,' says grandma. Then Little Red Riding Hood says, `What big teeth you have, Grandma.' And what does grandma, the Treasurer of this country, say? `All the better to eat you with, Little Red Riding Hood.'

That is exactly what has occurred. Not one of those 16 pledges that the Democrats made to the Australian peopleâthe pledges to `keep the bastards honest'âhave been kept. When it comes to food, that is where we have seen the most dramatic departure from the Democrats' commitments to the Australian people. Over one-third of all food consumed by low and middle income Australians is still subject to the GST. If you are on a pension, if you are earning under $30,000 a year, one-third of the food that you consume will be subject to a GST; and 75 per cent of everything that you consume, if you are under $30,000 a year, will still be subject to a GST.

That is the extent of the Democrats' departure from the commitments they gave to the Australian people. None of those commitments will be honoured. What we have is a coalition-Democrat deal that represents John Howard and Peter Costello's GST. None of the architects of this monstrosityâPeter Costello, Tim Fischer, Meg Leesâcan ever again be trusted by the Australian people.

If you want to find out the truth about this tax, you do not have to look at the Labor Party's analysis, you do not have to look at all the economic people in the universities; you can just look at what has been said by some of the reputable people who have rejected this tax. Senator Harradine said:

Decisions we make now on this issue are not for the next three years; we are making decisions here that will affect generations. The question that I have to ask myself is whether I am going to be a party to imposing an impersonal, indiscriminate tax on my children, my grandchildren and their children for generations to come.

He was right. And so were the tens of thousands of people around this country who wrote and faxed and emailed Senator Harradine with their opposition. No doubt the `assistant treasurer' in this government, Senator Lees, would say that that was the result of a Labor Party phone tree. What it was the result of was an overwhelming revulsion at the stench of the deal that has been done by the Liberal-National-Democrat coalition.

Let us look at what all the churches have had to say, let us look at what all the charities have had to say, let us look at what all the community organisations have had to say. An ACOSS media release states:
The package will . . . widen the gap between rich and poor, and the whole nation will suffer from greater division between the haves and have-nots.
Food is exempted from the GST, but the definition is too narrow.
Earlier this year, when the Democrats agreed with ACOSS on tax reform, Senator Lees had this to say about a statement from ACOSS:
I'm delighted to see the statement echoes the Democrats' position that raising $5 billion by taxing food and using it to fund tax cuts for the well-off is quite simply immoral.

Absolutely! Meg Lees said that the deal she signed up to with John Howard and Peter Costello was completely immoral. Let us just not dwell on ACOSS, which represents all the churches, all the charities and all the community organisations in this country. Let us have a look at what the gutsiest community organisation in this country, the St Vincent De Paul, has had to say about the GST:

We will enter the next millennium having lost the opportunity of providing a just and equitable Australia by enshrining a system that will provide an unegalitarian and unfair Australia thus locking millions of Australians, as has been done in other countries, into a cycle of poverty. The myth of a "fair go for Aussie battlers" will become another casualty in our search for what we are told is "good for the economy".

What has the government's response been? All we have had is the K-Mart Treasurer out there laughing about birthday cakes at the Prime Minister's 25th anniversary. He was chuckling about the fact that we will have to legislate for cakes, that we will have to legislate for bread recipes. All of this is very funny. The pictures said a thousand words. Remember the stony look on the Prime Minister's face when the Treasurer was lampooning the deal that had been agreed to. That is because the Prime Minister thinks that Meg Lees is a far better ally for him in this Liberal-National-Democrat coalition than Peter Costello. The stony look from the Prime Minister at the talk about the cake said it all. What we have got is a completely nonsensical approach to this tax. Where is the simplicity? All that is left is the stupidity and the unfairness.

Let us look at some of the unfairness. As I said earlier, up to a third of all the food that is consumed by people on incomes of less than $30,000 a year will still be subject to a GST. Seventy-five per cent of all the expenditure by pensioners and low income workers will still be subject to a GST. Of course, the Democrats would have us believe that that was not the case. The Democrats have said that 80 per cent of food is GST free. Unfortunately, 80 per cent is not 65 per cent. So low income Australians are really going to bear the burden of that component of food which is still taxed.

We have evidence from the retailers association that, as a result of the compliance nightmare, the price of food will rise again for those items that are not subject to the GST. So the Democrats so-called big win on food is already looking very shaky. The fact is that battlers in this communityâthe government does not talk about battlers anymoreâare going to be paying the GST on all of the essentials of life. They are going to be paying it on the electricity account, the Telstra bill and the insurance bill. That is where people are going to get slugged. That is where their standard of living is going to go down the tube. That is what we know about the nature of their deal.

We also know that it is going to be particularly punishing for families. Families with children will be particularly badly hit, because families with kids spend much more on housing, energy, clothing and household services. They are the items that are really going to take that big whack out of the family budget. The ABS household expenditure survey reveals that 75 per cent of the budgets of low income earners and families will be hit by the GST. Families with three or more children spend something like $98 a week on housing costs compared with couples without children, who spend just $76 a week. Such families spend $23 a week on energy costs compared with couples, who spend just $16, and so on. Families with children are going to have their standard of living substantially eroded.

So for the Prime Minister and other ministers to come in here and use pro-family rhetoric is simply obscene, because every step they take sends families backwards. It is two steps forward, five steps backwardsâconstantly eating away at the standard of living of families. Even with the Democrats' changes, a family with three children earning $30,000 a year gets just $16 a week in tax cuts compared with a couple earning $100,000 a year who get $60 a week. This means that children born into a family earning $30,000 are worthy of just a quarter of the tax cut of children born into a family earning $100,000. That is how obscene these new tax scales are.

The so-called family package is nothing more than an attempt at compensating for an unfair GST. What do we find in that package? We find that the government calculates that the GST cost of a child is 30c a week extra. That is all that we get from this government when it comes to the importance of helping children in families. On top of that, parents will pay the extra tax on haircuts, school books, video hire and so on.

When we look at this Liberal-National-Democrat deal, the deal provides only $1 of every extra $5 in additional expenditure directly in the form of additional compensation, and families get just seven per cent of that total additional compensation package. So you can never say that, with this package, families were a priority of the Democrats or the Liberals or the Nationals. Of course, the package also particularly penalises dual income families. Children in families with one child with one income earning $50,000 a year get $61.50 a week while children in dual income families earning the same amountâthat is, $50,000âget only $27 a week. That is the extent of the social engineering we are getting from this government.

What should be occurring is that people should be getting assistance on the basis of need, not some social judgment made by the government. Why is one group of children worth half of what the other group is worth? That is simply very bad social policy. It will also have very perverse results on a woman's decision to work. It will build a whole new raft of poverty traps which will disadvantage many two-income families where, frequently, the second income is relatively minor but is absolutely essential so that that family can survive and aspire to do better for themselves and for their children.

That now brings us to charities, because the one thing you can guarantee from this package is that poverty will rise. It will build two Australias. It will deeply entrench poverty in this country which the previous Labor government had worked to get down. The latest NATSEM report indicates how much Labor did to redistribute income in this country to ensure that people got a better go at the lower end. What this package is going to do is push those people much further down, and that is the whole purpose. The thing about this package is that it is very strong in taxing the weak and very weak in taxing the strong. The end result of this package is going to be a redistribution of wealth from the bottom to the top.

This is a program which has really been developed by the radical rich. It is nothing more than a transfer of the tax burden to the few at the top from middle and low income earners. What the conservative parties and their new partners, the Democrats, have really constructed here is not tax reform; it is basically tax deform. They have deformed the tax system, and they have done it with the very deliberate intent of redistributing all of the benefits from the bottom to the top.

This government simply believe that the person who is in the ritziest restaurant in town washing the dishes should be paying the same amount of tax as the person who delivers the goods in the truck and the same amount of tax as the millionaire diner sitting at the swankiest table in the restaurant. At the end of the day, a GST is simply a flat tax which pays no heed to capacity to pay. Via that mechanism, they are on about redistributing wealth from the bottom to the top. As we have said on many occasions before, when you look at this government's policies in social security, in education and in labour market reform, they have one favourite minorityâthe wealthy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere is nothing the Labor Party hates more than a good deal for the poor, a good deal for Australian families, a good deal for all Australians. This new tax package is not just about compensation; it is about a bonusâa social bonus for all Australians. It is a tax package that provides benefits to all sectors of the community but particularly benefits to those who are on low incomesâto the pensioners, to the welfare beneficiaries. And sitting opposite are a group of people who are about to vote against it. They are about to become the first political party in Australian history to vote against a real increase for pensioners. They are trying to vote down a four per cent pension rise from 1 July 2000. Is this a group that cares for the poor? They invoke the name of St Vincent de Paul and then try to vote down a pension rise.

speech.para: This is supposed to be a matter of public importance, but the member for Lilley chooses to use the time to tell fairytales. In fact, almost the whole of his address was a fairytale there was so little element of truth associated with it. He used his time to tell fairytales about what the processes might be and what the real effects of this package might be. But the sad part about this whole tax debate has been the total irrelevance of a party that claims it is the alternative government. In fact, it has so forfeited that role that a small number of people in the other place have become the effective opposition. A small number of people in the other place are engaging themselves in the tax debate while the Labor Party stands aside in the grandstand.

I thought it was rather interesting that in the very first question today in question time the Labor Party asked about the effect of the GST on a seat in the grandstand. Of course, they would be very interested in the effect of the GST on a seat in the grandstand because that is where they have been through this entire tax debate. I might add that they have not even been in the front row of the grandstand. They have not even got into the front row of the grandstand. They have not got into the corporate boxes. They are right up in the terraces sitting under the umbrella sheltering from the rain with no friends. They are so irrelevant, so out of the TV picture, right up there on the terraces because they have nothing to say about the tax debate. They have no contribution to make. They are talking about the flower decorations while we build the new economy.

They are talking about trivial matters. They are trying to nitpick on matters of comparatively limited significance while failing to make any kind of an attempt to capture the vision of what is going to happen when we build a new tax system for the people of Australia. Labor have lost their opportunity. I was interested to hear the member for Lilley talk about St Vincent de Paul and comment on the lost opportunity. Indeed, the lost opportunity was the lost opportunity the Labor Party had to participate in a relevant way in this important debate. In this debate that will shape the future of our national tax system, Labor prefers to sit in the grandstand in GST-free seats, because that is where they want to beâonlookers playing no real part.

Even when the honourable member for Lilley got his grand opportunity to make his landmark speechâafter claiming to make the only contribution to the Leader of the Opposition's new vision for Australia with the jobs bonus, something that would have contributed absolutely nothing towards getting people back into work, the member chose an out of the way stage at the Evatt Foundationâhis passion, his vision for the future was to tell us that Labor's social welfare policy had failed and he was thinking of this great new idea called mutual obligation. Whenever I have heard the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business talk about mutual obligation, Labor have said what a shocking horror it is.
Mr Swan interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe member for Lilley, stop sounding off.

âThe Lord Mayor of Brisbane won't support mutual obligation, but the member for Lilley has deserted his Labor colleague in Brisbane and he is now talking about mutual obligation in the welfare system. Maybe he has at last found the key to some new Labor reinvention of their attitude towards social welfare. Sadly, Labor have been marginalised absolutelyâup in the grandstand, taking no interest whatever in this whole debate.

speech.para: It is a tragedy that a party that has over the years always prided itself on trying to be the party for the battlerâthe party that wants to look after the poor, those who are disadvantagedâhas been well and truly trumped by a caring and compassionate government that consists of the Liberal and National parties. The coalition has delivered and will deliver, with the benefit now of an agreement from one of the minor parties in the other place, to the pensioners and battlers of Australia a new tax system that will provide real benefits to all Australian taxpayers.

Every Australian taxpayer will pay less tax. Over 80 per cent of Australian taxpayers will pay 30 cents in the dollar or less. That provides real incentive for people to earn that extra dollar to be able to care better for their family, to ensure that the benefits of their labours return to their own lifestyle. When St Vincent de Paul and others have been critical of benefits provided to low income earners they have not been, like the Labor Party, prepared to tear down the benefits of encouraging people who want to go out and work and to keep some of those benefits for themselves. It is a very clear statement of fact over the years that you do not benefit the poor by punishing middle income earners and the rich. By encouraging and providing incentives across the board, you provide the rewards and incentives that are necessary to build a stronger economy. Governments do not create jobs. Governments do not create wealth. That is done by the labours of Australians, by those who are prepared to invest and expand. You only encourage that kind of investment and expansion when you have a tax system that rewards effort, that rewards and encourages those people who are prepared to put in that extra effort.

Our system does not just benefit the workersâthose with jobs, those with incomes, those with medium or higher incomes. They certainly benefit, but it also provides an important social bonus for the poor. We should not talk about the four per cent increase to pensions as being compensation. It is more than compensation. It provides a two per cent indexed real bonus for pensioners, a real improvement in their standard of living. Is that what the member for Lilley is condemningâan improvement in the standard of living for pensioners? Is the member for Lilley also condemning the bonuses that we propose to provide to self-funded retirees, to others who are poor and who have set money aside in their working life for their own retirement? They are going to receive the benefits of this package as well. Are those the sorts of people that the Leader of the Opposition chooses to condemn?

The other interesting point that the Labor Party always want us to forget in this taxation debate is that they are experts at putting up taxes. They are experts at inventing new taxes. These are the people who told us faithfully there will be no capital gains tax and then turned around within a month or two and introduced the toughest capital gains tax in the world.
Honourable members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The members for Dawson, Richmond and Grayndler will not interject when they are not in their places.

âThese are the people who told us we would have l-a-w tax cuts and then revoked them at the first available opportunity. These are also the people who delivered at the same time the biggest increase in indirect taxes in the history of our nation through Labor's wholesale sales tax system. When they introduced all of those tax increases, what was their compensation package? What did they do for the poor? What did they do for the disadvantaged? Absolutely nothing. These are the poor people who had to pay all these tax increases and got absolutely nothing. There was no four per cent increase in benefits up-front. There were no increases in benefits for the poor under Labor. They could not care less about this group of people.

speech.para: They tried to scare and frighten pensioners. The member for Lilley is a champion at that, running around the bush trying to whip up a frenzy of concern instead of trying to educate people to give them the opportunity to understand the real benefits this package will provide to all. We are offering not only a four per cent increase in pensions, not only bonuses to the self-funded retirees and others who are put aside, not only massive increases in family benefits, not only the new benefits that will be provided across the whole social welfare system, but also the benefits that flow through to the nation as a wholeârich and poorâfrom having an economy that works more effectively, where there is more investment, where there are more jobs. The best thing you can always do for an unemployed person is to give them a job. Yes, we want to make sure their living standards are not disadvantaged, and this particular tax package will certainly ensure those incomes are protected. In addition to that, this package offers a new taxation arrangement for Australia that will reward investment, that will encourage people to seek out the jobs that are available and to take the best possible advantage from them.

I would also like to mention some of the other benefits included in this package for those who are less well off. There will be increases in the income and assets test free area, which will mean something like 45,000 additional Australians will qualify, for the first time, for a part pension and the benefits that are associated with that. Labor wants to vote against giving those 45,000 people access to the age pension and other benefitsâ45,000 people whom Labor does not want to give benefits to. What about the others who will get the benefit of the increases in the tax rebate to pensioners and low income earners? What about the benefits under the aged person's savings bonus? That is a tax-free benefit up to $1,000 for people over 60.

What I was amazed about with the opposition in their absolute frenzy and annoyance that the Democrats have trumped them in getting involved in the tax debate was their criticism that somehow or other this deal was unfair. It is a deal that actually took the GST off standard items of foodâso reducing the potential rise in the cost of living as a result of the new packageâbut it kept the entire compensation package in place. Is that unfair? Is it unfair to give pensioners an even better deal? It seems to be for the member for Lilley. He does not like good deals for pensioners; he likes better deals even less it seems. These benefits flow through to people and will certainly be appreciated by the people of Australia from 1 July.
Mr Albanese interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI was also interested when the Leader of the Opposition and, for that matter, the member for Lilley made comments about the impact of the GST and referred to the Australian Bureau of Statistics household expenditure survey. I will put aside the fact that, when they were in government, Labor considered this survey to be worthless and of no value at all. Now they are in opposition, they are happy to quote from the survey. The member for Lilley went through the survey and identified that three-quarters of the budget of pensioners would be subject to GST and only about a quarter of it would be GST free.

speech.para: Mr Albanese interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe member for Grayndler's deposits of goodwill of the chair are rapidly diminishing.

âWhat the member for Lilley always chooses to ignore is that many of these items that will have GST on them currently carry the wholesale sales tax, often at rates of up to 32 per cent. In fact, there will be some items that currently have wholesale sales tax on them that will be GST free in the future. Certainly the system where items which a pensioner has to buy every week that currently attract a wholesale sales taxâLabor's favoured tax option with up to 32 per cent tax on pensioners and welfare beneficiariesâgoes. Labor like to ignore that fact, unless they are going to vote to retain those taxes as well. Presumably so. They like to have these sorts of regressive taxes that affect pensioners in this way. The member for Lilley refuses to acknowledge that fact in assessing the real impact of the new tax package on pensioners and welfare beneficiaries.

speech.para: So this indeed is a matter of public importance for the people of Australia and for those who are poor and disadvantaged in our community. They want an improvement in their standard of living. They want the opportunity to enjoy the benefits that our society can offer. This tax package offers that opportunity, and it is time the Labor Party supported it. It is time they supported a four per cent increase in pensions. It is time they supported the benefits for self-funded retirees. It is time they supported the benefit, for low income earners. It is time they supported the benefits for our economy to deliver a much better Australia for the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt seems that the Prime Minister's great tax adventure has come undone. The shadow minister for family and community services was put in mind of the story of Little Red Riding Hood. I was reminded of another story, and that was J.R. Tolkien's story The Hobbit , where a motley collection of dwarves and hobbits go on an adventure to find a magical ring. We are about at the point of the story where the hobbits get lost in the murky forest of Mirkwood and the spiders are rapidly approaching.

speech.para: The Australian public know that this tax cannot be made fair and it cannot be made popular. For that reason, the Australian Newspoll figures today show that about 33 per cent of voters support the Democrats-government GST deal, while 58 per cent of Australians oppose it. The deal is opposed by 58 per cent of the people, and that is because they understand the details of this tax now. They understand that the Democrats' deal will not protect them from the adverse effects of the GST. They know they will not be protected, and that is why 19 per cent of Australians have shifted their support for the GST since May.

What is the result amongst the people who have negotiated this deal? They are very busily blaming each other for the deal. They cannot blame each other fast enough. It was very interesting to read Glenn Milne's piece this week. He pointed out that Peter Costello was the first to distance himself from the deal. Milne reported that his decision was to:
. . . distance himself publicly for 24 hours last Monday .. serving notice that this was the PM's compromiseânot his.

Then we see that John Howard has been telling others that, if the coalition loses the next election, it is not going to be his fault. No, it is not going to be his fault, having negotiated the deal; it is going to be Peter Costello's fault.

talk.start.para: âI think you mean the Treasurer's fault.

âIt is going to be the Treasurer's fault because he is the person responsible for implementing the deal. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has also made it very clear that he is not associated with this deal. In fact, he has given the Prime Minister the kiss of death by publicly acknowledging the Prime Minister's very central role in negotiating this deal. Milne reported Reith as saying that the man:

speech.para: . . . who has provided leadership in this issue, doggedly, persistently, with determination for over 20 years is none other than the Prime Minister.

They cannot blame each other fast enough. The Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, has an election coming up later this year and he cannot blame the federal government fast enough either. It is certainly not going to be Jeff Kennett's GST. He is also suggesting amendments and criticising the onerous implementation measures that small businesses will face.

Senators Stott Despoja and Lees are also very busy blaming each other for the breakdown in the Democrats' united front on a GST, but the Australian public know who will be to blame when this GST is implemented. They know that the government and the Democrats will share culpability for this new tax. The government are culpable because they are the ones who wanted this unfair tax to start with. The Prime Minister has pursued his obsession for over 20 years, and the government are the ones who have undertaken to deliver huge tax cuts to high income earners at the expense of ordinary Australians.

The Democrats are culpable because they made 16 pledges to the Australian electorate before the last election and every single one of them has been broken. They have broken their pledge on food. They have broken their pledge on books. They have broken their pledge to protect the environment. They have broken all of those pledges. They had a strong negotiating position when they went into negotiations with the government and they have given away that strong negotiating position. Australians will blame them when this tax is implemented, and they will blame them when the environmental effects of the diesel fuel measures come into effect as well.

What is particularly disappointing about the Democrats' deal is not only that they negotiated away, they gave away, their position of strength but that they are claiming victories for things that are not victories at all. They are claiming victories for things that the government was going to do anyway. It is certainly not a good example of negotiating from a position of strength.

While they have been very busy feeling important in their negotiations with the government, it is good to see that they have kept their priorities right. I was pleased to read a piece by Dennis Shanahan in the Australian which said that the Democrats want to reassure Australians that they can enjoy their favourite breads, from focaccia to Turkish pide and cheese topped rolls, without paying a GST! Really, they are giving away so much and yet focusing on the details of whether Australians can eat focaccia and pide.

I am sure that many people in my electorate will be pleased that their pide will not be taxed, but really it is pretty poor compensation for the fact that education will be taxed, that many health products will be taxed, that gas, electricity, books and insuranceâall of those necessities of lifeâwill be taxed. The public transport that most of my electors take to get to work will also be taxed, and that is pretty poor comfort for the fact that they will be able to eat tax-free pide. We have to really look at who the real losers will be from this tax.
Opposition member interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is right. The shadow minister interjects that aromatherapy is also going to be GST free, and that is a great comfort as well.

speech.para: The compensation package negotiated by the Democrats is simply not good enough. At the Press Club a few months ago, Senator Lees said that the compensation package that Senator Harradine was speaking about was a `paltry, inadequate sum'. This `paltry, inadequate sum' is twice what the Democrats have finally settled for. A two per cent increase in social security benefits will absolutely not be enough to compensate those people who rely on social security, but it also will not compensate those many people on low incomes who do not have access to social security, including new migrants, unemployed young people between 18 and 20, mature aged unemployed people with superannuation assets, self-employed people without children, workers compensation recipients, people with disability or chronic illness and Australians in rural and remote areas, especially remote Aboriginal communities.

It is worth bearing in mind not only the sorts of prices that these communities are already paying for fresh fruit and vegetables in particular but also many of the things that will be taxed under the GST, many of the types of food that will be taxed. Of course, full-time wage earners and self-employed people on very low incomes who also are not beneficiaries of social security benefits will pay this major new tax on all the necessities of life.

The tax breaks are still skewed to high income earners. All taxpayers with incomes over $60,000 will still gain that tax cut of $62 a week. The Democrats are congratulating themselves while forgetting that many of the poor people who are included in the list that I have just mentioned will still pay this extra tax on all the necessities of life.

The implementation of this tax is going to continue to be a nightmare. The Democrats have done nothing to make this easierâin fact they have made it even harder. Small businesses will certainly not thank the Democrats for the complication that they have added to this tax, particularly those corner shops that will be taxing some of their products and not taxing others. It is going to be an absolute nightmare for them. I do not see how the Democrats can even think of congratulating themselves for this absolute dog's breakfast of a tax that they have negotiated with the government.

ACOSS, St Vincent de Paul and other organisations have pointed out that this tax will definitely not benefit low income earners. ACOSS have said that `the Senate should not pass this tax in its current form'. They have said that all taxpayers with a taxable income over $60,000 still get their $62 a week tax cut, thus widening the inequality. St Vincent de Paul have also pointed out many of the inequities in this new tax.

My final word to the Democrats is: you cannot make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. It is not too late. You are able to change your minds on 21 June and walk away from this tax. There is no way that this tax can be made fair. There is no way that this tax can be made popular. The Democrats should realise the error of their ways, realise that they have been done over by the masters, realise that they have been negotiated into a corner, and they should walk away on 21 June.

talk.start.para: âThis so-called matter of public importance really is the ultimate act of desperation and hypocrisy by the Labor Party. Having sat on the sidelines, they are now frantically trying to write themselves into the tax reform equation. So what do the ALP do in times of crisis? They reach into their well-worn bag of tricks and dig out the old class warfare line. No amount of compensationâadequate, generous or over the moonâwould have prevented the Labor Party from raising this MPI today. It is their standard fall-back to say that some Australians will be better off at the expense of low and middle income earners even when they know it is not true. The fact is that nothing could be further from the truth.

speech.para: The original tax package, which the Australian people endorsed last October when they voted the Howard government back into office, provided adequate protection for low and middle income earners. That is proven by the fact that not one single bit of evidence was brought before the Senate inquiry into the GST that anyone would be worse off under our packageânot a single fact, and this is the case. Sure, there was a debate about how some people may be more better off than others, but the fact is that, even with our original package, no-one was going to be worse off.

I know it is a difficult concept for Labor, but the new tax package was actually about collecting less tax overall from the Australian people than is currently the case. After years of Labor continually increasing taxes when they were in officeâand I know this is a difficult concept for them to get their heads aroundâwe are actually going to collect less tax. So, under the original package, low and middle income Australians, along with all other Australians, were actually going to have more money in their pockets.

The new package negotiated with the Democrats goes even further to provide protection for low and middle income earners. It provides all the same tax cuts for the low and middle income earners, as well as increases in pensions and benefits, no GST on most food items, and a whole range of other positive benefits. So, if the Senate inquiry failed to find that anyone was going to be worse off under our original package, this new package absolutely guarantees an even better deal for low and middle income earners.

I could go on at length about the many ways in which the new tax package provides not only protection for low and middle income earners but real lasting benefits. But time does not permit me to list all the improvements and, in any case, I doubt if anyone on the other side would even be listening. What I want to ask is: how on earth does the member for Lilley have the gall to come into this place and play politics with such an important issue? I suppose the Labor Party are running out of stunts with chicken and soup. That is about the extent of their imagination and vision when it comes to the important issue of tax reform in the 21st century. I will bet that the discussion today in their caucus meeting went something like this: `Let's pull a few political stunts to get the journalists going. We'll trot out the old class warfare line.' It is such a predictable game plan for the ALP and it is getting quite boring.

As someone who raised eight children under the 13 years that Labor were in office, I am surprised that they have the nerve to come into this place and pretend to be champions of low and middle income Australians. I can tell them that, under Labor, low and middle income earners, particularly families, pensioners and self-funded retirees, were squeezed from every direction. They talk about fairness and compensation now. How fair was it when, before the March 1993 election, they promised Australian people no new taxes and then, in their very first budget in 1993, they increased every single wholesale sales taxâ

talk.start.para: âShame!

âIt definitely was a shame. Ten per cent went to 12 per cent, 20 per cent went to 22 per cent, 30 per cent went to 32 per cent, and so on. On top of that, they increased petrol taxâand it was proportionately higher for low and middle income earners, many of whom drive old cars fuelled by leaded petrol. And on top of that, they did not deliver the l-a-w tax cuts which they promised. So, by way of bracket creep, they clawed more money from low and middle income earners. And where was the protection? Where was Labor's compensation for low and middle income earners? There was not a scrap; not one single cent.

speech.para: What the Australian public got from the Labor government, as well as their tax increases, was a massive blow-out in the government's debt and a horrendous ongoing interest bill. In fact, in their last five years, the ALP increased government debt from $16 billion to $96 billion. The interest every year, on that $96 billion alone, is a whopping $9 billion. And every Australian pays for Labor's debtâlow and middle income earners more than most. Labor left us with a $9 billion bill, for interest alone, every year. That means $9 billion less for hospitals, roads, support payments and social programsâevery year from now until forever, as far as the Labor Party were concerned.

It is only the coalition government, through responsible economic management, that has begun to pay back Labor's debt. We have, remarkably, turned the Keating-Beazley $10 billion budget black hole into a surplus of over $5 billion, so we can tackle the debt and reduce the crippling interest payment every year. But the ALP even tried to stop us doing that. After our first few budgets, they decried our reducing the deficit and bringing in a surplus. They said it was not necessary. As always, they were obstructionist and irrelevant. If we had followed Labor's path of debt and deficit, where would Australia be in the wake of the Asian financial crisis? A few things are certain: we would not be the fastest growing economy in the world right now, at 4.8 per cent; Australian families would not be enjoying the enormous benefits of the lowest home loan interest rates in over 30 years; unemployment would not be at its lowest level in nearly 10 years; and we would not be able to afford the many necessary compas sionate social programs that this government continues to deliver.

We are determined to continue to deliver our promises of tax cuts for low and middle income earners. Let us be clear about this: in opposing this package, Labor are opposing the largest reduction in personal income tax in Australia's history. In opposing this package, Labor are telling farmers and all Australians living in regional and rural areas that they must continue to pay enormous transport costs. And as someone who represents the regional and rural townships of Beaudesert and Boonah, I know that the single biggest concern farmers and business people in these areas have is the transport costs that they must incur, along with the income tax that they pay.

It seems to me that everyone in Australia can see that Labor's taxation system is a mess. The personal tax system robs people of the incentive to work harderâand takes too much from low and middle income earners. The sales tax system was designed in the 1930s, and it is a complex, ramshackle disaster. Everyone accepts that tax reform is the next logical step towards securing Australia's future responsibilityâeveryone, that is, except the Labor Party. The sad thing is that, deep down, Labor know that we are doing the right thing. But they are not prepared to say it, because they think they can win a few votes by opposing us.

My electorate of Forde covers many low income areas. I have lived, worked and raised my family there for the past 25 years. My constituents recognise that we need a fair tax system to take us into the 21st century. The Democrats also realise this, and I congratulate them for their actions in putting the national interest first. I can assure Meg Lees that she has gained respect from mainstream Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe real opposition.

âThank you. She has gained respect particularly from the people in my electorate of Forde for her commonsense approach and her willingness to work with the government to make positive achievements. It is such a stark contrast to Labor's approachâas this ridiculous MPI today testifies.

speech.para: I would like to cite just one final example of why the Australian Labor Party have absolutely no credibility when it comes to pretending to champion the cause of low income people. Under Labor's economic mismanagement, home loan interest rates hit 17 per cent, which forced many low and middle income earning Australian families to either take a second mortgage or sell their homes. I know how this felt, because I was one of the many Australian residents who were forced to take out a second mortgage at that time. Like many Australians, I continue to pay for Labor's failed approach. It just astounds me that Labor fly in the face of all commonsense and continue to oppose every single sensible plan of this government. It is clear they have not learnt from their mistakes.

Even before our tax package is put into place, there are reports that Labor will make political mileage out of promising to exempt many more things from the GST. Not only will this make this system more complex, but we have to ask: how much will it cost and where will the money come from? There are only two ways: by raising other taxes or running up more debt. Going on Labor's track record, it will probably be the worst possible combination of both. (Time expired)

2Mr Ripoll to move:

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 June, on motion by Mr Hockey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999 and cognate bills. I note that the shadow minister has indicated that the opposition will be supporting the bill as well, and so it should. The reform of the trusts legislation is an important part of the overall reform of the taxation system. I would certainly congratulate both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer on their far-reaching reforms of the overall tax systemâthe most significant tax reforms we have seen since Federation and certainly the most significant we have seen in this chamber. Through this legislation, the government intends to eliminate the unfair advantages for those who use this particular type of tax approach, while at the same time respecting the role of trusts as well-used vehicles for asset protection and holdings by farmers, small business and others in the community.

speech.para: In the public debate, trusts have been characterised by the Labor Party as being a mechanism for the very rich. The reality is that they are widely used by small business and professionals as well as investors in listed property trusts. Likewise, there are many legitimate reasons why closely held trusts should be used and why they contain multiple trusts. It is clear, however, that there has been a significant growth in the number of trusts and that a certain number of these trusts and that multiple trusts are being used to give individuals an unfair tax advantage or to make it difficult for the Australian Taxation Office to piece together the trail of distributions.

In 1996-97 there were 427,431 trusts lodged in Australia, up from 331,000 in 1993-94. The number of companies has also increased over this period but not at the same rate. The Australian Taxation Office has stated that the relative rates of growth of trusts and companies could reflect the different tax treatment of both trusts and companies. The Australian Taxation Office has commented on the use of trusts as follows:

The preference for a discretionary trust over a company structure or vice versa is dependent upon a range of factors including establishment and operating costs, the taxation treatment of income from companies compared with income from discretionary trusts, the capital gains tax treatment of shares compared with interest in a discretionary trust, and the relative level of the company tax rate.

Along with the measures contained in this bill, the government has also brought changes to ensure that trusts are taxed in the same way as companies in many regards. That is a fairly logical, sensible approach to this whole process of tax reform, which of course is symbolic of the whole reform of the tax system and the GST system itself.

According to the Australian Taxation Office figures, discretionary trusts have grown by some 30 per cent in the last decade. The main reason behind this growth in popularity is that they are effective tax shelters. Trusts distribute all income and realised capital gains tax free. Tax is paid by the beneficiaries at normal income tax rates. Trustees have complete discretion as to how income tax and gains are distributed.

The current taxation laws in respect of returns and assessments have certain deficiencies, including where the net income of a trust estate is passed through a series of trusts without any ultimate beneficiary having been named or assessed on that net income either because there is no ultimate beneficiary or because the ultimate beneficiary cannot be identified. A trust deed may, for example, describe a class of persons from which the trustee may select to distribute trust moneys. There may not, however, at a particular point in time, be any persons who fall within the described class. In this situation, there will not be any ultimate beneficiary.

The government's new tax system is about fairness and ensuring people pay their fair share. The government wishes to see that wealthy individuals and businesses which are normally in a position to avoid paying their fair share of tax are less able to do so. I think all members of this House would agree with that proposal. The estimated revenue gains expected through this measure alone will amount to some $30 million in each of the 1999-2000 and 2000-01 years. This money will lessen the burden of the average taxpayer and will find its way through consolidated revenue to social programs and paying off Commonwealth debt. While the ALP clearly does not place the same importance on paying off national debt, it nevertheless recognises the abuse that exists in the trust system. Reform of the trusts legislation was a major part of the Labor pre-election tax package.

Taxation Office computers have discovered a rort known as a circular trust program, thought to have died out in the 1970s. In one technique known as `substituted reporting dates', some trusts have shuffled income from one trust to another and then back again. The Taxation Office has said that there is evidence that some taxpayers are using complex chains to make it difficult for the tax office to piece together the trail of distributions from trust to trust to establish liability. Mr Gil Levy, a partner at Arthur Andersen, said that he suspected that some trusts have been swamping the system with so many returns that no-one really knew whether tax was being collected along the way or not.

The three bills before us deal with these issues. They propose measures that are generally very well targeted, and it is reasonable to expect only opposition from tax avoiders and their financial advisers because of their vested interests and from the opposition. In this case, we know that the opposition will be supporting us.

Taxpayers and ordinary Australians stand to make significant gains. Firstly, the aim of the A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999 is to correct deficiencies in the existing law and will require the trustee of a closely held trust to provide the Commissioner of Taxation with the tax file numbers of the ultimate beneficiaries of certain net income and tax preferred amounts distributed from trusts. This will apply where the immediate distribution is made by one trust to another trustâfor example, where a chain of trusts is involved. Secondly, where there is no such disclosure, the A New Tax System (Ultimate Beneficiary Non-disclosure Tax) Bill (No. 1) 1999 imposes tax on the part of the net income at the top marginal rate plus the Medicare levy. The non-disclosure of tax preferred amounts produces offences under the Tax Administration Act 1953. Thirdly, where there is no ultimate beneficiary, the A New Tax System (Ultimate Beneficiary Non-disclosure Tax) Bill (No. 2) 1999 imposes a tax on part of the net income at the top marginal rate plus the Medicare levy plus the penalties for not doing so.

The two main concerns with this bill cover the liability of trust directors and the burden of these measures on all discretionary trusts. Both are unfounded. The first question is in regard to the liability of trust directors. Not surprisingly, there have been some negative reactions to this. We found comments in the Financial Review about this. In an article appearing in the Financial Review on 26 May 1999, solicitor Robert Richards claimed that this legislation `does not protect a director who in good faith tries to do the right thing'. It is necessary to point out that, under section 102UL, which relates to ultimate liability, directors are specifically excluded from liability if, because of illness or other good reason, they did not take part in the decision to make a correct ultimate beneficiary statement; they did not take part in a decision not to make a correct ultimate beneficiary statement; they were aware of a decision not to make a correct statement but took reasonable steps to prevent the making of that decision; or they voted against the majority decision not to make a correct ultimate beneficiary statement.

The let-outs given to directors are exhaustive and cover all the legitimate reasons for an individual director being held liable. Secondly, the inclusion of a discretionary trust in the definition of a closely held trust is claimed to spread the compliance burden too far. The definition of a closely held trust is also criticised by tax avoidance advisers, who stand to lose another loophole. Their complaint mainly centres on the fact that a closely held trust includes trusts where up to 20 individuals are entitled to a 75 per cent or greater share of income of capital of the trust or a discretionary trust, and discretionary trusts themselves. There is an unfounded fear that this measure will force some 60,000 trusts to engage in more paperwork. It is seen incorrectly as a penalty compliance burden imposed on many to control cheating by a few.

These proposals do not go beyond the original intention, however. The only trusts that can be affected are those which are closely held and have other trusts as beneficiaries. All discretionary trusts are treated as closely held trusts for the purpose of the proposal, but most will not have any trusts as beneficiaries and therefore will never be affected. The only trustees that will find these measures burdensome are those who operate complex trust chains. It will not be known how many trusts are set up as part of complex structures until these measures are implemented. The government has specifically excluded a number of types of trusts from this measure. These include complying superannuation funds, deceased estates, and fixed and Stock Exchange listed unit trusts.

We see from the proposals under these three new bills that there are some changes that will be beneficial to the tax system and will yield additional revenue of the order of $30 million in the next two financial years. It will close many of the loopholes where the ultimate beneficiary is not spelled out or the circuitous route is so complex that, from the way in which the whole trust is set up, it is not clear which person is ultimately respon sible. The purpose of these bills is to get to those particular individuals or to those trusts which are simply aimed at avoiding legitimate tax. There is no doubt that many of these trusts are used for entirely legitimate reasons. They are used by small business and they are used by farmers, but there are those who simply use them to avoid paying their fair share of tax. I am sure that all members of this House would want the government to retrieve income tax where it is legitimately due and these three bills will do much to address this in relation to trusts. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe government has promised some action on tax avoidance and evasion, using trusts in its so-called A New Tax System package. Indeed, when it needed revenue to fund the loosening fiscal policy resulting from the totality of its new tax package, it claimed significant revenue increases from a package of revenue measures it called `consistent treatment of entities', which included taxing trusts as companies.

speech.para: They claimed a positive budgetary impact of $1.67 billion in 2000-01, declining to $650 million in 2002-03, yet we have not seen those bills; we have seen only these ones. It is a small measure to deal with some of the abuses of trust structures for the purpose of tax avoidance and evasion. It requires the disclosure of the ultimate beneficiaries of income from trusts. That is so the tax commissioner can check whether each beneficiary has properly disclosed that net income or their net assets include the receipt of any tax preferred amounts. Failing that disclosure, the income of the trust will be taxed at the top marginal rate plus the Medicare levy. These requirements, however, apply only to closely held trusts. These are defined in the bill as:

(a) a trust where an individual has, or up to 20 individuals have between them, directly or indirectly, and for their own benefit, fixed entitlements to a 75% or greater share of the income, or a 75% or greater share of the capital, of the trust
or
(b) a discretionary trust.

A discretionary trust is a trust that is not a fixed trustâthat is, one where persons have fixed entitlements to all of the income and assets of the trust. A fixed entitlement is an indefeasible interest in a share of the income or assets of a trust.

The bill specifically excludes unit trusts with units listed on the Stock Exchange; complying superannuation funds, deposit funds, pooled superannuation trusts; and deceased estates until the fifth anniversary of the death. The fact that it is only expected to raise an additional $30 million a year is a demonstration of how limited this measure is. There are many greater tax avoidance and evasion issues associated with trusts. The government's reluctance to come to grips with these avoidance and evasion issues shows how disinterested it is in real tax reform that protects the revenue and makes everyone pay their fair share. There is every sign the government wants little more than a few measures it can point to to deflect criticism about its lack of action. The lack of speed and commitment in this area has now reached the dimension of a scandal of such proportions that in the context of this bill it requires a second reading amendment. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House notes that:
(1) In relation to tax avoidance
(a) the Government has failed for three years to take adequate action to deal with major tax avoidance and evasion by high wealth individuals using complex trust structures;
(b) lack of action is causing major ongoing losses of revenue;

(c) at the time these aggressive tax avoidance and evasion schemes were first identified by the Australian Taxation Office in late 1995 and early 1996 an amount of $800 million was being evaded by 80 high wealth individuals;
(d) some of the high wealth individuals participating in these schemes were manipulating their taxable incomes to declare as little as $20,000 a year and so claim various government benefits;
(e) the legislative action required to eliminate these schemes is well understood by the Australian Taxation Office; and
(f) the lack of adequate action on tax avoidance and evasion using trusts is an indicator of the Government's failure to provide proper and fair tax reforms; and.
(2) In relation to so called taxation reform, of which this bill forms a part as a component of the New Tax System;
(a) the government has not achieved real tax reforms in Australia, it has merely agreed to introduce an unfair GST;
(b) the new Howard/Lees GST will involve a massive tax mix switch which will hurt ordinary families, which is directly contrary to the balloted policy of the Australian Democrats;
(c) the Howard/Lees deal will actually increase the tax on food in Australia;
(d) ordinary people will now face a GST on top of state indirect taxes on bank accounts; and
(e) the amended tax package is still unfair and will also damage the environment".

It is obvious to anyone with a serious interest in tax policy that there is scope for tax avoidance and evasion using trust structures. Throughout 1994 and 1995 the Treasurer's office pressed Treasury for advice on the extent of the problem and possible remedies. It was raised on an almost weekly basis in meetings with the department. Nothing was forthcoming until 9 November 1995 when the Australian Taxation Officeânot the Treasury, the tax officeâadvised that they had uncovered a significant problem using multiple trust structures. They had been using new software which was capable of finding patterns in large amounts of seemingly unrelated information.

They had found that large numbers of seemingly unrelated trusts were in fact related and a range of techniques were being used by high wealth individuals to reduce tax liabilities to low or negligible levels. Treasury and the tax office worked on the issue over the next three months, eventually advising the Treasurer that it would be appropriate to make a public announcement that the government would act to end these practices.
The press release issued by Treasurer Ralph Willis on 11 February 1996 accurately set out the issues. It was titled, `High Wealth IndividualsâTaxation of Trusts', and read:

On November 9, 1995 I was informed by the Australian Taxation Office that as part of the Compliance Enforcement Strategy authorised by the Government, it had conducted analysis of the accumulation of wealth by certain individuals and the taxes paid by them. That analysis revealed that some high wealth individuals were employing strategies which allowed them to accumulate wealth, enjoy a lavish lifestyle, but pay little or no tax. The analysis was in its early stages but the ATO believed the revenue implications might amount to several hundred million dollars.

At my request, the ATO and Treasury provided more extensive advice and analysis on December 20 1995. It revealed that in the 1993 financial year, 80 individuals each with a net worth of over $30 million had returned taxable incomes of $20,000 or less. This enabled some of them to qualify for low income rebates, Medicare exemptions, deferral of HECS payments and reduced child support payments. The tax minimisation techniques employed by these individuals mainly involved the use of trusts.

By January 19, 1996, the ATO and Treasury were able to advise that on the basis of the work undertaken to date in respect to 100 wealthy individuals alone, appropriate measures to deal with a range of specific tax minimisation techniques using trusts would produce additional revenue of at least $500 million. Later at a meeting on January 23, 1996, Treasury gave me verbal advice raising that estimate to $800 million. Some amount could be forthcoming in 1996-97, but the first full year effect would be in 1997-98.

The January 19, 1996 advice also included separate revenue estimates in addition to the $800 million for techniques involving thin capitalisation and abuses of the provisions for payments by trusts to foreign charities.
The ATO has identified a number of complex tax planning arrangements used by some wealthy individuals to avoid tax, these include:

- the characterisation of income as capital by the use of multiple trust structures to conceal a common controlling mind. If the activities of the various trusts and associated companies were viewed as a whole, the profits of the group could be treated as trading income. The ATO has found a number of cases of wealthy individuals operating over 100 trusts;
- the creation of artificial losses (revenue as well as capital) to neutralise otherwise taxable profits, particularly through the use of related party transactions;

- distributions to wealthy individuals and family members being disguised as loans and other benefits which are claimed to be non-taxable. In relation to companies this includes exploitation of alleged weaknesses in section 47A and 108 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, of the deemed dividend provisions;
- the continued use of offshore trusts to hold significant funds which seem to be applied for the benefit of wealthy individuals and their families; and
- the use of Australian charitable trusts and overseas organisations to disguise benefits provided by family trading trusts to family members.

Obviously, these are not techniques which are practised by the overwhelming majority of trusts operated by and for Australians. Trusts provide an appropriate structure to meet a range of legitimate needs such as for charities, education and non-profit organisations, deceased estates, a variety of family purposes, and for solicitors and other professionals. The Government will not interfere with these arrangements. The Government undertakes that the measures it will adopt will ensure that activities not involving tax avoidance are not adversely affected.

No responsible government could stand back and let blatant abuse of the tax system by extremely wealthy individuals continue. The ATO is undertaking action to test the effectiveness of the existing law to deal with some of these practices. However, it is not expected that an outcome will be achieved by these means in the near future due to the long time frames involved in testing issues before the courts. The ATO has advised that it is particularly difficult to run test cases in these areas because the individuals concerned will settle at the end of the day rather than have their private affairs or practices exposed to the public.

On January 29, 1996, I wrote to the Secretary of the Treasury and the Commissioner for Taxation, asking them as a matter of urgency to develop a legislative response to cover income from the 1996-97 financial year. The new tax measures which the Government will introduce to deal with these specific areas of tax avoidance will be prospective not retrospective.

One of the most important things this Labor Government has given Australia since it was elected in 1983 is a tax system based on the principle of integrity and fairness. Maintaining that basic integrity and fairness requires stamping out tax avoidance wherever and whenever it emerges.

The reason these measures are being announced today is because the Government is seeking a mandate to deal with this area of tax avoidance. We call on the other parties in this election to support these reforms. I am offering Mr Howard a briefing this afternoon from the Commissioner of Taxation.
I think the shadow Treasurer of the day received a briefing the next day.

More than three years have now passed and the two substantial things that have changed are the government and the fact that Australia no longer has a government with the will to do anything about this scandal. If the Howard government had any interest in the fairness and integrity of the Australian tax system, it would have legislated to put an end to this abuse in its first year.

Two weeks before the 1998 election, when the government needed money to fund the tax cuts contained in its ANTS package and when it knew Labor would raise this issue, it came out with a plan to tax trusts as companies. Eight months later, we still have not seen the legislation. But it is not just eight months since the task was put in front of them; it is three years, three months and 25 days. Perhaps the Treasurer is shooting for the record on inaction on major tax fraud. Former Fraser government Attorney-General, Peter Durack, left the prosecution file for the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes in his bottom drawer for seven years. If the Liberal government can win the next election, the Treasurer has the chance to beat Durack's record.

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister supported him too.

âThank you for that interjection, Mr Emerson. We are now being told that the government will produce its solution to this problem in the Ralph Review of Business Taxation. It is a bit more urgent than that. It has been a bit more urgent than that for more than three years. At the 1998 federal election, Labor indicated its preparedness to tax trusts as companies, so it is not a matter of political debate between the Labor and Liberal parties. The remedies on trusts were clearly set out in the ANTS package by the Treasurer. Labor wants them implemented as quickly as possible. But now the election is out of the way the issue has been put off. Why has a policy which was clear enough to be included in the government's election policies become too difficult? Why is this the case when we have been hearing regularly from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for over a year about their determination to stamp out abuse in this area? On 30 September 1997 the Financial Review reported:

speech.para: The Prime Minister ruled out an attack on the abuse of trusts for taxation purposes on the spuri ous grounds that such a move would hurt small business.
The Prime Minister was sufficiently incensed by this to make a personal explanation in the House the same day, saying:

Can I say that I have done no such thing. What I have said, and I am happy to repeat it today, is that I have assured the members of the government parties that in any taxation changes we make we will not be acting in a manner that would seriously damage, or indeed damage at all, small business. But at no stage have I said that my government would never take action against the abuse of trusts. We will always take action against abuses within the tax system.

On 24 February 1998 the Treasurer was reported in the Herald Sun announcing that family and company trusts should be taxed at the same rate as company profits as part of the government's crackdown on tax loopholes. The Australian Financial Review quoted him on the same day saying:
In an ideal tax system, taxes would relate to the economic activity that is being carried on, rather than the legal vehicle which houses that activity.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer are very adept on this issue. They say one thing but they do nothing. Any move to stop tax evasion and avoidance always meets resistance, someone will try to characterise the measure as draconian or claim their activities are legitimate or essential.

According to the Financial Review of 30 September 1998, the coalition's policy was being undermined by the Leader of the National Party even before election day with his letter of 22 September 1998 in political doublespeak to the Australian Cane Farmers Association:

I can assure you that whilst the National Party is committed to stopping any practice of `rorts' through FBT or trusts, it will take all necessary action to ensure that genuine use of distributions of capital from family trusts to beneficiaries will not be subjected to fringe benefits tax.
This contradicted the government's tax policy which said FBT would be:
. . . extended to benefits in excess of $1,000 a year provided by companies to their shareholders or by trustees to trust beneficiaries, where the benefits were not taxed currently.

There was a report in the Australian Financial Review on 30 March this year, following a National Party meeting, that Senator Winston Crane was focusing his attention on preserving the rights of `legitimate' business trusts. Senator Crane claimed he had received a lot of support from his coalition colleagues. The next day, AAP reported Queensland state opposition leader Rob Borbidge had announced that the Queensland National Party would oppose any attempts to tax trusts like companies and that both the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister had been told of the Queensland Nationals' position.
