On 25 May 1999 the Sydney Morning Herald reported that National Party concerns that the Review of Business Taxation proposals would reintroduce death duties on family farms by cracking down on discretionary family trusts had been given a sympathetic hearing among coalition parliamentarians. The report said it was understood the cabinet secretary, Senator Bill Heffernan, was investigating the matter further following a presentation from Queensland solicitors Cleary and Hoare, representing more than 200 farmers. The National Party is apparently hoping the Review of Business Taxation will not pursue proposals to tax trusts as companies.

On 24 May, Glenn Milne reported in the Australian that the Deputy Prime Minister had said, `We'll kill this in Cabinet.' Parliament has sat for several weeks since then, but there has been no personal explanation like the Prime Minister's. On the Sunday program two days ago, the Deputy Prime Minister was again trying to characterise taxing trusts as companies as a death duty. His exact words were:
But, at the end of the day, are we about to retrospectively reintroduce death duties by some approach to trusts? No.
And:
The Government's made no decisions, and we still haven't got the Ralph report, and it will be a little while yet.
That was immediately contradicted, first by Mr Ralph, reported in yesterday's Australian Financial Review as saying:
We can't see where there is any negative effect arising out of proposals being considered that would give effect to an inheritance tax.
It was then contradicted by the Treasurer yesterday when he responded to a question from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition asking him to:
. . . confirm that full implementation of the proposal to tax trusts as companies outlined in your original GST package has been factored into the budget surplus projections?
The Treasurer replied:

The government's policy as announced in A New Tax System, ANTS, stands. The government is proceeding to implement that. In relation to those matters that are fully costed as part of ANTS, they have of course been taken into the budget position.

The noise was coming from the National Party even before the election was over, and it is still coming today. That explains the last eight months' procrastination. But the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are going to have to decide very soon whether their position is best summed up by an incisive comment made by the Minister for Sport and Tourism in her backbench days. On 2 October 1997, she was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying:
Carmody should stop attacking Australians for not paying tax.

That sums up where the Liberal Party have been coming from for the last three years. Nor should we forget in the context of this debate that there are 20 members of the government frontbench who themselves have trusts. We saw today how this government treats conflicts of interest. We can only wait and see what the next excuse will be. Which interest groups and what misrepresentation will we see next? Meanwhile, the tax evaders and avoiders are using Australia as a tax haven and treating the rest of the community with contempt. The tax commissioner can have a good enforcement regime, but he will not be effective if the government fails to give him the tax law to do his job. Any government that lets tax avoidance and evasion of this magnitude go unchecked can never be taken seriously on tax reform.

talk.start.para: âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

âIt is a pleasure to rise to speak on the A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999 . Just to respond to my friend on the other side for a little while, I preface my comments by saying I am not a person who has any involvement with trusts, so I can wipe my hands clean on that one. I remind the opposition that they did have 13 years to bring in this `very effective' legislation that they are now proposing could be brought in. As for tax reform generally in the last 25 years, this government is now in a position to bring fundamental tax reform to Australia for the national good, as no other government has since Federation. This is but one small part of the tax reform process. I will keep coming back to the fact that my friends on the other side, the Labor Party, did have 13 years to deal with this issue, if they think it is the evil that they have stated in this place they believe it to be.

speech.para: Let us look at the growth of trusts in Australia from 1993 to 1994. In 1993-94 there were 331,338 trusts. In 1996-97âthat is, the financial year following the demise of the Labor governmentâthere were 427,431 trusts. There were just under 100,000 trusts formed in that short Keating Labor period. If we break down the growth of trusts in the Labor period, we see that the growth in companies from, say, 1992-93 was 8.2 per centâthat is, about 426,000 companies at that point grew to 559,520. They had a 5.6 per cent growth in 1996-97. If we look at trusts in that period of Labor government that I was quoting, we see that they grew in 1993-94 at a rate of 8.3 per centâhigher than companies were growing. In 1994-95 the number of trusts grew at a rate of 9.6 per cent per annum. If we go to 1995-96, we see growth in trusts at 9.6 per cent. So there were very significant rises in the number of trusts formed in that period of Labor government.

Further, in general information to the House, something I had not realisedâit is all available here in the Bills Digestâis that trusts prominently focus on the property industry, at 42 per cent of the total number of trusts, through to an education trust at 0.1 per cent of the number of trusts. Across the range of industry and primary productionâwhich was mentioned here today, about farmers and the frontbench et ceteraâ5.2 per cent of the number of trusts in Australia are involved.

In the pre-election ANTS, a new tax system, which the government put to the people in 1998 was a very clear undertaking from the government in response to the rhetorical question, `What immediate action has the government taken to address the misuse of trusts?' Here I quote from the pre-election document which was taken to the people:

The government has taken immediate action to deal with an area where the Australian Tax Office has found evidence of trusts being used for tax minimisation. This is the use of complex chains of trusts which disguise the ultimate beneficiary and make it difficult to collect the tax.

So the government did act, and it certainly put to the people before the election of 1998 what it intended to do. I keep coming back to that great growth in trusts during the Labor government, and I certainly shall keep coming back to the fact that they had 13 years to bring in this crackdown, as they see it.

Who can forgetâthere seems to be a regular pattern in the way the Labor Party does itâthat about six weeks out from any federal election there is about another $1 billion to be found from very rich individuals. It becomes part of the mantra of the Labor Party to try to convince peopleâthat is, the whole population of Australiaâthat suddenly, in that last six weeks of an election campaign, you can find revenue that has been sitting out there for 13 years. Suddenly you can find the revenue, and you can attack those wealthy individuals. Suddenly that all fits into the context of an election campaign. Don't do much about it; don't talk much about it before that; don't talk much about it in the previous 13 years; but just when we are coming up to the election you remind us, you create the politics of envy and try to create some concept of political opportunism from this whole process.

I now come to the legislation as introduced into the House on 13 May 1999 by the minister. The effect of the legislation is simply to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and associated laws to ensure that the trustee of a `closely held trust' with a trustee beneficiary discloses to the Commissioner of Taxation the identity of the ultimate beneficiaries of certain net income and tax preferred amounts of the trust.

I turn to the background. The taxation of trusts is governed by the provisions of division 6 of part III of the Income Assessment Act 1936. Trust income is taxed to either the trustee or the beneficiary. Where the beneficiary is presently entitled to a share of the income of the trust estate, and provided that they are not under a legal disability or a non-resident at the end of the income year, the beneficiary is assessable on that share of the net incomeâfairly straightforward, I would have thought. Conversely, where they are under such a disability or are a non-resident, it is the trustee who is assessable on behalf of the beneficiary. Trustees are also assessable where no beneficiary is presently entitled to that part of the income.

As such, trustees are required to lodge a tax return each year in respect of every trust estate. In most circumstances, this return enables the tax commissioner to determine what taxable income has been earned by the trust and which beneficiaries have been entitled to the various elements of that income. In turn, the commissioner can then reconcile the relevant shares of the trust income that have been included in appropriate beneficiaries' returns and enable assessments to be issued to the trustee in respect of those components of net income for which no beneficiary has been assessed.

We now come to the new measures. As I have alluded to before, in August last year the Commonwealth announced a series of far-reaching taxation reforms entitled `A New Tax System'. Perhaps while I am dealing with that, I might just remind the House of what the government did take to the people. At this time, as we come up to a vote in the Senate on the `A New Tax System', what we said and what the people voted on at the election in October last year appears to have escaped many people's memories.

The key points were to introduce a GST which eliminates sales taxâI stress, eliminates sales taxâand a range of nine other indirect taxes. Of course, we know that that has changed with the subsequent agreement with the Democrats, but I think most Australians understand that change. It will change the Commonwealth-state financial relations by providing the states and territories with an independent revenue base. It will implement significant changes to individual marginal tax rates. It will implement a major rationalisation of family assistanceâvery, very important. It will replace the various existing taxation payment and reporting systems of company tax, provisional tax, PAYE, PPS and RPS by one quarterly tax payment system; I repeat that: by one quarterly tax payment system, pay as you go. It will introduce a new universal business number system. Through its implementation, we will move towards an entity taxation system which is directly towards the elimination of tax advantages between different business structures. Finally, it will simplify the imputation system and introduce refunds for excess franking credits.

As part of these reforms, the Commonwealth announced that it would take immediate action to deal with the evidence uncovered by the Australian Taxation Office, as I have said. While there are many legitimate reasons for trust structures to contain multiple trustsâand I notice the previous speaker, the member for Kingston, acknowledged that there are legitimate purposes for trust structures, and I fully endorse thatâit would appear that some taxpayers had constructed complex trust structures, including multiple trust arrangements, to deliberately mislead the Australian Taxation Office as to the true destination of distributions and the true level of tax liable.

With immediate effect, a special anti-avoidance rule was applied on the afternoon of 13 August last year to require the identification by trustees of discretionary and closely held fixed trusts of the ultimate beneficiaries entitled to trust distribution and their tax file numbers, as I indicated earlier. In short, this measure provides an administrative audit trail for the ATO to examine to ensure that all taxpayers are treated fairly and equitably, regardless of the trust structure they or their agents construct.

It is worth noting that, alongside this immediate action, the Commonwealth acknowledged back in August that the introduction of the proposed redesigned company tax arrangements from 2000-01 would involve structural changes that would address tax minimisation through trusts more generally. As a penalty mechanism, where a trustee of a closely held trust does not correctly identify the ultimate beneficiaries within the specified period, after the end of year, income tax at the top marginal rate, plus Medicare levy in the case of net income, will be imposed. It should be noted that, in the case of tax preferred amounts, this kind of failure produces offences under the Taxation Administration Act 1953. Where there are no ultimate beneficiaries of net income of the closely held trust, the measures specifically impose taxation of that part of the net income of the trust at the top marginal tax rate plus the Medicare levy.

As well as shutting down an apparent abuse of the tax laws, this measure will raise an additional $30 million in 1999-2000 and 2000-01. In turn, compliance costs associated with this reform will be minimised, thanks to the number of trusts that have been carved out of the measure and, in certain circumstances, the identification of lower level beneficiaries in chains of trusts should prove sufficient disclosure.

I think I have summed up in fairly short fashionâI do not intend to speak any longerâthe purpose of the A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999 , introduced by Minister Hockey earlier in the year. I support the bill.

talk.start.para: âLabor supports the A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999, this legislation on trusts, meagre as it is. But we also strongly support the amendment that has been moved by my colleague the member for Kingston that points to the lack of action by this government on tax avoidance and evasion using trusts. We believe that such lack of action is an indicator of the government's failure to provide proper and fair tax reforms. In addition, part (2) of the amendment deals with the government's and the Democrats' GST, which I will be speaking on.

speech.para: This legislation imposes an obligation on the trustees of closely held trusts to disclose the identity and tax file numbers of the ultimate beneficiaries of net income and tax preferred amounts; and, if the trustee fails to do so or there is no ultimate beneficiary, the legislation provides for taxation at a penalty rate or offences under the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

The number of trusts has grown dramatically in the last few years. In 1993-94 it was just over 330,000, but by 1996-97 it had grown to 427,000. The Australian Taxation Office attributes the growth of trusts in recent years to the increase in the number of taxpayers who are seeking to hold and organise their assets and businesses in private discretionary trusts. The annual growth of companies decreased from eight per cent in 1992-93 to six per cent in 1996-97, yet in the same period the growth rate for trusts increased from two per cent to almost 10 per cent in 1995-96 and tapered off just a little to seven per cent in 1996-97. The tax office has stated that the relative rate of growth of trusts and companies could reflect the differences in tax treatment of these entities.

I could relate to you my own personal experience. I set up with a partner a small business in Brisbane, and in the process of setting up that business I was encouraged very strongly to set up a unit trust and then a family trust. The purpose of the family trust would be so that I could avail myself of income splitting that ordinary wage and salary earners could not avail themselves of. I did not proceed with the advice that my colleagues had given me, at a cost estimated by them to be a minimum of $5,000 in the first year when the trust would be setting up, then $10,000 per year thereafter. So for a very small business those are the sorts of opportunities that are being presented by the government's failure to do anything substantial on trusts.

The Howard government has really been dragged kicking and screaming by the tax commissioner to plug a gaping hole in the income tax base from family trusts. As my colleague the member for Kingston has pointed out, this problem was identified several years agoâin fact, in late 1995. The member for Kingston has given a very good account of the saga of the coalition backsliding on trusts. An article in the Australian of 24 September 1997 headlined `Trusts safe from tax attack, PM tells troops' states:
Mr Howard's comments were believed to have appeased MPs who feared the Government was planning a major crackdown on trusts.
Of course they would fear that, because 20 out of 30 coalition frontbenchers do have trusts.

talk.start.para: âMaybe he did not expect to be reported.
âAbsolutely. The article goes on to say:

speech.para: While Mr Howard and Mr Costello are prepared to close down loopholes being exploited by the top end of town, trusts pose a dilemma for the Coalition.
The reason is that most people who use trusts are core Coalition constituentsâeither small businessmen and women or farmers.
A large number of Liberal and National Party MPs also use trusts themselves.

Just recently, the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia was quoted in the Australian as saying, `We will kill this in cabinet,' such is the lack of commitment by this government to dealing with tax avoidance through trusts. Now we find that the main legislation on family trusts and on trusts in general has been put off into the business tax review. Once again, the Democrats have capitulated on this. They should have insisted on this legislation coming forward. It was in the ANTS package and it should have come forward as part of the legislation that was going to the Senate before 30 June, but the Democrats crumbled under pressure. The Leader of the Democrats walked into those negotiations, picked up the cards from the table and had four aces. The Prime Minister, at the other side of the table, picked up the cards and had two sevens. He asked the Leader of the Democrats, `What have you got?' She said, `Four aces.' He said, `Bad luck, I've got two sevens, I win.'
The Democrats signed up to the GST that ACOSS described as `fundamentally unfair and unacceptable' and which should be rejected by the Senate. ACOSS also said:
The package will widen the gap between rich and poor, and the whole nation will suffer from greater division between the haves and have-nots.

What happened is that the Democrats got half of Senator Harradine's amendments. It was a case of: the amendment that Meg Lees rejects makes Harradine's amendment the best. But the best amendment to this legislation would be to apply the GST at the rate of zero; that is, to dump completely the goods and services tax.

This is not the only issue on which the Democrats have been duped by the government. A media release issued by the Leader of the Democrats claims that the tax mix switch is only $2.75 billion. ACOSS correctly identifies a $5 billion net increase in indirect taxes under the deal struck between the Democrats and the government, but to that we must add the reduction in income tax of more than $10 billion. In other words, we have a switch in the tax mix towards regressive indirect taxes of more than $15 billion a year, not $2.75 billion as claimed by the Democrats.

If the GST is such a good tax, why do the Democrats persist in misleading the Australian people about it? A document that has been obtained from the A Current Affair online chat room outlines advice that the Democrats gave to people who logged into the chat room on 1 June 1999. I would like to take the House through a few of the completely false or misleading claims that were made by the Democrats in response to queries that were raised.

Firstly, the Democrats indicated in the chat room that `around 80 per cent of a low income household's food purchasesâwould be GST free.' Wrong! The household expenditure survey reveals that about a third of low income household food purchases would in fact attract the GST. In the next statement made in the chat room, the Democrats say, `If there's any doubt, it is GST free.' What we have here is the Leader of the Democrats becoming the tax commissioner, the Leader of the Democrats going around Australia over the next few years declaring, `If there is any doubt, it will be GST free.' Talk about fairies at the bottom of the garden path! The next thing we hear from the Democrats is that:
We kept 80 per cent of food groceries GST free and taxed only those things consumed more by wealthy households.

The household expenditure survey reveals that more than five per cent of the spending of the lowest 20 per cent of income earners is on bakery items whereas the top 20 per cent spend only about 4.2 per cent on such items. As a proportion of income, the gap between those two would be even greater. The next question asked was this:
When I buy foods with the GST, is the GST "built-in" to the price, or the GST added at the cash register?
The Democrats say:
It's one-eleventh of the final price, built in, as happens in most countries.
Yet we find this statement in the Canberra Times on 31 March:

The Democrats said last night the Government should insist on retailers displaying before-and-after prices, for three months before and three months after the new tax comes into force on July 1 next year.

That is another glaring inconsistency. I do not believe they know what they are saying. The Treasurer complains about the wholesale sales tax being a hidden tax, but he says, `Well, the GST will be embedded in the price.' How will consumers know if they have been falsely charged GST on some foods? The next example is a caller who asked:
Why can't you put a GST on non-Australian foods and leave the Aussie foods tax free! Won't that help Australia get back on its feet?
The Democrats say:
That's effectively what we've done.
That is completely untrue. They say:
All fresh produce will be GST free but junk food, much of which is imported, will be taxed.

I ask, rhetorically, are these things junk food: Lean Cuisine, chicken pieces, everything in the bakery outside Meg's bread recipe, freshly squeezed orange juice in a cafe and fruit salad? The Democrats are trying to be the nation's nutritionists. They have a particular view about the role of women in the homeâthat is, that women should not take home takeaway food or any prepared food; they should stay at home and cook it. That view happens to coincide with the view of the Prime Minister, a very long-held view it is too. The next caller says:
I am a mum of a disabled daughter and I know for a fact the GST will hurt us financially.
The Democrat response:
Food will be GST free . . .
Now all food is going to be GST free. The Democrats will say anything about this tax. The Democrats go on to say:
We have picked up international best practice . . .
This fiasco is seen by the Democrats as international best practice. Another caller, Steve, asks:
I work in a school where purchases are currently exempt from sales tax. Will GST apply?
The Democrats respond:
Education is GST free, and schools will be able to claim even more sales tax exemptions than they can now. For eg: on books, electricity, plumbing services etc.

The first point is that they say education is GST free. What about school uniforms? What about shoes? What about stationery? What about school cases and bus and train fares? All of those bear the GST and the Democrats deliberately misled this person on that point. The second point is that they say that schools will be able to claim even more sales tax exemptions than they can now. The Democrats are giving tax cuts to schools by imposing new taxes and saying that schools do not have to pay them. This is like Nero: we are going to build a new city by burning down Rome first. The final point relates to books, electricity, plumbing services, et cetera. This is highly misleading because there is no tax on these items at present. Mushie logged in and asked:
What's happening with fuel, alcohol and tobacco?
The Democrats said:
The GST will be imposed and the relevant excise reduced by 10 percent.
Wrong! That is wrong for tobacco. The excise will not be reduced by 10 per cent. That is why tobacco prices will go up so much. Why do the Democrats continue to mislead on this? Another question:
How do you think voting for the GST will affect your party's standing in the next election?
The Democrat response:
I believe that the voters will be pleased that the Democrats said there will not be a GST on food, and that we delivered that.
I rest my case. They are still saying to those people who log into this program, and to other people, that there is no GST on food. When will they tell the truth? Another question:
Will rents paid by business be subject to a GST and if so how will they be compensated for a 10 percent rise on one of their largest expenses?
The Democrat response:
Rents will be input taxed, ie no GST will be charged, but no credits given on any GST paid by landlord.

That is not true of rents on business premises. That is yet another deliberate misleading of the people. The Commissioner of Taxation effectively commented on the Howard-Democrat deal in a speech delivered in Hobart on 24 March 1999, just a few weeks ago. He said:
In the UK and Canada exemptions have been introduced for food products that may be generally described as "basic groceries" or "essential foods".
Giving effect to these concepts is difficult and requires administrative or legislative rules that are ripe for ridicule.

And how right the tax commissioner was. These rules are ripe for ridicule. Just last week, on 3 June, the Premier of Victoria gave an interview with Neil Mitchell on 3AW. I will pick just two of the points he made, and he is absolutely right about them. He said:
Because of the debate going on about items in, items out, the public's confidence in the package as a whole is being substantially eroded to the point that the package is losing credibility.
He is right about that. The Newspoll in the Australian today reveals a 19 per cent turnaround in just a couple of weeks of those opposed to the GST. The Premier went on to say:

Secondly, because the Democrats have insisted that certain foods be out, there are going to be many small retailers, milk bars, seven-eleven stores, places like family run supermarkets in country Victoria, country Australia, a whole range of stores that are simply not going to be able to comply by July the first next year.

Then he questions whether they can comply at all. But we have the solution to that. The Democrats have got the answer to that. In the Australian Financial Review on 31 May 1999 the Democrats are reported in the following terms:

The Government will consider a series of options from the Democrats to minimise compliance costs, such as one that allows small outlets to "opt out" of the exemption voluntarily. That is, a store which sold mainly taxable food, such as a takeaway, might be allowed to charge the GST on tax-free items to minimise compliance costs.

These people truly are the pixies at the bottom of the garden. They are saying that small businesses can apply the GST to goods that they sell which do not bear the GST and this will reduce their administrative burden. They then remit the GST, illegally applied, to the Taxation Office, which is supposed to say, `Thank you very much.' Then these people say, `Isn't this great! We've minimised compliance costs.'

This is astonishing stuff. We have an appalling deal between the Democrats and the government that is going to be very unfair for Australia, as pointed out by ACOSS. It is going to create a compliance nightmare for small business, and it is completely unnecessary. There is no need for this GST. The growth in revenue under the existing tax system has been very robust indeed. In fact in this year coming revenue as a proportion of GDP is projected to be the largest for around 12 years. So we are being told that the system is broke and it has to be changed, that we must have a new efficient GST. It is now a GST that is full of exemptions, riddled with holes, a ridiculous GST that is going to cause a compliance nightmare.

What are we seeing in relation to the great efficiency benefits that are claimed in relation to the abolition of nine state taxes, the nine state taxes that everyone received material on in the election campaign which said, `We are going to get rid of nine state taxes'? At best, they are going to get rid of four state taxes. Five state taxes have been identified as being particularly inefficient taxes. But the Treasurer said today, `No. We are getting rid of them all.' One of those five taxes will be removed from 1 July 2005, but there is no date set for the removal of the other four at all.

Moreover, there is no mechanism to remove these taxes because there is no new agreement and no premiers conference to forge a new agreement for the abolition of these taxes. All it is is a line of writing in a press release prepared by the Leader of the Democrats and the Prime Minister. It has absolutely no force. So the efficiency gains from this tax change simply are not there. We are taking the country backwards. We are taking the country backwards in terms of loss of jobs from the imposition of the GST, particularly in the labour intensive service industries. There is absolutely no benefit in terms of economic growth. Treasury has been able to demonstrate no benefit whatsoever. Independent economic modellers have been able to demonstrate no benefit whatsoever. We have an absolute disaster in the making. There is time, however, for the Leader of the Democrats and the Australian Democrats to change their position before 30 June, admit they have made a mistake and repudiate this ridiculous tax.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to join with my colleagues the member for Kingston and the member for Rankin in discussing A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999 and associated legislation. It is, as others have remarked, an anti-avoidance measure aimed at curbing the abuse of trusts. The particular abuse arises where chains of trusts are used to disguise who the ultimate beneficiary of the trust income is. There is difficulty in ensuring that the original trust income, which is supposed to have flowed through that chain of trusts, has been accounted for by the ultimate beneficiary and that the net assets of the ultimate beneficiary actually reflect the receipt of that income.

speech.para: This legislation proposes that the trustee of what is called a closely held trust with a trustee as a beneficiary must disclose to the Commissioner of Taxation who the ultimate beneficiary of trust income and the capital distributions is within a specified period. It defines closely held trusts as those which are either discretionary trusts or where up to 20 individuals have fixed entitlements to a 75 per cent or greater share of the income or capital of the trust. There are certain trusts which are excluded from this regime: namely, the superannuation funds and other superannuation entities; deceased estates until five years after the date of death; fixed trusts which are wholly owned by tax exempt persons, for example, charities; and unit trusts listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. If the ultimate beneficiaries are not disclosed, then the income to be distributed through the trust beneficiary is to be taxed at the maximum marginal rate plus the Medicare levy, that is, 48Â½ per cent.

The legislation provides an exemption for situations where the trust is a deceased estate for five years after death. It is appropriate for a reasonable period to apply to deceased estates. I suppose the question is whether five years is too long. We would be interested to hear the government's response on this point and why it believes five years is the appropriate length of time.

Let me turn now to the issue of taxing trusts as companies. This legislation is expected to raise $30 million each year for 1998-99âit commenced on 13 August last yearâand 1999-2000. Thereafter the so-called entity tax regime is due to commence. Page 26 of the explanatory memorandum states:

After these periods, the effect of the measure is likely to be absorbed by the entities' taxation proposal announced in Tax Reform: not a new tax, a new tax system: the Howard Government's Plan for a New Tax System , if it is implemented as announced from 2000-2001.

The point here is that we have an explanatory memorandum suggesting that the entity tax regime may not actually appear. Indeed it is a matter of the gravest concern to the opposition that for all the bills we have seen introducing the government's GST, all the bills that have been part of what is referred to as the ANTS package, a new tax system package, we have not seen the legislation to implement the entities' taxation proposal. Maybe the drafters of the explanatory memorandum who cast doubt on whether the government intends to deliver on its undertaking to tax trusts as companies had had the benefit of reading or at least were aware of reports recently written about the National Party's commitment to this proposal.

Let me draw the attention of the House, as I think other speakers have also done, to the report by Glenn Milne in the Australian on Monday, 24 May. He said that the federal management committee of the National Party's Queensland branch had organised for Mr John Hoare to address the federal National Party room. In addition to expressing concern about the Ralph committee's proposals to scrap tax breaks for accelerated depreciation, Mr Hoare objected to the proposal to crack down on discretionary family trusts. Mr Hoare is reported by Glenn Milne as saying:
For a lot of people in the room there was disbelief. They just didn't understand the impact of the Ralph committee on trusts.

According to Mr Hoare, the Deputy Prime Minister declared in the National Party room, `We'll kill this in cabinet.' This is just extraordinary, because this is not a proposal which in some fashion is up for consideration; this is something which the government announced as part of their tax package, and they put a price tag on it of the order of $760 million in the first year and down to $430 million over the course of a three-year period. If the government were to abandon this idea of taxing trusts as companies and abandon the entity tax proposal, we would have a black hole of the order of $1.5 billion. This is a done deal and what we are waiting for in the opposition is for the government to introduce that part of their legislation as they have introduced so many other pieces of legislation.

The Queensland National Party expressed concern about the proposal that family trusts would be taxed as companies. This means there would be a 47c tax rate on the distribution of capital to a beneficiary on the rental value of a house owned by a trust and lived in rent free by a beneficiary, and the beneficiaries of the discretionary trusts are family members. Milne reports that:

Hoare pointed out to National Party MPs that trusts were a favoured financial management vehicle among farmers. But the primary purpose of such trusts is for asset protectionâin other words, ensuring the family property is not broken up.

Those other purposes to which trusts may be put are all well and good. As speakers on the government side have mentioned, there are legitimate uses for trusts, but that does not mean they should not be taxed in the same way that companies and other entities areânot for a moment.

A further media report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 7 June said that the Ralph review was examining a government proposal to tax trusts carrying on a business as companies. That would mean that income would be taxed at the company rate and beneficiaries would then get franking credits. The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, was again quoted as saying that he would not support any crackdown on trusts that amounted to a de facto reintroduction of death duties.

The point I make again is that this is not something which is open for ongoing debate. It is something which the government announced as part of its new tax package. At the time the new tax package was announced, we learned there was something like $13 billion in tax cuts, and 52 per cent of those tax cutsâtotalling some $6.6 billionâwere going to the top 20 per cent of income earners in this country, leaving the rest of the tax cuts for the remaining 80 per cent of Australians. When we in the opposition pointed out the unfair nature of this tax package, one of the government's responses was to say, `No, it's all right because we're hitting the high wealth individuals by taxing trusts as companies. We're hitting them with entity taxation.'

This is not something on which the government has any wriggle room whatsoever. It is something which the government is obligated to introduce. For the government to come into this parliament with a piece of legislation which it says will yield $30 million in revenue, when it has previously said it will get $760 million in revenue through the entity taxation proposal, is simply not good enough. It is a case of the dog that did not barkâthat is, where is the tax legislation necessary to give effect to the government's commitments? On that basis, I strongly support the amendment which has been moved by the member for Kingston.

I want to express some concern about where the non-appearance of this legislation leaves the area of tax avoidance generally. I think it does call into question this government's sincerity in opposing tax avoidance and acting to crack down on tax avoidance. The member for Kingston gave us something of the history of the issue of high wealth individuals and the advice that the previous government received back in 1995 and early 1996 about action that was needed to crack down on high wealth individuals. Indeed, when we announced as a government that we were going to take that action, the then opposition indicated it would support that and obtain that revenue as well. But in these past few years it has failed to obtain that revenue.

In the meantime, we are becoming increasingly aware of the development of a crisis within the Australian Taxation Office concerning some of the tax avoidance schemes. I want to draw the attention of the House to a report in the Business Review Weekly on 4 June by Mr Michael Laurence. It states:

Behind an image of calm efficiency, the Australian Taxation Office is deeply troubled. Commissioner Michael Carmody is making a desperate effort to manage a crisis of his office's own making. For years, his most senior officers have been quietly endorsing aggressive schemes that make the payment of tax optional.

In particular, this article goes on to describe the resignation of a former first assistant commissioner, Mr Nick Petroulias, and conflict concerning a particular scheme known as controlling shareholder superannuation where the controlling shareholders of private companies make contributions to non-complying fundsâthat is, outside the control of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Actâand claim deductions for those contributions and also claim that they are not subject to fringe benefits tax, not subject to superannuation contributions tax and not subject to the tax surcharge on contributions.

This issue has become one of major conflict within the Australian Taxation Office. What we learn from this Business Review Weekly article is the fact that the development of this scheme has made it optional for a number of clients of the advisers who have been promot ing the scheme to pay tax. Indeed, we read that:

Tax advisers were expecting to claim up to $1.5 billion in deductions in the 1998-99 financial year for controller super alone. Recently, a sole investor was detected by the tax office's employee-benefit taskforce based in Moonee Ponds, Victoria, preparing to claim a $10 million deduction. In the past five years, billions of dollars have flowed through arrangements that, to use the commissioner's expression, claim a "total tax wipeout".
That same article quotes Sydney tax consultant Robert Richards as saying:

The Government and the tax office is negligent in not rushing through amending legislation. The tax office is not prepared to admit a mistake and still thinks the law can be applied to stop the schemes.
The article also quotes the former tax ombudsman, Mr Peter Haggstrom, to the effect that:

By effectively endorsing controlling shareholder superannuation schemes for years, the tax office created a dual tax system where it was optional to pay tax. It hounds small business people over relatively few dollars yet has allowed tax advisers to go for gold. The schemes make a joke of tax reform when a straightforward change in the law would have considerably helped revenue collection. To continually give favorable rulings and opinions for schemes that exploit a legal loophole is ludicrous.

As the article says, all of this raises some pretty crucial questions. Is the tax office capable of fighting aggressive tax schemes when it has proved so wanting in the past? Did the commissioner know that his most senior officers had long been approving schemes that skirt around the tax system? What role did aggressive tax planners have in Mr Petroulias's departure?

We learn here of a very sorry system and scheme existing within the tax office. I am certainly concerned that, as a result of this government's lack of interest in cracking down on tax avoidance, that culture is going through to the tax office as well with the result that paying tax has become optional for far too many high wealth Australians. Peter Haggstrom was further quoted as saying:

I believe the tax office's cynical policy towards aggressive tax planning says something quite fundamental about its relationship with government . . . Hardened players in the tax industry well understand this dynamic, and they stretch the rubber band as far as it will go.

We see here a very sorry state of affairs unfolding. Further to that, I note that the recent report of the CPSU on things occurring within the tax office points out that the overall staffing picture for the tax office is far from satisfactory. There are many new staff planned to come on stream in the event that the GST gets up. The tax office is to employ 3,800 new staff in GST positions, and 600 sales tax staff are gradually being picked up in GST and other work. For a scheme that is promoted as simplifying Australia's tax arrangements, it is very interesting to learn that all these new staff are going to be there to enforce the GST.

The overall staffing arrangement is one that sees no more than 1,000 between 1998-99 and 2002-03. Although the tax office is being somewhat secretive about its plans, we in fact are going to see 2Â½ thousand staff cut from current functions over the next three years. The impact of that will be that some 1,000 staff will be cut from the small business area. So the picture in the future is going to be one of increased reliance on the indirect regressive taxes and the automatic tax with little attention being paid either to individual service to small business or to pursuing tax evasion.

Indeed, we are already seeing the situation where taxpayers are not able to make payments in person at tax offices but are forced to make payments at post offices, and the tax office has already announced plans to severely restrict its in-house inquiry service. So there are accounts of taxpayers travelling a long distance to a tax office only to be referred to a phone in the foyer of the tax office and told to call the tax office. That is most unsatisfactory and it does call into question just how well things are going within the tax office.

I also noted that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration had expressed concern that the tax office had inefficiencies in its revenue collection system leading to estimated annual losses of almost $500 million. Those things were identified in a recently released Auditor-General's report. These things are cause for considerable concern.

I am pleased to support the amendment which has been moved by the member for Kingston. He identified the fact that, in 1995, the tax office reported that multiple trust structures were being used by high wealth individuals. The extent of the loss to revenue was of the order of $800 million. We had a situation where people who had over $30 million in assets were declaring incomes of $20,000 or less. That situation is absolutely shameful. This government has taken no effective action to crack down on that avoidance by high wealth individuals. It said it was going to introduce entity taxation and to tax trusts as companies. So far it is yet to do it.

This legislation will yield a fraction of the money which the government has said will be yielded through entity taxation. It is simply not good enough, and I call on members of the House to support the amendment moved by the member for Kingston and put some pressure on this government to become fair dinkum about tax avoidance.

talk.start.para: âAt the outset, I would like to thank the honourable members for Melbourne, Cook, Rankin, Kingston, Grey and Wills for their contributions to this debate. The member for Wills, of course, will not be at all surprised to hear that the government does indeed reject the amendment moved by the member for Kingston. The government is very pleased, however, that all members of this House do in fact support these measures which are an important part of the government's tax reform package for which it obtained a mandate at the election held in October last year. This has been a wide ranging debate. The particular items included in the three cognate bills have been canvassed, but certain of the participants have also talked about other aspects of A New Tax System. As the government has made out quite clearly, it is absolutely committed to curbing abuses of trusts which are contrived or designed for the purposes of avoiding tax.

speech.para: The government has been criticised by some who suggest that the bills are draconian. Solicitor Richard Roberts says in the Financial Review of 26 May that `this bill treats users of discretionary trusts as tax cheats'. So the government, on the one hand, is criticised by the opposition for not going far enough; on the other hand, the government is blamed for going too far. So it is pretty clear that the government has got the balance right.

As is well known, the Taxation Office has evidence that certain taxpayers are using complex chains of trusts to minimise tax. The A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999 and the two associated bills address this problem by enabling the tracing of ultimate beneficiaries through complex chains of trusts. These measures will apply regardless of the number of trusts through which the distributions may pass. In effect, these measures will provide an administrative audit trail, helping to establish tax liabilities in circumstances where complex chains of trusts are used to minimise tax. At their heart, these are anti-avoidance measures. They are anticipated to raise $30 million in each of the 1999-2000 and 2000-01 financial years. As has been pointed out by the honourable member for Grey, Mr Wakelin, the number of trusts lodging returns in Australia has grown in recent yearsâfrom 331,338 in 1993-94 to 427,431 in 1996-97. Therefore, it is appropriate that the tax treatment of these vehicles is considered carefully to ensure that equity is retained.

The member for Wills suggested that in 1995 it was suggested that something needed to be done about the area of trusts. It ought to be recognised that in 1995 the Labor Party was in office and it did absolutely nothing following that information coming to light. We ought not to lose sight of the very obvious fact that for 13 years, from 1983 to 1996, the Labor Party was the government of this country. So it is all very well for Labor members to come into the chamber and to huff and puff and accuse this government of inactivity. The reality is that this government has done more than any other government about doing away with abuses of trusts and closing loopholes, and we are not, in any way, shape or form, apologising for what we have done.

Honourable members would be aware that the government did reintroduce trust loss provisions, it brought in measures to combat sales tax fraud in the computer industry, and it brought in various other tax avoidance provisions and provisions which define the tax laws to make sure they apply as intendedâfor example, franking credit trading, dividend and capital streaming and dividend substitution. In addition, everyone in Australia knows that the change in tax mix which will follow the implementation of our new tax system as we approach the next millennium will indeed reduce opportunities for tax evasion. These are real, meaningful tax reforms. They reduce reliance on income tax and change the collection system and the way trusts are taxed.

The amendment moved by the honourable member for Kingston claims that the new tax system will hurt Australian families. The Prime Minister has said, and this government has made it amply clearâand it is widely recognised in the Australian communityâthat, far from hurting families, it has a very strong bias towards the Australian family. It brought in the family tax initiative and many other meaningful and real reforms which benefit the Australian family. The amendments to the new tax system which were negotiated with the Australian Democrats will also benefit families. So people will reject the arguments of the Labor Party. They have no tax policy. As we approached the last election, they were rejected yet again by the Australian people, and yet they seek to come into the chamber and thwart the attempt by this government to implement its promises and the mandate given to it by the Australian people.

The current measures are meant to counter practices where entitlements pass through a series of trusts. For instance, part or all of the net income of a trust may be passed through a series of trusts, with no ultimate beneficiary being assessed on that net incomeâeither because there is no ultimate beneficiary or because the ultimate beneficiary cannot be identified. Other assets of a trust may be said to be distributed through a series of trusts, yet the assets may never be reflected in the assets of any ultimate beneficiary. Or there may be taxpayers whose assets reflect trust distributions which cannot be traced back through the succession of trusts to which they are ascribed. Broadly speaking, these bills require trustees of closely held trusts with trustee beneficiaries to disclose to the Commissioner of Taxation the identity of ultimate beneficiaries of trust net income and trust preferred amounts to which another trust is entitled.

To reduce compliance costs, a number of closely held trusts, such as complying superannuation funds and deceased estates, have been excluded from the measure. The honourable member for Wills asked me why the government selected the period of five years with respect to deceased estates. I am very happy to advise the member for Wills, and indeed the chamber, that the reason five years has been selected is that this period is consistent with other provisions in the tax laws, including the trust loss provisions.

Under the legislation, a trustee need trace an entitlement to net income no further than any of a range of listed persons, including exempt bodies, charitable trusts and widely held trusts, and this also reduces compliance costs. For those people who suggest that there will be excessive compliance costs, it ought to be seen that the government has very carefully drafted this legislation to minimise any concern in relation to this area. I believe that the government has the balance right in relation to this particular area.
In his speech, the honourable member for Melbourne said:
Labor has no problem in supporting this legislation. It improves the equity of the tax system and makes those with the capacity to pay, pay more of their share.

They are the words of endorsement from the honourable member for Melbourne. The member for Melbourne ought to be commended for that very supportive statement of the laudable motives of the government, as encapsulated in the three bills which we are now debating. It is, however, an ongoing tragedy that the Labor Party refuses to approach overall tax reform in the same objective manner. Instead, it refuses to look to the national interest and continues to oppose tax reform.

The honourable member for Cook, as always, made a very thought provoking contribution. He stressed the reasons why the government sees these three bills as being necessary. He also emphasised how the government has a genuine commitment to real tax reform. The honourable member for Grey mentioned the growth in trusts, and I referred to that a moment ago. He summarised the provisions of the bill and he provided an overview of the government's overall tax reform strategy. He stressed that the compliance costsâas I have just saidâwill indeed be minimised.

The honourable member for Rankin spoke about problems which were identified in 1995 in relation to the taxation of trusts. I have just alluded to the fact that those problems were identified during the 13 years of Labor government when nothing was done. He also claimed that there were inconsistencies in the tax package as amended. The reason we would have any inconsistencies, if they were to exist, is that the Labor Party failed to support the mandate given to the government by the Australian people in October last year.

We see our original tax package as being fair, and we see the amended tax plan, agreed with Senator Lees and the Australian Democrats, as being fair. We are proud of the fact that we have been able to sit down with Senator Meg Lees and the Australian Democrats and been able to compromise and bring forward real and meaningful tax reform.
Mr Martin Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt is very interesting to listen to those opposite who are supporting a continuation of an appalling situation where we have a hidden wholesale sales tax which is charged at six irrational and varying rates. The government's proposal for tax reform is comprehensive. We intend to abolish Labor's inefficient and outdated wholesale sales tax, and we are not going to apologise for doing so. I simply do not know why the Labor Party is so devoted to such a troglodyte attitude to tax reform. We are proud to be replacing Labor's wholesale sales tax with a much fairer, broad based and single low rate GST.

speech.para: Mrs Bronwyn Bishop interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI thank the Minister for Aged Care for her supportive interjection. States and territories will receive all GST revenue. Our tax plan delivers over $10 billion of tax cuts. This means that 80 per cent of Australian taxpayers will be on a top marginal rate of no more than 30 cents in the dollar. We have increased assistance to families, pensioners and independent retirees. There will be lower diesel fuel costs for businesses and also for rural Australia.

speech.para: We are very supportive of the environment. Indeed, it ought to be recognised that this is the greenest government Australia has ever seen. The Natural Heritage Trust, funded by the partial sale of Telstra, has ensured that the situation of Australia's environment, which we hand on to future generationsâ
Mr Martin Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt will be infinitely better, my friend, than what the Labor Party failed to achieve in its 13 years of office. As part of the tax package, we are spending $1,000 million on initiatives to improve the environment, such as urban air quality, greenhouse gas emissions and so on. We are building on the wonderful record that we already have.

speech.para: There was also some comment made in the debate in relation to the provisions on page 26 of the explanatory memorandum under `Government Revenue'. Under 1.102, it says:

This measure was estimated to raise revenue of $30 million in each of 1999-2000 and 2000-2001. After these periods the effect of the measure is likely to be absorbed by the entities' taxation proposal announced in Tax Reform: not a new tax, a new tax system: The Howard Government's Plan for a New Tax System , if it is implemented as announced from 2000-2001.

These bills before the chamber are only part of our tax plan. We cannot presume that all bills will get through the parliament, although we are confidentâfollowing the agreement with the Australian Democratsâthat, unlike the Labor Party, we will be able to deliver on the mandate given to us by the Australian people. This government is committed to keeping its promises.

We do remember that when the Labor Party were in officeâand I suspect that you yourself, Madam Deputy Speaker, rememberâ they were prepared to do anything. Prior to elections, they were prepared to promise anything. They said they would not sell the Commonwealth Bank. I think they said they would not sell Qantas.
Mrs Bronwyn Bishop interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAnd what did they do? They sold them both. So the Labor Party are prepared to do anything. They come into the chamber prepared to promise anything prior to a poll with a view to getting elected, and when they get onto the government benches they simply tear up the promises that they have made.

speech.para: This government is determined to keep its promises. This government was given a mandate by the Australian people, and this government is very pleased to support the new tax system which we are bringing in as we approach the next millennium.

Returning to the provisions of the bill, it ought to be seen that the commissioner will need the information from trustees to check that a beneficiary includes his or her share of the net income of a trust in his or her assessable income for the year and to make sure that the right beneficiary's net assets include any other tax preferred amounts from the trust. When a trustee does not get the necessary information in relation to net income of the trust, the bills will impose a tax on the trustee in relation to that part of the net income at the top marginal tax rate plus the Medicare levy. This is so regardless of whether the trustee refuses to give the information, cannot give the information or gives incorrect information. The bills will also impose a tax on a share of the net income for which there is no ultimate beneficiary, again at the top marginal rate plus Medicare. If the trustee does not give the required information about a tax preferred amount, the trustee of a closely held trust may be guilty of an offence under the Taxation Administration Act 1953 if the trustee did not give the information that he or she knew or did not take reasonable steps to find out any information that he or she did not know.

This has been a wide-ranging debate. The contributions made by government members have stressed the importance of A New Tax System. The contributions made by those opposite have, as always, been shallow. I am very pleased to commend these three bills to the chamber. The government rejects the amendment moved by the honourable member for Kingston.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Cox's amendment) stand part of the question.
