subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 June, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThese three billsâthe Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1999 , the Customs Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill 1999 and the Excise Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill 1999 âform a package which gives effect to the announcement in the budget of an increase in excise and customs duty on aviation gasoline, known as avgas, and aviation kerosene, known as avtur, from 11 May 1999. There will be an additional duty of 0.467c per litre for avgas and 0.391c per litre on avturâraising $8.6 million a year. That will be appropriated to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to address what the government refers to as a `shortfall in the aviation industry's contribution to CASA's aviation safety programs'. A `temporary surcharge'âthat is what it is calledâof a further 0.5lc per litre on all aircraft fuels will raise $11.1 million a year. That will offset the Airservices (Location Specific Pricing) Subsidy. This surcharge is limited to two years and will be reviewed within that period. The government claims this surcharge is necessary following the Senate's disallowance of regulations permitting the contracting out of air traffic control services.

speech.para: The bill also repeals requirements for mandatory consultation with the boards of CASA and Airservices Australia in setting the `statutory rate' of duty and on determining the respective shares of revenue between CASA and Airservices Australia. The opposition is not opposing these bills, although I note that there is opposition from some sections of the aviation industry who, perhaps understandably, are angry with the coalition for backing off from its previous position that funding CASA and Airservices through fuel duties or levies was not something it supported. That is what it has said in the past. I note that the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, for example, claims that this move:
. . . breaks all promises made by the current government to the industry about the way air services and regulation is to be paid for.

It is certainly something the former minister, Mark Vaile, was loudly carrying on about last year. He claimed to be moving towards what he called `an equitable charging system'. He said he wanted a user-pays, fee-for-service approach. This is the sort of approach, as we have seen in many other areas, that can look great in theory but tends to go off the rails in practice.

It comes down in the end to whether you think aviation safety and the services that ensure aviation safety should be treated in the same way as buying a car or getting a haircutâas some kind of expendable commodityârather than as a service with a public or community value that extends beyond the purely commercial. This is a very distinct philosophical difference. This government believes that if you treat aviation safety like any other service then it is appropriate to charge on a user-pays basis, and it is happy to let those services which are not affordable or which are not used by many people or, for example, that are in remote areas fall by the wayside when they do not turn a profit. But if you consider, as Labor does, that aviation safety has wider public implications then you are more inclined to look for funding options which ensure that services are fairly distributed, that the price, quality and accessibility of the service are kept at a reasonable level in rural and regional areas, and that public safety or some other important community goal is not compromised.

This is the nub of the problem facing the coalition in the area of aviation safety. On the one hand, their ideology drives them towards a user-pays, fee-for-service approach to just about everything. On the other hand, it is becoming very apparent that applying such an approach to air safety is not a very bright idea. And we can see that it is not turning out to be such a great idea, because less than one year after the government headed off down the path of their so-called `more equitable charging system' they are back here in the budget debate telling us, `Sorry, we've now got a shortfall to make up. We have to put the aviation fuel duties back up.'

I should also make the point here that there were sections of the aviation industry that opposed the removal of the so-called avgas levy and that some of the observations they made at the time the levy was scrapped now look very prescient indeed. They spoke of their belief that the government had failed to properly explore the cost consequences of its decision. They warned that some level of cross-subsidisation was essential for general aviation and regional airports to survive. They expressed doubts about the capacity of the government to deliver quality safety regulation without the levy, and they argued that, if the government insisted on sticking to this course of action, it would eventually have to find funding from some other source to maintain access to services at a reasonable price. The introduction of these bills makes it quite apparent that the implications were not fully explored.

Turning first to CASA, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services tells us CASA has been running a deficit since 1996-97. It is interesting that, while the minister says there has been an industry shortfall in contributions, the Director of CASA, Mr Mick Toller, told the Senate estimates hearings last week that the shortfall came from the government's reduction of the CASA contribution from fuel excise by 30 per cent. He described it as an `overcorrection'. Whatever it is, CASA expects to be around $8 million short this year.

There have been mutterings within the industry that the shortfall has not been helped by very large expenditures by CASA in the past year on consultants. I know that some in the aviation industry who are otherwise happy to contribute to CASA's safety programs through fuel duties or levies are not so pleased to think they are contributing to activities that may ultimately have very little to do with improving safety. In Senate estimates last week, answering questions from Senator Kerry O'Brien, Mr Toller revealed that CASA had spent $1.98 million on consultancies this financial year to the end of April. That is a significant amount of money to be spending when you face a known funding shortfall. The industry would have every right to be annoyed if, having been told it has to pay for the restructure of CASA through this particular increase in fuel duty, this amount of money continued to be spent on external consultancies.

I think we will all be entitled to feel angry if the restructure does not in fact deliver improved safety outcomes, because this is a restructure that is going to cost $18 million. Redundancies make up $12 million of that. CASA loses 10 per cent of its work force with this restructure. The opposition is a long way from being satisfied that such a loss is not just further cost cutting for its own sake. We are not convinced that it will actually lead to better safety outcomes. So this is something we will continue to monitor.

When it comes to the so-called `temporary surcharge', there are also real questions over what exactly the government has achievedâor what the government hopes to achieveâ through its shift to location specific pricing and its plan to privatise air traffic control towers. Very early on, after the abolition of the levy, it became apparent that Airservices Australia needed some financial assistance from the government to subsidise general aviation and regional towers. This is, of course, another exercise in the shift in language to try and convince us that air safety is a business and not a public obligation. That is why it is called a `subsidy' and not a `community service obligation', as we used to call it. It is a bit cute actually for the government to be arguing that the surcharge is necessary because of the Senate's failure to pass regulations enabling the privatisationâor, to use the government's euphemism, the `contracting out'âof air traffic control towers. It is hard to believe that the government is seriously suggesting that, even if the Senate had passed the regulations, the subsidy would not have been needed for a further period. For a start, Mr Mick Toller told the Senate estimates hearing that he did not believe CASA could develop the necessary safety regulatory frameworks for air traffic control and airport firefighting services before June 2000. That in itself suggests a considerable delay, irrespective of the Senate's actions or the Senate's vote.

The fact that the government is moving in these bills to extend the current subsidy to general aviation and regional airports is not about the government's plans being thwarted by the Senate; it is really about the long-term implications of those plans and the ill thought out consequences and the problems the government is having in getting to the point where it can set up alternative air traffic control providers that can offer cheaper service while remaining a safe service. That is the crux of the problemâtrying to fit the ideology, as usual, to the reality and sprinkling it with euphemisms all the way. As I have said before in this chamber, Labor holds a different view. We believe air traffic control services should remain a public operation and a responsibility of governmentâmotivated, first and foremost, by the need to protect public safety, not the need to make a profit.

There has been a lot of upheaval, a lot of anxiety and a lot of confusion caused by the government's agenda in this area. Despite that, we do not intend to oppose this legislation. We think that the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee will engage in a very thorough examination of the issue of location specific pricing and the current state of aviation safety, so we do not need to take the time of other committees of the parliament to duplicate this. But we do intend to continue to oppose an agenda that is motivated more by the need to cut costs than by the need to ensure safety, and we do intend to continue to oppose the pointless and potentially dangerous exercise of privatising airport firefighting services and air traffic control towers.

talk.start.para: âThe Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1999 , the Customs Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill 1999 and the Excise Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill 1999 are fairly straightforward. They were introduced into the House on 2 June 1999. This legislation amends the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act 1988 to effect the announcement made in the 1999-2000 federal budget of a small increase in excise and customs duty on aviation gasolineâthat is, avgasâand aviation kerosene, avtur. Additional duty raised will address the shortfall in industry's contribution to aviation safety programs and will help maintain air traffic control services at regional and general aviation airports.

speech.para: The package of three bills will give effect to the government's decision in different ways. Customs and excise charges are implemented through the Customs Tariff Act 1995 and the Excise Tariff Act 1921. These charges will be amended through the Customs Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill. Funds raised through these levies are appropriate under the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act 1998. This legislation will be amended to direct the additional revenue to new aviation safety and equity measures. It is worth while to note that the government has dramatically reduced the duty on aviation gasoline since 1996. In fact, that duty is now 15.768c per litre lower than in March 1996.

The new measures will increase levies. Rates of duty on avgas and avtur will be raised to 2.71c per litreâthat is, 0.467c per litre extra on avgas and 0.391c per litre on avtur and an additional 0.51c per litre to offset the Airservices (Location Specific Pricing) Subsidy. In response to the member for Dickson, there is a very significant subsidy there currently of around $9 million. The coming financial year, 1999-2000, will bring it to a total of $11 million, with a $7 million subsidy in 2001. These measures have been in place since midnight on 11 May 1999. Due to a technicality, the two rates of duty were uncoupled in November 1995. Under these amendments the two will be made identical again.

Going to CASA's funding and organisation, this measure will increase CASA's funding by $8.6 million a year and $46 million a year total revenue from aviation fuel levies, thereby ending the deficit that CASA has been running since 1996-97. As a result, CASA will be able to carry out a major restructure which will centralise critical enforcement decisions such as suspensions, cancellations and prosecutions. The end result will be increased air safety through a better resourced and run CASA. It will help guarantee what pilots and aviation companies have wanted for yearsâfair treatment in a uniform and standard manner.

I would add that I have had some experience of this inconsistent treatment meted out by CASA, and it is one of the more frustrating experiences. The legislation is quite draconian. It is very, very strong legislation which acts as a god to all. It has the all powerful and all enforcing ability to put someone out of business instantly. So it is important and essential that the administration be fair, centralised and consistent. After having been involved in someâhow do I put it carefullyâkind of negotiation with the previous structure of CASA and some of its personnel, I am encouraged that this sort of structure will give it a far better chance than it has had in the past to be fair, centralised and consistent.

Turning to the issue of aviation control towers, at present the federal government provides a subsidy to Airservices Australia to ensure the maintenance of reasonable prices for tower services at regional general aviation airports. The current subsidy includes the $11 million for 1998-99 and $2 million in 1999-2000. As I have indicated, the revenue will be boosted by $9 million, and $7 million in 2000-01. The total subsidy is $29 million. The subsidy will be administered by the Department of Transport and Regional Services to ensure the achievement of the goals intended.

The government will be spending up to $18 million over the next two years to help pay for air traffic control towers at 15 regional and general aviation airports where landing charges are capped at $6.75 per tonne landed. This is crucial to ensure that regional areas continue to receive the high quality, affordable and safe air transport and freight they require and deserve. Without the subsidy, the cost of a landing at just one regional airport would have been $38.22 per tonne rather than under the cap of $6.75 per tonne.

Increases in landing charges would devastate airports and their local economies. Closure of towers would render vast areas of Australia unsafe for air traffic. Unfortunately, an earlier attempt to reduce the costs of airport facilities by contracting out tower operations at regional airports was disallowed in the Senate. Other suggested alternatives to the rise in gasoline levies, such as a ticket tax or yearly registration fee for aircraft, would have not only created a difficult administrative burden but also placed in danger the already vulnerable general aviation sector.

I now turn to the expansion of the definition of `eligible aviation fuel'. From 12 May the definition of `eligible aviation fuel' will be expanded to include aviation kerosene as well as aviation gasoline. Avtur will now be treated in the same way as avgas. Requirements of mandatory consultation with the boards of CASA and Airservices Australia in relation to setting the `statutory rate' will end, as will those regulations concerning respective shares of revenue between CASA and Airservices. Such a matter is more properly one for the federal government, without such mandatory consultation. The minister has clearly indicated that he will continue to consult with the boards of both agencies, where such consultation is considered to be appropriate.
That is a brief explanation of the legislation. I speak obviously in support of the bills and wish the legislation a speedy passage.

talk.start.para: âWhile speaking in support of the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1999 , the Customs Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill 1999 and the Excise Tariff Amendment (Aviation Fuel Revenues) Bill 1999 and the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Grey on this particular issue, I ask that we not lose sight of the fact that the duty on aviation gasoline will still be 15.8c a litre cheaper than it was when this government took office in 1996. We must keep in mind that it will still be 15.8c a litre cheaper than it was when we came into office in 1996.

speech.para: The problem has been that, on 1 July 1998, Airservices Australia introduced terminal navigation charges for all its tower services, including those in regional areas, which were based on the costs it incurred at each location. The Federal Court ruled Airservices's charges unlawful other than on such a basis; and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, from which Airservices must obtain approval when it seeks to vary its charges, supports location-specific charges.

The move to location-specific charges was accompanied by the abolition of 15.692c per litre avgas duty that was directed to Airservices. The full implementation of these charging arrangements under Airservices's current cost structure would result in increases in charges of up to 300 per cent at some regional and general aviation airports ranging from $7.07 to $38.22 per tonne landing compared to the current subsidised rate of $6.75c at these airports.

An increase in charges of that kind or of the kind necessary to cover costs will destroy aviation services and training facilities in regional Australia, as my colleague the member for Grey mentioned. As some of these airports are vital to important regional centres, it was announced in the 1998-99 budget that the government and users of the major capital city airports would subsidise the charges of these particular airports. However, at the time the subsidy was agreed to, it was on the basis that it was required as an interim measure.

It was anticipated that Airservices would be able to contract out or privatise tower services at many of these subsidised locations, thus reducing the costs imposed on airport users and allowing the subsidy to phase down markedly in the 1999-2000 years and, of course, disappear in the following year. The recent disallowance by the Senate of the contracting out regulations has meant that cost reductions through the use of alternative service providers are no longer an option in the short term. In order to ensure that these essential services are provided at regional and general aviation training centres at a reasonable cost to users, the government has agreed to maintain a subsidy.

I turn to the solution. The Howard-Fischer government believes that all Australians should have access to safe and affordable air services. The government provides a subsidy to Airservices Australia so it can maintain tower services at regional and general aviation airports at prices lower than full cost of recovery. In addition, Airservices Australia will continue to cap general aviation charges at Cairns, Coolangatta and Canberra.

It would be prohibitively expensive to use some of our major regional airports without the subsidised cap. For example, in my own electorate of New England, the cost of landing at Tamworth regional airport would be $38.22 per tonneâquite an extraordinary amount of money. Some people have suggested that we could force airport users to pay the full cost of the tower services or, alternatively, close those control towers. The increases in landing charges necessary to fully recover tower costs at some locations would have a devastating effect on the airports and their local economies, and it would be unsafe to close the towers at some of those locations.

Instead the budget extends the subsidy to 2000-01. It provides an additional $9 million in the 1999-2000 year, taking the subsidy to $11 million next year, and an additional $7 million in the year 2000-01. The government is committed to reducing the cost of tower services in the longer term and has asked the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to develop safety standards for the operation of control towers by alternative service providers by 30 June 2000. The government will increase the duties on aviation turbine fuel and aviation gasoline to 2.71c per litre to pay for the extension of the regional control towers subsidy and the increase in CASA's funding. The tower subsidy component of the increaseâ0.51c per litreâis a temporary measure that will apply over the next two years.

The budget increases funding for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority by $8.6 million a year. In total CASA will receive $88.1 million from the government in appropriations and fuel duties in 1999-2000. CASA has been running a deficit since 1996-97. The increased funding will make it possible for CASA to carry out a major restructure, which will centralise critical enforcement decisions such as suspensions, cancellations and prosecutions. This restructure is being funded separately through a resource agreement with CASA. One common complaint about CASA is that its district offices apply the aviation laws inconsistently. I am sure we have all heard them. The centralisation of critical decisions will guarantee that pilots and aviation companies are treated in the same fair way, no matter where they are in Australia.

A proportion of the rise in the aviation fuel duty to 2.71c per litre or 0.467c per litre on avgas and 0.391c per litre on avtur will pay for the increase in CASA's funding. The government examined other optionsâas it should, and as it was duty bound to doâfor increasing the organisation's funding, such as a levy on airline tickets or yearly aircraft registration fees. The ticket tax, however, would have been administratively cumbersome, and yearly aircraft registration fees would have greatly increased the tax burden on the vulnerable general aviation sector. In closing, I repeat the fact that the duty on aviation gasoline is still 15.8c a litre lower than it was when the government took office in 1996. I commend all the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, I thank honourable members for their contribution to this debate. This package gives effect to the government's budget decision to increase the duties on aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel to 2.71c per litre. In her comments, the member for Dickson noted in passing that the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association was opposed to an increase in the duties. I would simply remind the House that the duty on aviation gasoline is now 15.768c per litre lower than it was when we took officeâa significant decrease in any terms. I thank those members who contributed so constructively to this debate. I commend the bills to the House.

debateinfo.title: NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT (LIFETIME HEALTH COVER) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 June, on motion by Dr Wooldridge:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 has been described by the Minister for Health and Aged Care as the last great reform for private health insurance. It is more aptly described as his fourth rescue plan in four years. We are rapidly going down the same road as we did in the Fraser years when we saw five health plans in five years. As I will explain, the opposition does not intend to oppose the introduction of lifetime community rating even though the scheme the government has dubbed `Lifetime Health Cover' falls a long way short of a great reform.

speech.para: The opposition has always said that it supports the private health sector working to complement Medicare. Most other OECD countries have private health insurance available to provide a service to a particular part of the community that wants and can afford such a product. Where we part company with the government is in its fixation that membership of private health insurance has to be artificially boosted at public expense. We strongly object to the $1.7 billion government rebate for private health insurance and will oppose measures that limit access to the public hospital system or anything that results in resources being taken from the public sector to subsidise the private sector.

This bill enables Lifetime Health Cover to be adopted by removing restrictions in the National Health Act 1973 that require private health insurance to be community rated. In essence, people will pay a higher premium depending on the age at which they join private health insurance. The intention is to create a penalty which encourages people to join earlier and, once joined, to stay with the fund.

The key elements of the scheme are that all existing fund members and anyone who joins in future under the age of 30 pays the base premium. People born before July 1934âthat is, those who are 65 nowâand who are currently not members of health insurance funds will be charged only a base premium if they join in the future. That does not mean the base premium now, but whatever the 30-year-old premium is in the future. Anyone else who joins after the age of 30 will pay an additional two per cent for every year they wait. This increases to a maximum of 70 per cent. So there is a 70 per cent penalty for people joining at age 65 or older.

Members can suspend their membership with the agreement of the fund if they travel overseas or have other hardship claims such as losing a job. Members who drop their membership have their effective age under the scheme adjusted by a formula that gives them up to three years of being non-financial without a penalty to their premium. Longer periods of absence impose a proportional penalty.

The government also intends allowing people to join health funds before 1 July next year without incurring any of these penalties. The outcome is intended to be that everyone pays a premium that reflects their age of entry to insurance adjusted for periods of absence. People who are members for fewer years pay towards the insurance pool. However, there will still be a substantial cross-subsidy in the arrangements and the grandfathering of people over the age of 65 as of now largely undoes the impact of the scheme in reducing hit and run claims in that age group.

Lifetime Health Cover is a move by this government away from community rating. The objective is transparently to push people into private health insurance over the next 12 months in fear of higher premiums after that. It really is designed to cover up for what has been an abysmal failure of the government's $1.7 billion health subsidy, which has neither attracted new members nor controlled premium rises.

In fact, it was reported on the day after the budget that the government has a target which it is trying to keep secretâa target that private health insurance membership levels will increase to 36 per cent of the population as a result of this move to lifetime cover. If it succeeds in this goal, it will create two significant problems. Firstly, and most importantly, it will result in $200 million being clawed back from public hospitals under the Australian health care agreements without any evidence whatsoever that the pressure on public hospitals is being reduced. Secondly, it may worsen the degree of adverse selection within the health funds.

The people who are most likely to join the health funds in the next 12 monthsâthat is, before the penalties startâare those aged between 50 and 65. Those over 65 have been given an exemption from the penalties but, if a lot of middle-aged people join, the funds may develop a very skewed age profile. If so, this will give them serious financial problems in a decade when these members start making large claims.

I will talk a little later about a range of other issues which may require some amendments to be made to the legislation. It certainly is the case that the bill has been constructed with some haste. There certainly is a need for more opportunity for public debate and consideration. As a result, the opposition intends to refer the bill to a Senate committee to give the community an opportunity to comment on the design the government has adopted. I will also outline a little later the general areas in which the opposition intends moving amendments when this bill reaches the third reading stage in the Senate. The most important of these concerns the flow-on impact that lifetime cover may have on public hospital funding.
We certainly now know the Prime Minister's view about private health insurance and its appeal to ordinary Australians. He went on television on 12 May just this year and expressed himself as follows:
. . . you are faced with the possibility that if you want it in 10 years timeâ
that is private health insuranceâ
when you are not as healthy as you are now it will be more expensiveâ
because of the government's change that we are now debatingâ
So therefore, you might say to yourself, `gee, it's more important to go into private health insurance now than to add another country to my next overseas trip.'

The Prime Minister should not be surprised that only 30 per cent of Australians can afford private health insurance at its current price. Far less than 30 per cent are planning globe trotting annual holidays. To understand why the industry is so keen on lifetime health cover we need go no further than the industry's own spokesperson Russell Schneider. He recently made the wonderfully frank admission that most young people will not buy private health insurance at any price. This came in stark contrast to his prediction of eight months ago that the 30 per cent rebate would result in a massive increase in participation to 45 per cent. In May this year, Mr Schneider addressed the ACT branch of the Australian College of Health Practitioners and used the occasion to outline the real motivation for Lifetime Health Cover. The Australian newspaper recorded that he told the gathering:
We are really after the 35 to 45 or 50 age group, especially if they don't have kids. It's then, they don't make claims. We are after the yuppies with no kids, they have lowest utilisation rates.

In other words, the industry openly admits that its products are not viable at the premium levels that would be required to recover costs from the existing membership. It is only by forcing more young and middle aged people to pay premiums without claiming that they hope to run at a profit.

The minister has been boldly going around predicting that Lifetime Health Cover will result in a drop in health insurance premiums. The truth is that there will be no such drop. Young people are not being offered a discount to take up health insurance; they are simply being told to join at the current prices or face a penalty premium in the future. Various people who responded to the initial discussion paper that the government put out proposed that there should be discounts for younger people to give them an incentive, but this advice was ignored. Everyone starts off at the same rates and late joiners pay the penalty. It could have been different, but the government lacked the insight to design a fair and effective system that would encourage rather than penalise.

Of course there is no substance to the minister's claim that premiums will actually drop. Once again, we need go no further than the always frank Russell Schneider to find out the industry's view. He told the magazine Australian Doctor on 7 May:

The cost of both private health insurance and private health care was unlikely to decrease and it is time that doctors and hospitals joined me in saying that. We have to end the myth of cheap health insurance.

I have to say that nobody with health insurance would think it was a myth that it was cheap. There is also no doubting where Mr Schneider and the industry stand on cost control. There is a long record of price increases running at two to three times the inflation rate to back up his conviction. Is there any wonder then that in an opinion poll in the Melbourne Herald Sun just last week in response to the question: `Do you think private health insurance offers value for money?' a mere 13 per cent said yes and a whopping 86 per cent of people said no. The industry has been unable to convince half of their members that they actually get value for money.

To understand just how heavily subsidised this industry has become let us compare the $1.7 billion a year government subsidy to the assistance that is given to other sectors of the economy. Madam Deputy Speaker Kelly, you might particularly be interested in this given the electorate you represent. The Productivity Commission's trade and assistance review last year records the total level of assistance given to other sectors, showing both the tax expenditures and the budget outlays. The total budget support for the primary production sector amounted to $823 million and all the assistance to manufacturing amounts to $1.4 billion. In other words, private health insurance funds get more support from this government than that which goes to the entire primary industry sector or manufacturing industry sectors in each single year. It is scandalous the extent to which this government is prepared to subsidise private health insurance for no benefit whatsoever to the health system.

The promotion of Lifetime Health Cover has depicted it as a long-awaited final solution for the ailing private health insurance industry. But the government knows well that it will not solve these problems. It is another in a long line of schemes that the government has tried and failed. The opposition is concerned that the public should be fully aware of the agenda which the government and elements of the health sector have for future changes to our health system. In the same week that Lifetime Health Cover was introduced into parliament, the news leaked out that the minister was secretly planning to sell Medibank Private. Since then, the minister has certainly not denied that such plans exist. He simply says that he has not formally raised them with his colleagues.

Medibank Private has served Australia well over the last 20 years and has an enviable record. Not only does it generally have the best premiums, it was also found by Choice magazine to offer the best buy for hospital cover in every state other than Tasmania where a local fund outdid it. On top of this, Medibank Private managed the lowest average increase of any fund in the most recent round of premium increases. Medibank Private put its premiums up by only 1.9 per cent, the same as the inflation rate. It is a great pity that many other funds were nowhere near this performance. So at a time when the industry is under great pressure, what does the government want to do about its most efficient fund? It wants to sell it off. Instead of welcoming the stability that a publicly owned, large and relatively efficient fund offers as a benchmark for the rest of the industry, this minister wants to get rid of it.

The next plan we have been hearing about is the means testing of Medicare. Two Liberal premiers, Mr Kennett and Mr Court from Western Australia, as well as many people in medical circles have been actively advocating that entry to public hospitals should be means tested or, as Richard Court said, limited to those on benefits. This would be yet another attempt to turn back the clock to the time when Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister and our current Prime Minister was Treasurer and they produced a radical agenda to privatise health care. It failed dismally then and contributed greatly to the demise of that government. It also led to the birth of Medicare, because the Australian public have said so clearly so many times that they want a universal health insurance scheme. If the next great reform to health care by this minister is the means testing of Medicare, it will be strenuously opposed by the opposition.

Another retrograde measure which apparently was considered by the government in the lead-up to the recent budget and which has been pushed by a number of medical groups, including the AMA, is a reduction in the threshold for payment of the Medicare surcharge to a large number of people earning below the current limits of $50,000 for an individual and $100,000 for a family. It would be another major blow if this minister thinks he might embark on another revolutionary reform to private health insurance, because it would be a significant attack on the universal nature of Medicare. If people on incomes around $35,000 were required to pay the surcharge, as some commentators have suggested, it would be tantamount to a tax on those who could least afford it. Many of these people have no need for private health insurance and, as Russell Schneider knows, most would make relatively few claims.

The reform the government is yet to give any details about is the reform of the reinsur ance pool. It is a contradiction that the government has made major changes such as the 30 per cent rebate and is now introducing lifetime health cover but has left the reinsurance pool untouched. The effect of the existing reinsurance pool arrangements is to share risks between the funds and equal out variations in their membership profiles and claim patterns. This gives no incentive to pursue cost saving agreements. It rewards the inefficient funds and equalises out the effect of changes, such as the one we are debating tonight, lifetime health cover. The funds that have a larger number of younger members or do effective deals to keep premiums down lose out in the current reinsurance arrangements.

The minister knows that industry experts are saying he should be changing the rules for the reinsurance pool at the same time he is abandoning the community rating principle. But he does not want to do that because he needs to have the industry united behind him in order to get this plan adopted. He knows that if he undertook the changes to the reinsurance arrangements he would lose the industry's support, particularly from the inefficient funds. The minister should be well aware that the logical consequence of moving to lifetime health cover is that the reinsurance arrangements will have to change. The latest information is that this will come next year, but we will have to wait and see because the way this minister seems to go about health insurance changes is to do them in a completely piecemeal way.

The minister also seems to be edging towards the soft option on the elimination of gap payments, another major issue in health insurance. Six months ago, he bowed to pressure from Senator Harradine in the Senate and finally agreed to tackle the rapidly growing gap payments, which is the main deterrent to people taking out or keeping their private health insurance. In an article in the Australian today, we see that gap payments have continued to grow. In the last two years, gap payments for nine frequently used surgical procedures have increased by an average of $200.

Last week in the Senate estimates committee, we saw that the government's plan to increase the Medicare rebate for difficult births in order to eliminate gap payments has been completely negated by obstetricians. Mothers are still facing gaps of almost the same amount. So despite the increase in the Medicare rebate from $400 to $950, the average gap payment has dropped only slightly from $300 to $218âno prizes for guessing who is holding the bill. The government did not have any agreement with the obstetricians to contain their gap payments. Those obstetricians have just said, `Thank you very much,' to the government for the extra money they have paid by way of the rebate and have made no commitment to eliminating the gap payments.

The same is now happening with the AMA plan. It was initially stated that there would not be any flow on in prices under a ministerially endorsed framework to control gaps. Now we are being told that this is being turned into gap insurance without any control on fees. We have not seen any legislation being put on the table, although I note once again in the Australian Doctor that it was intended to pass before the end of June. The minister should think very carefully before he brings in legislation that permits gap insurance at the expense of rapidly escalating premiums. The spiral of medical inflation of costs would be the death knell for private health insurance, as he well knows.

There are a number of areas in the Lifetime Health Cover proposal that certainly will need to be improved and I hope we will be able to do that in the Senate. To do that, we will certainly need to have access to the actuarial advice the government has so far refused to release. That advice goes to the specific scheme that we are debating tonight. The only public information we have is limited to a 1997 report that is based on quite a different design. The opposition is calling for the latest analysis to be tabled before the Senate committee, and we will also be seeking to question the consultants who designed the Lifetime Health Cover about the details of the scheme.

One of the serious weaknesses in the scheme we have before us is that it makes no distinction between the very large number of products now available for private health insurance. Any type of hospital cover is sufficient to preserve the lowest possible entry date. This leaves open the opportunity for a quite blatant sort of rort. A person could purchase a low cost hospital policy with a large patient contribution, or what is called `high end deductible'.

These policies have become very fashionable because of the design of the government's Medicare surcharge which the funds have exploited. Often people with this sort of policy have no intention whatsoever of using private hospitals unless they have a very serious illness. They are simply avoiding the surcharge and buying the cheapest scheme possible. Now they will also be able to insulate themselves from the penalties in Lifetime Health Cover.

Why should a person who has paid less than half a full premium be able to upgrade their premium after 20 years without any penalty when they have paid a fraction of the commitment of a person who has been fully covered throughout that period? It just does not stand up by the government's own logic. The Senate inquiry should look at a more accurate formula that would allocate a premium penalty in accordance with people's past commitments to make sure that there is some internal fairness in the scheme.

The government should also look closely at its grandfather provision for people aged over 65. There is no question that this is a worthwhile and, I have to say, atypically generous move by the government to avoid creating problems for those who are most vulnerable. One issue which would improve this part of the scheme would be if the government could explain why it has grandfathered people over the age of 65 but not extended the same concession to those women aged under 65 who are already in receipt of the age or widow's pension.

As far as the hardship provisions are concerned, the government's proposal is complex and is likely to create numerous anomalies. The rules in relation to periods of leave, overseas absence and suspension of membership overlap and the definitions are potentially ambiguous. The way in which these rules affect people in different family situations need to be explored in depth by the Senate inquiry. I do not want to dwell on these points now but I would like the government to have a look at these provisions in the bill because it currently lacks a mechanism to resolve complaints and solve these hardship situations.

The assigned date of entry is a key piece of information for each person, and it will be costly if a dispute arises. Funds are meant to accept transfers of members at the same level, but there is no compulsion and no process to sort out even a basic problem such as a lost file. The hardship provision that is in the bill has a tight sunset clause in the year 2002. It also depends on the minister investigating hardship cases to resolve them. The opposition believes it might be more effective to have a continuing mechanism whereby the private health insurance ombudsman has clear discretion and powers to resolve disputes and alleviate hardship. Again, the details of what is required should be explored in the Senate inquiry.

Another concern we have is with regard to the advertising program proposed by the governmentâanother $10 million of taxpayers' money to be spent on health insurance. Our concerns are: will this be another blatant political campaign conducted by this government? I certainly hope we are not going to have to see the ACCC being the policeman again. We will be seeking some stringent guidelines through the Senate inquiry to make sure that that does not happen. As I said at the start of my remarks, the opposition does not oppose the concept of Lifetime Health Cover, but I do have grave concerns about some of the design elements. We will not oppose the bill in the House, but we will pursue some of these problems when it gets to the Senate.

As I have also said, the main concern that we have is the way in which the scheme, as it is currently designed, will impact on our public hospital system. What I will be seeking from the government and what I put to the minister tonight is that we need to make sure that this scheme does not result in further cutbacks to our public hospitals that form the core of our health system. The government has failed to demonstrate any evidence that an increase in private health insurance will result in reduced demand on our cash strapped public hospitals.

It was reported the day after the budget when lifetime cover was announced that the Department of Health and Aged Care thinks this scheme might frighten enough people into private health insurance to achieve the target of 36 per cent. If private health insurance did rise to 36 per cent, that would cost the government over $300 million because of the 30 per cent rebate. But the government has made it clear that the basis for proceeding with Lifetime Health Cover is that it will not come at a cost. You might ask: how can this be possible? Because the government intends to take this money off our public hospitals.

Demand for public hospital beds has continued to increase and funding provided under the Australian health care agreements is already insufficient to provide decent health care services sufficient to meet demand. The public needs to know that the government inserted a clawback clause in each of these health care agreements with the states. So funding to each state will be reduced when private health insurance coverage exceeds a particular trigger point for that state. These trigger points are generally around 34 per cent. Our public hospitals will lose around $200 million if the government achieves what is understood to be its undisclosed target of 36 per cent membership by next July as a result of the proposed $10 million television campaign.

This is outrageous on two counts. Firstly, the people the funds and the government hope will take out health insurance because of Lifetime Health Cover are the young and the healthy who do not claim. As they are not sick, they will not be going to public hospitals either. In other words, increasing health insurance by this method will not take any pressure off public hospitals.

Secondly, the states did not know about the introduction of Lifetime Health Cover when they signed the Australian health care agreements. They were not to know the government had in mind attempting to drive people into health insurance by this method which would take no pressure off the public hospitals. The government should act immediately to make sure that our public hospitals are protected. We all know the enormous pressures that they are already under, and this further cut in funding which the government has in mind will only make matters worse.

If Lifetime Health Cover is to proceed, the clawback arrangements need to be removed and an assurance given that there will not be a reduction in public hospital funding, which is not related to actual demand for public hospital services. To proceed without this assurance would highlight the risk that this scheme is just another attack on public hospitals and the principle of universal coverage under Medicare. I certainly hope that the minister will seriously examine this proposal, and I look forward to the detailed consideration of this bill when it gets before the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI acknowledge the long involvement of the shadow minister for health in the health industry and her tabling of the Macklin reports, and I note her total commitment to the Medicare arrangements and her rejection of private health insurance. I totally reject her very unfair attacks on Russell Schneider, who is the spokesman for the insurance industry. Nobody has a better understanding of the issues involved in the private insurance industry than he has, and I think the shadow minister was very unfair in the way in which she attacked Mr Schneider. I also totally reject the argument that the $1.7 billion allocated by the government is a scandalous subsidy in the $40 billion total health budget. Finally, I note that the shadow minister has said that the opposition will not oppose this measure, and that is a reflection of the public support that the government has received in putting forward this proposal.

speech.para: I support very strongly the National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 because most Australians value their health. Being in good health is fundamentally important to most people. Most people, if they have to choose, would rather be healthy but not rich instead of wealthy and sick. It is a fundamental thing that most Australians and most voters understand, especially in my electorate of Corangamite, where 59 per cent of the people have taken out private health insurance.

Australians really want a choice as to the kind of health care they have, and this measure will help provide this choice. They do not want, nor should they have placed in their path, a public health system where there is only one choice. We see this situation in the UK, where it is 100 per cent National Health Service, although the situation is changing in that country. On the other hand, private health gives people a choice. It gives them the ability to choose their own doctor and hospital and to receive treatment when it suits them, instead of having to get in the public hospital queue. I talked with Minister Tuckey, who is at the table, about this on a number of occasions during his time as the shadow spokesman for health.

People want a choice in protecting their own health, and surveys reveal that the overwhelming majority of people want to have private health insurance to supplement their Medicare cover. Unfortunately, a few of them are stopped by what they consider to be the prohibitive cost of private health insurance, and I think both sides of the parliament acknowledge that fact. They consider the cost of private cover to be too high compared with the `free' Medicare systemâand I think this is the fundamental issue before us all in this House. The problem is worsened by patients having to pay the gap between the schedule feeâwhich private health insurance coversâand the actual fee from the doctor. The gap occurs when GPs do not bulk-bill and patients end up paying 15 per cent of the schedule fee, and when doctors in hospital charge a patient more than the schedule fee. I think that most Australians are concerned about that issue. Gaps rarely occur with hospital fees, because they are more regulated and more understanding.

Private cover does not cover everything; people can still be out of pocket, and that is the main complaint that I get. There is a need for attractive `no gap' products to be further developed, and the government is encouraging insurers to make innovative changes. On the other hand, the government is discouraging specific gap policies and is encouraging people to take out the total insurance. This legislation is one of a series of reforms designed to protect health care in Australia.

I emphasise that the coalition's support of Medicare is ongoing. Medicare has wide community supportâeveryone in this parliament would understand thatâand, under this government, Medicare stays. However, the survival of the public health system is contingent on the survival of the private health insurance system.

Recent ABS figures, from 1996, tell us some very interesting facts. According to those figures, health in Australia takes up 8.5 per cent of the GDP, compared with about 15 per cent of GDP in the USA. So, relatively speaking, we have an efficient health system here in Australia which is not taking too much of our resources. Health is a $40 billion industry, and I think members on both sides should fully understand the magnitude of the amount of money involved in the health industry in Australia. Forty-five per cent of the health industry is Commonwealth fundedâso this parliament funds about half of the industry; 22 per cent of the industry is state funded; and 33 per cent of the industry is funded by private expenditure. So the reality is that 65 per cent of the health sector is government funded, and nearly three-quarters is funded by the taxpayers.

The fundamental problem is that taxpayers are paying already for the systemâbut they see it as free or as something that is to be used because it is there. They have that attitude and that makes it difficult for private insurers. The private sector is hardly on a level playing field, because they are up against another product which is perceived as being free; but obviously it is not free, because the taxpayers are funding it.

The other significant benefit of private health insurance is frequently overlooked: the existence of the private sector encourages efficiencies throughout the entire health system. Without private hospitals there would be less choice, less competition and lower efficiency standards throughout the system. We know that privately insured Australians comprise about 30 per cent of the population, and that figure has been debated in this place throughout the health debate over the last few years. Fifteen years ago, 65 per cent of the population was privately insured but, under the Labor government, that dropped quite dramatically. It is estimated that every time this figure drops by one per cent, another $100 million will have to be spent on the public system by the taxpayer.

Facts about private health insurance from the Industry Commission's report on private health insurance conducted in 1997 provide some very interesting data: private health insurance is a $4.5 billion industry; the six million Australians it covers tend to be richer and older than average; most individuals who have private health insurance have top level cover, costing an average of $1,230 for individuals and $2,460 for families; there are 48 health benefit organisations, and most are mutual societies. There are more than 60,000 people employed in the private system, and there are in excess of 22,000 beds.

The private sector is a very important part of the total health system in Australia. There is a need to stabilise and then increase the number of privately insured Australians, especially with an ageing population where people make greater use of doctors and hospitals. The other important feature is the introduction of new medical technology, making it all the more costly to use these facilities.

How is this government increasing the number of privately insured patients? Firstly, it has put a surcharge on high income earners, encouraging them to insure privately because they have more resources to do so. An individual earning more than $50,000 per annum or a couple earning $100,000 will pay a 2.7 per cent Medicare levy rather than the 1.7 per cent levy. That is an incentive for people to take out private health insurance and not lean on the public system. This is an equitable policy, and it reminds people that there is no free public system, like there is no free lunch.

The 30 per cent rebate which the Howard government introduced effectively deals with the fundamental reasonâwhich we have certainly debated in this placeâthat people have dropped out of private cover: it is too expensive. The Industry Commission, in its deliberations, identified that the price issue was the major factor of the vicious circle of declining membership. As the costs went up, the numbers declined and then costs went up again, and it was forever a vicious circle which reduced the number of people in the private system.

The government is hoping to stabilise the numbers and improve the membership profile; that is, increase the number of young peopleâwho are better insurance risksâwith private health insurance. A very important and encouraging aspect of this particular policy is that from the age of 31 onwards you will pay an extra two per cent per annum on your premium for every year in which you do not have private health cover. So if you apply for private health insurance in 10 years time, you will pay an extra two per cent for every year you do not have cover. The fundamental decision people have to make is whether to join a private health insurance fund at an early age and keep the cover later in life or pay a penalty later on if they want to join.

These reforms, as members would be aware, take effect from July next year. There will be a period of grace until then to allow people to make these decisions. If you are in a fund before that time you will pay the lowest rate and there will be no penalty. If you are 65 or older on 1 July 2000, you will be exempt from paying these premium penalties. The government is encouraging people to join, and it is providing a period of grace for people in the short term so that in the longer term the funds will be in a competitive position. The government has allowed for cover to be suspended for an aggregated period of 1,094 days for the unemployed and those travelling overseas to cover some of the anomalies that have been raised in the debate.

This policy rewards long-term members and discourages hit-and-run members. There has been an ongoing debate about people who, to use the parochial term, hit and runâthose who join the funds in times of potential medical need and leave at a time when they do not think they will use the funds. People in the electorate of Corangamite frequently say to me, `I've paid for my private cover for years. It's very expensive, but I'm too afraid to leave.' They have done the right thing, been in private health insurance, and they are not game to leave but are very worried about the high level of premiums. Fundamentally, loyalty to these funds should be rewarded by a lower premium structure so that we do not have this hit-and-run syndrome and people remain in the funds for most of their lifetime.

The public perceives the fairness of what we are doing in this legislation. The MBF-Morgan Health Watch survey of 1,200 people across the country conducted last month indicated that 68 per cent of Australians agree with the principle of lifetime community rating. The government has also addressed the other key finding: that the public do not want to see the elderly penalised. The concepts of community rating and the need to look after the older, potentially sicker members of our community can be addressed in this legislation. We have addressed the problem of the over-65s being exempt in the early stages of the legislation.

If we do have a lifetime community rating concept, it will increase the likelihood of premium reductions. Actuarial projections suggest that five years of lifetime health cover will make insurance more affordable for all members than under the current system. The projection is that premiums could be 15 per cent lower compared to the current system. This will take pressure off the public hospital waiting lists, and that is one of the key outcomes of the proposal before the parliament.

When Medicare was introduced in 1984, 65 per cent of Australians had private health insurance. Under the Labor government it was reduced to 30 per cent. The government has written to everyone 65 years and over telling them that they are exempt from these current proposals. Labor, however, want to neglect private health insurance, as they claim it will destroy Medicare. As the shadow spokesperson indicated in her remarks to the House, they are supporters of Medicare. However, it is interesting to hear what some other members of the Labor Partyâthose who had an understanding of health matters and understood what the declining membership of private health funds would doâhave had to say. Former health minister Graham Richardson has often been quoted. In the Bulletin of 21 August 1996, he had this to say on Labor's position:

Labor aren't recognising the big problem. It's still a huge problemâthat people are deserting health insurance at the rate they are. It isn't a problem any of you will worry about tomorrow, but in ten years time it will be.
He went on to say:

I steered the package through the Cabinet but resigned before I could sell it to the caucus. Practically the whole package died when I left as the Labor Party has always been biased against private health insurance. Without a sponsor, any proposal to help the industry was doomed.

We can see quite clearly what that spokesman, what that minister, thought about the Labor Party's position, and no-one has really refuted the intelligent and sensible remarks of former Senator Richardson.

There is also the member for Werriwa. He is a thoughtful Young Turk. On 19 March 1999, Mark Latham, writing in his regular column in the Daily Telegraph, referred to the intent of this legislation: to link premium levels to the age at which people take up fund membership. He noted:
This is what the Whitlam Government wanted to do in 1973.
Approvingly, he continued:
. . . private health insurance needs to operate according to the rules of risk and competitive pricing.
His conclusion was:
The best way to support Medicare and the public hospital system is to support the phasing out of community rating.
I might debate some of the points that he raised, but he fundamentally understands that you need to have the Medicare arrangements, and you need to have the private sector running alongside.

There are projections that health costs will double in 25 years and that governments of all political colours will not be able to fund these galloping health costs. This government is spending an additional 17 per cent on Medicare in the coming years. The Howard government is providing the choice of Medicare, and it has made an attempt to stabilise the decline in private health numbers. It has doubled medical research funding, with an increase of $614 million over the next six years. This is a step in the right direction. The area of research has an impact on the total health bill, which impacts on patients. Community rating remains. It is fair and it gives a lifetime guarantee.

Through this legislation we are responding to the Industry Commission report of 1997, which recommended lifetime cover. We have received support from the Council on the Ageing, Consumers Health Forum of Australia, the AMA, the Australian Private Hospitals Association, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association and the Australian Consumer Association. Reform needs to be ongoing. All members on the government side would agree with that, and this is a major step in the right direction. The Industry Commission recommended there be a further broad inquiry into Australia's health system. Allowing the Industry Commission to have yet another look at the health arrangements is worthy of consideration.

The next real challenge to the government and to all those persons interested in the health of Australians is no-gap insurance to cover the gap between the scheduled fee and what the doctor charges. It is a very real issue out in the electorates, as most members would be aware, and the government is looking at that. I encourage the minister and the policy makers to address this fundamental issue. It is incumbent on insurers to look at innovative products to ensure that those people who wish to remain in private health insurance get value for the money they are paying out on an annual basis through their premiums.

The main thrust of this legislation is to protect the choice that the private sector brings to the health industry. More importantly, the legislation encourages efficiency in the health industry. Individual Australians can receive treatment in the public hospital system or the private hospital system and have the doctor of their choice. I think it is a step in the right direction. It is a fundamental move which, hopefully, in the longer term will establish an ongoing system of private health insurance.

Those sitting opposite have fought tooth and nail to refute the arguments about the importance of private health insurance in the scheme of health provision in Australia. That is a pity, because in the longer term we need the resources to look after young and older Australians. We need to make sure that over the next 20 and 30 years we have the resources to increase medical technology. Private health insurance, with more Australians in private health funds, will ensure that this comes about. I commend the bill, I commend the concepts behind it and I commend all Australians and this parliament to support this very innovative and important piece of legislation.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Corangamite, in his selective quotations of the member for Werriwa, forgot to point out that in the same article the member for Werriwa said he believed Graham Richardson was wrong in 1993. The second reading speech on the National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 says:

speech.para: The government is committed to ensuring a balance between public and private health sectors. This balance will ensure Australians have a level of choice as well as universal access to excellent health care.

The government then goes on to claim that it has demonstrated this commitment through recent reforms to private health insurance. In the light of the commitment I cited above, I question the government's motives in this legislation and its priorities.

I would like to deal with these issues in turn. What exactly does the government claim? The government announced in its recent 1999-2000 budget that it would introduce Lifetime Health Cover from 1 July 2000. Essentially, Lifetime Health Cover is an extension of the carrot and stick philosophy, designed to allow private health insurance funds to charge different premiums depending on the age at which people take up private health insurance. It is based on age rating rather than risk factoring. Anyone in future who joins under the age of 30 will pay the base premium. Existing members are protected, no matter what their age, and will pay the base rate set for people of 30 years-of-age for the rest of their lives provided they remain insured.

A carrot at the end of this health insurance stick is the sunset clause, with a commencement date of 1 July 2000. After all the incentives thrown at people over the last four years by this government, this allows a 12-month period in which people who are not currently members of private health insurance funds to join and pay the rate for a 30-year-old. Anyone else who joins after 1 July 2000 and after the age of 30 will pay an additional two per cent for every year they wait. This increases to a maximum of 70 per cent for people joining at age 65 years or older. However, people born before 1 July 1934 will be able to join a fund at any time and pay the rate for a 30-year-old.

This is an interesting choice of age rating. Industry analysts suspect that 65 years as the maximum age threshold has been chosen probably for political rather than actuarial reasons. The same could be said about the special treatment of those over 65. So what is the logic of choosing 30 as opposed to, for example, 25? To date there has not been an announcement by health insurance funds on the actual new base rate premiums for health insurance policies.

In order to rationally debate the legislation, it is prudent to outline some of the arguments put forward by supporters of Lifetime Health Cover. These would include some of the following, which I would add are quite contentious and fundamentally flawed in places. For instance, over time, Lifetime Health Cover should result in a broad cross-section of the community being covered by private health insurance. This is premised on the argument that younger people will be encouraged to join funds at the cheaper rate rather than waiting until they are older. Thus, as the age profile of people insured changes, it is argued that premiums should begin to stabilise and may even fall because the funds will have more good risks.

The government further argues that the introduction of Lifetime Health Cover, combined with the effect of other initiatives such as the 30 per cent rebate, will make private health insurance more attractive to people who regard it as poor value. Finally, there is a belief that the existing system of community rating encourages a short-term view of private health insurance, whereby many people weigh up their risks and join health insurance funds only when they expect to use their insurance cover.

It is interesting to note that this is the fourth major change to private health insurance in four years. In 1996, a means tested rebate was introduced to fix the health insurance industry's problems. Well, it did not work, so we were hit with a one per cent Medicare levy surcharge to force higher income earners to take out health insurance. It did not work.

Less than a year ago, this government tried the current approach, a $1.7 billion bribe to get the middle class to take up private health insurance. It was warning us that the private health care industry faced a bleak future unless the Senate passed the new 30 per cent health insurance rebate. With the privately insured portion of the population dipping towards only 30 per cent, the tax rebate was a desperate measure by the government to stop the unravelling of the private insurance system it so passionately supported. The 30 per cent rebate was supposed to achieve 550,000 new members by the end of this year and increase the insured population from 30 per cent to 33 per cent. Six months ago, the industry itself was saying that it would lift coverage to 45 per cent, translating to 2.5 million new members.

What do we have now? The industry tells us that more measures are now needed. I note that the June-July 1999 edition of Health Cover reported the March 1999 quarter increase, for an outlay of $1.76 billion per year in taxpayer subsidies, as this:
. . . piddling 8.2 per cent notwithstanding extensive advertising that misled many. The insured population rose a net 57,000 from 30.1 per cent to 30.3 per cent.

The obvious conclusion to draw from this scheme is that it was an expensive bandaid proposal, along with others before it, to repair the private health care industry. It has not worked. It has not resulted in significant uptakes in membership quite simply because it went largely to people who were already insured for a wide range of reasons. Additionally, the rebate scheme's objective to arrest premium increases has also failed to materialise. Premiums have gone up by an average of 4.9 per cent. This is not surprising, and analysts of the proposed legislation argue that the trend will continue.

Jacquie Hayes of the Australian Financial Review of 15-16 May 1999 cites comments of Nicola Ballenden, a senior health policy officer of the Australian Consumers Association, who says that the proposal is unfair and probably will not achieve its aim of bringing more people into the system and encouraging a more rational pricing policy. Since 1999, premiums have risen each year between four and 17 per cent, which is an average of almost eight per cent. Ballenden has concluded:
In effect, the health insurance premiums are rising higher than inflation and there are no guarantees those prices won't continue to rise.
In what really sums up the major problem with this legislation, Ballenden says:
In my view, it's more likely they will rise, because there is no mechanism in place to stop it.

The Herald Sun of 2 June 1999 published a Voteline on the question of whether private health insurance is value for money. Of the 522 calls, 86.6 per cent said no and 13.4 per cent answered yes. I can assure you that the Labor Party did not arrange that ring-in.
Paul Gross, in the Australian Financial Review of 19 May 1999, labelled the current proposals before the House as:
. . . yet another marginal tinkering with health insuranceâand it will not drive down the price of health insurance in the short term.

He quotes Minister Wooldridge as saying that these proposals would have a long-term impact. His first guess was `three to five years', but it soon became five to 10 years later in the interview. Few health commentators believe that the proposed legislation will force down premiums or fundamentally attract younger people.

Russell Schneider, the Chief Executive of the Australian Health Insurance Association, claimed that this legislation would not achieve its aims because the young neither wanted nor could afford private health insurance. I am sorry that the member for Corangamite is not here because Jenny Macklin did not attack Mr Schneider's credibility; she merely quoted him. I will continue to quote him:
The scheme's real success is not going to be that it gets young people in, but it gets younger people in a few years before they start making claims.
We're really after the 35-40 or 50 age groups, especially if they don't have kids for they don't make claims . . .
We're after the yuppies with no kids. They have the lowest utilisation rates of anybody.

In effect the proposed scheme is based on the aim of attracting low risk profile insurers with the lowest utilisation rates. There are two interesting consequences of this. The first is that, given the current base premiums, there is not much incentive for young people to join an insurance fund, either on health or on economic grounds.

Ian McAuley, lecturer in Public Service Finance at the University of Canberra, has done extensive study on alternative options to health insurance. In the main, McAuley argues that viable alternatives exist for people who resent being forced into taking out insurance they either do not want or feel they do not need. The point he makes is that even with coercion or incentivesâcarrot and stick policiesâthose who ignore the fear factor and choose either to defer joining a fund until age 65 or to commit to a disciplined savings plan to pay for their own medical expenses are likely to be better off.

For example, a 30-year-old who pays a $1,000 premium every year until the age of 80 would end up paying double that of a 65-year-old who would be hit with a full 70 per cent penalty for late membership, paying $1,700 a year for the next 15 years. This is the stage of life when most Australians really need insurance to help with the costs of failing health. Alternatively, a person who saves $800 a year to self-insure would still end up $25,000 ahead of the 30-year-oldâeven if they had to pay $2,000 out of their own pocket every five years for unexpected medical expenses. McAuley prophetically concludes that given this government's continued tinkering with health insurance:

Can you see a 30 year-old making a plan for the rest of his or her life based on a health policy? Health care policy changes with every change of Government and there are major health policy changes every few years anyway.
Don't we know it? He goes on:
So you have got to ask people, are they willing to be on the next 50 years?

Thus the rate at which premiums will increase under this schemeâthat is, at two per cent per yearâis not enough to encourage greater participation in private health insurance by younger and healthier people. McAuley's calculations have shown that younger people would be better off delaying participation in private health insurance until they are older despite the extra premium loading which they would be required to pay. Kenneth Davidson wrote in the Age on 18 May 1999:

Self insurance is still the best bet for those who do not want to queue in the public sector . . . a reasonably healthy young adult could put aside the premiums for two to three years (relying on Medicare in the interim), and save more than enough to cover the cost of private elective surgery and private hospital accommodation.

Perhaps we forget the financial impost younger people already experience. Generally, youth and good health is accompanied by significant financial costs. Those attending university will barely have repaid their HECS and university fees before they are required to contribute to private health insurance at age 30 in addition to paying the Medicare levy. These people are likely also to be in the early stages of mortgages and are likely to be facing the additional costs of raising a family.

The Age editorial of 18 March 1999 was headed `Tinkering at the edges on healthâlate joining penalties will not cure health insurance problems'. Lifetime Health Cover is in fact playing at the edges of health insurance. It is not a solution to the underlying issue, which is that most of the community, especially younger people, regard private health insurance as too expensive and unnecessary.

I mentioned earlier the comments of Russell Schneider of the Australian Health Insurance Association and the aim of attracting low risk, low utilisation insurees. However, the proposal is unlikely to persuade many young and healthy peopleâdisinclined as they are to join private health fundsâbut it will make access to health care more difficult for less wealthy older people who simply may not have been able to afford private health cover when they were younger. Let's face it, if such people miss the 12-month sunset time, private health insurance will continue to be out of their reach.

An important consequence of lifetime community rating or `the forgotten effect' raised by Professor Don Hindle of the School of Health Services Management at the University of New South Wales is that a matter of crucial importance is overlooked. He states:
If the risk profile of private insurers is improved (by reduction in the average age relative to no lifetime community rating) then the risk profile of the public insurer will deteriorate.
