Professor Hindle's comments strike at the heart of the legislation's fundamental weakness.

In its attempts to prop up the private health insurance industry, the government ploughs awayâdeliberately or not, consciously or unconsciouslyâon three courses. The first is that, if the high risk elderly people or those planning a family are discouraged from having private health insurance, they will need to be provided with care in the public sector. If one assumes that the overall level of care is unchanged, then the reduced utilisation experienced by the private insurance sector will be balanced by increased utilisation in the public sector. The private sector will be better off, at the expense of increased financial pressures on the public health care providers.

As the Consumers Health Forum submission to the 1997 Industry Commission noted on page 431, reduced premiums for younger consumers and an increase in the viability of the private health insurance industry `will do little to relieve pressure on the public system as it relies on reducing the risk pool of private health insurance'. And this is the crux of the matter: what of the public system?

One could argue that, if the costs to the public sector are increased because of a deterioration in its own risk profile, there should be a corresponding decline in private sector expenditure. Don Hindle thinks not. A more realistic scenario is that public hospital demands will increase but will not be matched by increased funding. Given this government's record of subsidising private health and reducing expenditure on public health, there will have to be further increases in efficiency and declining standards in public health. Private health insurance revenues will increase, and private care providers will maintain their revenues by providing services which would not have been affordable given the previous high risk profiles.

It has been estimated that every unit of care costs more when delivered by the private sector. For example, the admitted patient episode costs at least 20 per cent more for a privately insured patient in a private hospital than for a public patient in a public hospital. This is not so much a consequence of inherently greater needs for care or lower levels of efficiency but, rather, of care providers' pressure to increase their revenues in a world where the only significant constraint has been a fear of loss of private health insurance membership due to unacceptable increases in membership premiums.

One of the greatest disincentives to private health insurance is the cost and, of this, the gap between what insurers pay and doctors charge. Don Hindle and Ian McAuley argue that pressures on the public health care sector will increase under lifetime community rating and the majority of Australians who do not have health insurance will tend to lose. It is not only the loss of public funding, as Eva Cox put it recently:
Given the limited number of medicare specialists who serve both sectors, the more not-so-sick queue jumpers we have in the private sector, the longer will be the queues in the public sphere.

There lies another measure which needs urgent actionâthe number of specialists available to the health system in general. The government claims it wants to take pressure off the public hospital system. But what is the point, as Kenneth Davidson rightly asks, if that goal can be achieved only at the expense of creating a second-rate public health system and an inefficient US style private health system which is too expensive for the bulk of the population?

My fear is that the plethora of schemes to bribe, entice and now coerce people into private health insurance, coupled with the erosion of funding to public health, is the thin end of the wedge into dismantling Medicare as a universal system by introducing means testing for access or running down the public health system to the point where, as Kenneth Davidson puts it, `only the desperate and the impoverished would use it'. No doubt many people believe means testing of public hospital services is not an achievable goal in the near future. We heard the words `never, ever' associated with the possibility of implementing a GST. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs the federal member for McPherson, an electorate where one in every five persons is 65 years of age or over, I am well aware of the concerns of older Australians, particularly in the area of health. This is why I was very keen to speak on the government's National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 and the benefits it will have for people in the McPherson electorate and, indeed, in Australia. From the volume of feedback I have received from my constituents, both in writing and on the telephone, it is clear the right messages are being conveyed to all Australiansâthe messages that the government is committed to getting the private health insurance industry back on its feet and that the government is determined to arrest the decline in private health insurance membership and ease the burden on public health.

speech.para: Lifetime Health Cover will end the unfairness of the current system and put in its place a new, workable solution. Under this scheme, registered health funds will be able to set different premiums so that people entering insurance at an early age pay a lower premium throughout their lives relative to those people who join later. It will reward those who take out hospital cover early in life and maintain this cover throughout their life. It encourages Australians under 30 to take on the responsibility of health insurance for life. It is important that younger Australians recognise that health services are expensive but that if they join a health fund early they will not be penalised in the future.

Furthermore, this new approach to private health insurance will provide benefits for older Australians. The scheme is particularly geared to assisting the elderly. No-one aged 65 or over as at 1 July 1999 will pay a higher premium. Those who already have private health insurance will always have the lowest lifetime rating. In other words, they will pay the same rate as someone who joined at age 30. People in this age group will be able to take out hospital cover at any time in the future without paying a loading for joining later in life.

Older constituents in my electorate who have recently dropped private health insurance have told me that this new initiative is a huge incentive. Along with the 30 per cent rebate, many have told me that they will rejoin their private health insurance funds, satisfied that the government is doing what it can to make private health insurance affordable. Those who so elect still have the choice of Medicare. The government is not abandoning Medicare nor taking money away from the public system to pay for the private system. Medicare remains a choice. In fact, the government has increased spending on the public hospital system by 17 per cent through the recently finalised health care agreements.

Another advantage for Australians across the boardâand one that particularly concerns thousands of young families in my electorateâis that Lifetime Health Cover will reward long-term members. People who pay health insurance over a long period will be rewarded for their membership loyalty. Currently, without Lifetime Health Cover, people who are long-term members of health funds are subsidising people who join only when they anticipate heavy hospital and medical expenses. This is grossly unfair and pushes up the price of private health insurance for all members.

Under this new approach, people who join after the age of 30 will pay a two per cent premium loading for each year they delay joining. The loading will be capped at a maximum of 70 per cent above the premium payable by a person who joins at age 30. Existing members of health funds who have hospital cover, no matter what their age, will be treated as if they joined a fund by the age of 30. Since I was elected in October last year I have had an increasing number of telephone calls and letters from constituents concerned about rising health insurance costs. In the past few years many have dropped out of their private health insurance funds because of escalating costs. Since the government's announcement of Lifetime Health Cover there has been a noticeable decline in such complaints. This is a positive sign that the government is listening and responding to people's needs.

Another advantage of Lifetime Health Cover is that it will discourage what is known as `hit and run' behaviourâthat is when somebody signs up temporarily to a health fund for costly surgery and then leaves the fund immediately after having the operation. On a broader scale, Lifetime Health Cover will stabilise membership numbers and improve the membership profile of health funds. It will also reduce premium increases in the future; this will put more money back into people's pockets, giving people more money for the important things in life such as family commitments and leisure.

The range of private health insurance reforms currently being implemented by the coalition government is designed to stabilise health insurance participation rates. We have known for some time that the private health insurance industry is under pressure. Since the introduction of Medicare in 1985 by Labor, the number of Australians with private health insurance has fallen from approximately 50 per cent to 30 per cent. This drop has created pressures on the industry and substantially increased Medicare costs for the government by increasing the number of public patients. It has also resulted in increases in premiums.

If the current system were to be maintained, the number of Australians with private health insurance would be likely to continue to drop. Increasing the number of public patients would create further pressures on the public health system and substantially increase costs for the government and, ultimately, the Australian taxpayer. Under the current system, in order to survive, health funds would have to continue to increase their premiums, thereby creating a vicious cycle of increasing costs and declining membership. Projections are that, under the current system, premiums would rise faster than they would under Lifetime Health Cover; after five years, the average contribution would be 15 per cent higher under the current system than it would be under Lifetime Health Cover.

The existing system of community rating was designed to ensure access to private health insurance for all members of the community, irrespective of their individual health risksâhowever, it has a number of major flaws. Over time, Lifetime Health Cover will make health insurance more affordable for all Australians, unlike the existing community rating system. While Lifetime Health Cover is a new scheme, it builds on the government's success in halting the health insurance membership decline which followed the introduction of the 30 per cent rebate; it is another government measure in a series of reforms to improve private health insurance. Other current measures include developing criteria for `no gap' and `known gap' policies and promotion of simplified billing.

In addition to Lifetime Health Cover having the support of the elderly in my electorate, it has been endorsed by industry and consumer groups Australia-wide. The model is supported by all key national groups, including the Consumers Health Forum, the Council on the Ageing and the Australian Consumers Association. Positive comments have been made by the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Catholic Health Care Association.

I thoroughly endorse the government's step to provide a grace period of 12 months to ensure that every Australian has the opportunity to take out hospital cover and lock in lower premiums. I would encourage other members of parliament to ensure that their constituents are aware of this grace period so that consumers do not miss out.

Recently, one of my constituents expressed a concern in the case of a person who becomes unemployed and cannot afford to maintain his or her membership. I endorse the move by the government to address such situations. Under Lifetime Health Cover, members may discontinue their private health insurance membership for a period of time for reasons of hardship. This reform allows people up to a total of 24 months absence during their lifetime without a loading being applied to their premium when they return to private health insurance.

In addition, the Lifetime Health Cover scheme will allow those with hospital cover to cease their cover for an aggregated period of 1,094 days without incurring any additional rise in contributions payable and to transfer from one health fund to another while retaining their Lifetime Health Cover entitlements. Lifetime Health Cover will stop hit and run membership. It will cut costs over time, reward long-term members and lead to the stabilising of private health insurance, taking direct pressure off public hospital waiting lists.

Lifetime Health Cover is a long-term measure. It is a reflection of the government wanting to make private health insurance more affordable for Australians now and into the future. It is a policy which will ensure the continuing stability of both the public and private health sectors. This new approach builds on the success of the government's 30 per cent rebate and demonstrates our commitment to long-term solutions, not just quick fixes. Lifetime Health Cover will slow down the rate of premium increases. It will halt the decrease in health insurance membership numbers. Lifetime Health Cover is to be commended to this House.

talk.start.para: âThe National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 is another attempt by the Howard government to address the health care needs of Australians by propping up an ailing private health insurance industry while starving the public health system and the states and territories of health dollars. This is the fourth rescue package that this government has introduced in an attempt to induce Australians to take out private health insurance. Each of these rescue packages has transferred health dollars to the private health insurance industry away from the public health system. Each package has been an abject failureâand I think we are going to be faced with another failure here. Every rescue package this government has introduced has been accompanied by a promise that it will increase the number of Australians taking out health insurance. Once again, this has been a failed promise.

speech.para: Initially, John Howard's government promised that changes it was making would lead to 45 per cent of Australian people taking out health insuranceâa far cry from what it is today, isn't it? So, if ever there was a failure, that was it. The proof is in the figures.

In 1996 this government introduced the means tested rebate. It said it was going to increase the number of people taking out private health insurance to 40 per cent. It did not deliver and failed again. It could not even meet its 40 per cent target. In 1998 we saw the initiative to beat all initiatives: the 30 per cent rebate. It cost $1.7 billion of taxpayers' money. It was supposed to increase the number of people taking out health insurance to 33 per cent initially. We have heard that it is going to hold the line. If you look at the number of people who took out health insurance as a result of this rebate costing $1.7 billion, you see that it cost $30,000 per personâ$30,000 of taxpayers' money per person was paid to insurance companies. Of the people who benefited from the rebate, 99 per cent were high income people who already had health insurance.

The real measure of just what a failure this rescue package is is the fact that premiums have increased. People were given a rebate of 30 per cent, health insurance was to be made more affordable, and the next thing we know is that premiums were increased. Medibank had the lowest increase, at 1.9 per cent; HCF had an eight per cent increase. The average increase across the industry was 4.9 per cent. This rescue package, which passed through this House in 1998 and came into effect at the beginning of this year, has failed. It has put $1.7 billion that could have gone into the public system into the insurance industry. It has done nothing whatsoever to help those Australians who need access to public hospitals, who need quality health care. It has failed.

What has this massive expenditure on health insurance done for Australians? Has it led to the building of more hospitals? No. Are more hospital beds available for people? No. Are there shorter waiting times available in hospitals? No. Is there a more efficient accident and emergency service? No. The answer to all these questions is no. Public hospitals are struggling with an increased demand for their services and fewer dollars, because this government is directing its dollars into insurance, not health care.

Coming from New South Wales and having been lucky enough to spend some time in the New South Wales parliament, I know how we struggled there with the cuts that this government made to the health budget of that state. I know how hard it was to stretch that dollar. I know how mean-spirited this government is and how it has lacked a commitment to the people of New South Wales and Australia as a whole.

Coming from the Hunter, I have a very high respect for the fine work done by the Hunter Area Health Service and the Central Coast Area Health Service. Belmont Hospital, within the electorate of Shortland, has been starved of funds over the last few years. This fine hospital has been in existence for 30 years. It is the centre of the community. The people who work in that hospital are committed to the public health care needs of the area. That hospital needs money to upgrade its obstetrics and gynaecological wards; it needs money for the accident and emergency area. The cuts that this government has forced on the states has made it harder and harder to deliver those things to the people of Shortland. Yet this government continues to make decisions to direct those health dollars to the health insurance industry rather than to public health.

If half of the money that went into the 30 per cent rebate had been put into public hospitals, it would have met all the health care needs of those in the public health system. The people of Belmont would have had the services and the upgrade that they need. But, no, instead $1.7 billion went into private health insurance. That money could have been used to treat 275,000 public patients. That did not happen because this government chose to spend that money on the health insurance industry rather than on health care.

This government has given greater financial commitment to propping up the health insurance industry than it has given to the primary production industry, which received only $823 million. Likewise, the manufacturing industry in this country received only $1.44 billion. It is absolutely unbelievable that a government can put money into insurance rather than into the delivery of services to the people of Australia.

What this government has demonstrated today is a piecemeal approach to public health, an approach based on health insurance, not provision of health services. The Howard government promised the Australian people that it would not destroy Medicare, yet every initiative it has taken has to some extent been an attack on Medicare and our public health systemâstarving it of funds and subsidising private health insuranceâand this will lead only to a second-rate public health system. I believe that is what those members on the other side of this House want. They want to downgrade the excellent public health system that we have here in Australia.

Most Western countries have strong public health systems supplemented by private health systemsâa smaller system which complements the public system. But this government has sought to change this mix. It is driven by its philosophical hatred of anything public. It hates public education just as much as it hates public health. The proof of that was in the budget that was delivered last month. Rather than having a private health system complementing a strong, healthy, well-resourced public system, this government is undermining our universal health system. What will this do? It will lead to the development of a two-tiered system and will force our public health system into poverty. It will operate as a poor second cousin.

The people of Shortland do not like this government's health priorities, just as they do not like the Howard-Democrat GST deal and its tax on health products. If there are two issues that constituents living within Shortland have contacted my electorate office about, it is this government's performance in the area of health and this government's performance in relation to the GST. The people of Shortland are opposed to this government's performance in both these areas and are opposed to its initiatives. The government should be ashamed of itself. It is an absolute disgrace. It is here to represent all Australians, not just its mates.

The Lifetime Health Cover legislation is yet another attempt to turn the tide to stop the exodus from the private health insurance industry. The first three rescue packages have not worked. Now we have mark 4. Once again, the government is investing in health insurance instead of health services. We on this side of the House have come to accept that that is the only way this government can think. It is impossible for it to make a commitment to people and a commitment to actually delivering health services.

The legislation, as I mentioned earlier, signals a move away from the principle of community rating. The government is introducing a new concept and a new approach to health insuranceâone that it has ignored to date and one that is a contrast to its subsidisation and rebates initiatives. This legislation will amend the National Health Act 1953 and allow the government to factor the age a person takes out health insurance into the insurance premium that a person pays. Let us not kid ourselves: it is an insurance premium. Just as you take out insurance on your house and your car, health insurance is insurance in that same way. It is a recognition that health insurance is just that. Age is a risk factor. Risk factors are written into health insurance policies just as they are written into the policy I take out on my motor vehicle because of the fact that I have a daughter who is aged 20.

The legislation enforces a two per cent loading for every year a person is over 30 when they take out health insurance to a maximum of 70 per cent loading, once again writing in a risk factor. If a person is now age 65, the loading does not apply. But I ask: what is a woman of pension age, which is 60, to do? Are they still going to be faced with having to pay that surcharge? This government has ignored the total impact this legislation will have on them. It is not a well thought through or well constructed piece of legislation. Sure, it has the goal of redistributing funds amongst people over the years, but the problem is that it is once again a piecemeal approach.

It does not look at anomalies. It is designed by the government looking at it from a government's point of view and from the point of view of its friends in the insurance industry. It does not look at it from the point of view of the individual, the consumer, the person who may be sick, the person who needs health careâyour mother, your father, your uncle, your aunt, your brother, your sister, your child. It does not look at that. It does not take into account all those little problems that can arise like records being lost and special, unique circumstances. Of course this does not surprise us. We are used to this government's tunnel vision approach to issues.

The other thing that is very frightening is the amount of money that will be sunk in advertising. We all saw how $7.5 million was put into advertising for the 30 per cent rebate initiative. And surprise, surprise! The ACCC found that that advertising was misleading. The government put $7.5 million into misleading advertising. This time it has allocated $10 million to sell its fourth rescue package. What worries me is that we will have a scare campaign and we will have pictures flashing on to our television sets scaring people into taking out this insurance.

This government will have an advertising campaign on our television sets which reflects the government's political objectives and along with that, as I said, the scare campaign. The day after this budget was introduced my office was inundated with telephone calls from older Australians who were terrified and who thought that they had to rush off that day and take out health insurance. I think the one part of this package that is most objectionable is the fear it has created for older Australians. A lot of people do not understand that they will have this exemption for being over 65 now. Once again, I caution the government and suggest that they look very closely at the situation of women receiving pensions.

We can only hope this initiative is more successful than the others. If it is successful, though, it will impact on the funding to states. If they get over 35 per cent membership in the funds, then the states will lose $200 million. Once again, it really makes you question what this government is about. I believe it is about putting money into private health insurance, moving away from its responsibility to the public system. The other issue that worries me is that they may start means testing patients who use public hospitals.

In today's Australian there was an interesting article that showed that extra hospital charges for privately insured surgery have really blown out. The government has failed to address that. The Newspoll published in today's Australian also showed that Australian people have no confidence or very little confidence in the government's commitment and ability to deliver in the area of health and Medicare. It showed that the Australian people believe that the Labor Party led by Mr Beazley can deliver in this area, not the government. People have experienced what the government has served to them for the last couple of years and they know that the government is just not up to standard.

Of the issues that were rated in the Newspoll survey, health rated second. When the performance of both the Labor Party and the coalition was compared, 38 per cent of Australians believe that the Labor Party was best able to handle and deliver the best health care to Australian people. Only 31 per cent thought that the coalition could. I wonder why. They have really been able to judge the government's performance and failures over the last four years. I think those people who were surveyed really believe that this government was not up to the grade. It could not deliver the goods, and it was just caught in an ideological time warp.

Everyone knows that Labor performs better in the area of health. The government promised not to dismantle Medicare. Yet all its efforts in the area of health have been designed to prop up an ailing private health system at the expense of the public system which has been starved of funds. While the dedication of professional staff in the Hunter and Central Coast area health services struggle with their budgets, this government is not accountable. This government continues to throw money into private health insurance whilst there is no money for new hospitals to treat Australians when they are sick. There is plenty of money for the health insurance industry. This government looks after its mates at the expense of ordinary Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI welcome the opportunity to speak on the National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 . I am extremely proud to be associated with the Howard led coalition government, particularly with regard to private health insurance. I am completely dumbfounded at the criticism levelled at our government by the opposition in terms of our attempts to arrest the decline in health insurance. It would only make sense to me that if health insurance is in decline a government would do something about it. I cannot believe that here today in this House we are being criticised for doing just thatâdoing something about it, attempting to arrest the decline in private health insurance, which has the potential to push further costs into the already stressed public health system.

speech.para: I also cannot believe that we would be accused of deliberately trying to establish a second rate health system in Australia. It is simply not backed up by fact. It is part of the hysterical rhetoric that goes on from oppositions who do not have a policy of their own and, rather than propose anything, merely attack and try to drag down what good government is doing in Australia. We know that the previous Labor government did nothing about the declining rates of private health insurance. We know they did nothing to try to arrest the decline. Yet the Labor Party comes into this House today and has the audacity to attack a government trying to do something about it.

This government has a realistic, practical and comprehensive plan to ease the burden on the public health system and entice people back into private health insurance. The member for Shortland described that as a piecemeal approach. That is absolute rot. What we see from the Howard led government is a strategic approach to ensure that people are encouraged to take out private health insurance. Far from being piecemeal, it is a carefully planned strategy which is working.

The government's national health amendment bill is only part of this plan and by itself addresses one of the main issues of private health insurance. Lifetime Health Cover rewards people who join private health insurance funds from a young age by charging a low premium if someone joins before the age of 30. This new lifetime community rating system will reward long-term members while discouraging and disadvantaging hit and run members who join to have surgical procedures done and then let their membership lapse afterwards.

This bill is aimed at improving the profile of the health insurance funds. That means getting more people into the funds, particularly young people. It takes into consideration the risk factor, as any commercial insurance scheme should, when people join funds late when the risks are high without having made any contribution at all in their younger years. The bill also allows for the transition period for people not yet members of the fund or for those who are already 30 years of age by allowing 12 months grace until 1 July 2000 for people to join and be treated as if they will be 30 forever.

In addition, Lifetime Health Cover takes into account those people who through changes in employment prospects or travel overseas can suspend their health insurance for up to 24 months, or longer if the fund decides on their discretion, without penalty on their return to private health insurance. Furthermore, people aged over 65 at the end of the grace period of 1 July 2000 will only ever pay the price of a 30-year-old to join a private health insurance fund.

I completely refute the suggestion that is made that we are simply trying to accommodate the middle class of Australia. As the Prime Minister said in this House on 23 November in an answer to a question from me, there are no fewer than 700,000 Australians earning less than $20,000 a year in private health insurance. Those 700,000 people are now benefiting from the initiative that the Howard government has already introduced in terms of the 30 per cent rebate, and we want to ensure that more people in that income bracket and in fact in all income brackets are enticed back into private health insurance.

Lifetime cover, however, is not expected to work on its own. There have, as I have already mentioned, been a number of responsible and practical initiatives introduced by the Howard government related to health insuranceâthe most significant being the 30 per cent rebate. The federal government's 30 per cent private health insurance rebate is yet another detailed scheme which is enticing people back into private health insurance. In my electorate of Groom, at the end of last year, figures showed 45,000 people were covered by private health insurance, almost 40 per cent of the total population of 117,220. That information is from the latest 1996 census. These are people who want a choice in hospital and health care, the same people who do not want to wait to get that hospital care. They want to have the type of treatment they want when they want it.

By way of example, if we look at the admissions into Toowoomba's biggest private hospital, St Vincent's, 95.4 per cent were covered by private health insurance, with more than half of those holding top cover. Not only do these people need to be kept in the health insurance system but we need to get more uninsured people into the system as well. This means the government must provide incentives to insure. That is the role of government. When the system breaks down, the government must step in to address a market failure. That is the basis for the 30 per cent rebate, and the 30 per cent rebate has been well received. It represents an incentive greater than a full tax deductibility of health insurance costs for the majority of taxpayers in Australia. It is having a real and positive effect on the number of people who have taken out health insurance since its introduction.

I have spoken to a number of insurance providers over the last few months at length. One of those insurance providers on the Darling Downs was Wideland Insurance Brokers, which I know well from a previous life, and they assured me that the government's 30 per cent health rebate is the best thing they have ever seen to entice people back into private health insurance. Ninety-five per cent of the inquiries to Wideland offices in Toowoomba are about private health insurance, and these inquiries came immediately following the announcement of the 30 per cent rebate and its introduction in January. To go further afield, I refer to the report by Salmon, Smith and Barney, the leading broker of Australian health care stocks. They have stated categorically that over 57,000 new people joined health insurance funds in the March quarter in 1999. That is the largest increase this decade.

Leading brokers are also predicting that the private health fund industry will improve its profitability. Profitability, for the benefit of some on the other side, equals sustainability for health funds which were obviously starting to face difficulties. I know members opposite do not support private health insurance and prefer instead to place an extra burden on the already strained public hospital system. In fact, the previous Labor Prime Minister, Paul Keating, went on the public record to that effect.

Private health insurance pays billions of dollars a year from the private purse into the cost of health care and hospitalisation in Australia. MBF alone paid more than $600 million in benefits to hospitals in the year 1998. This amount of money is a very real and significant saving to the government and is money which would otherwise need to be paid by the government to the public health care system. The more we, the government, can do to encourage people to pay their own health care costs, the less the taxpayers of Australia are called on to meet these costs. Consequently, this means lower taxesâyes, lower taxesâsuch as we are seeing in the ANTS tax package and more money available to the federal government to spend on educational services, other community issues and public health. As the member for McPherson quite correctly stated, that is a 15 per cent increase. For members opposite to belittle and disparage the government's real and proven effort to ease the burden on the public health system illustrates only their own lack of understanding on this issue and their inaction and lack of commitment on the issue during their 13 years of government.

Private health insurance and private hospitals play a vital part in Australia's health system and deserve the continuing support of this federal government, and they will get it. In my electorate, the two major hospitals are St Vincent's and St Andrew's. Over the last 12 months, these two hospitals admitted 29,000 patients and saved the public hospital system in excess of $53 million. That is $53 million in my electorate in two hospitals alone. This is not an issue about insurance versus health care; this is an issue about relieving the burden on the taxpayer of health care in Australia. Despite the gains we are making in private health insurance and the vital role of private hospitals in the nation's health care, all is not rosy in private hospitals.

To be more specific, these private health insurance funds are at times dictating irrational prices to private hospitals for patient care, the effect being that at times the prices paid to hospitals by health insurance funds do not meet the actual real cost of patient care. While I realise the necessity of keeping health insurance premiums as low as possible in order to increase the uptake of private health insurance and thus decrease the burden on the public health system, private hospitals in my electorate are facing serious difficulties.

In the year 2000-01, private hospitals will be in their fourth year of marginal decline. This means that right now, unless something is done to remedy the situation, Australian private hospitals face an inevitable collapse in investor confidence. Moreover, some private hospitalsâin fact 25 in the last 12 monthsâhave caved in under the burden placed on them and closed their doors. This issue of static or declining payments from health insurance funds is very much a contributing factor to this degeneration.

While the bigger private hospitals in my electorate of Groom such as St Vincent's and St Andrew's are surviving, if only just, the smaller ones in towns such as Pittsworth, Clifton and Crows Nest on the edge of my electorate are facing severe financial difficulty. These smaller hospitals belong to and are part of their community. They are operated by their community and respond to their community's needs. These hospitals are part of the community's fabric and, unless action is taken, their disappearance will contribute to the disintegration of communities throughout regional Australia.

I said earlier that the health funds were squeezing private hospitals. In fact, while health funds are in some cases not allowing the two larger hospitals in Toowoomba a fair return on their investment by lowering in real terms the benefit paid for the medical services at these hospitals, the situation in these three smaller hospitals is far worse. In fact, the health funds, for some unknown reason, are paying these smaller hospitals even less for the same services than they are paying the larger hospitals in Toowoomba and metropolitan areas in Australia. This is simply intolerable and, unless changed, will wipe out small private hospitals in our country towns.

While I have grave concerns for the small private hospitals in my electorate, I also have concerns about our ability to ensure that doctors come to stay in these small rural communities. Clifton, a town in my electorate some 40-odd kilometres south of Toowoomba, came to national prominence last year through its difficulty in securing the services of a GP. While a doctor has been secured for Clifton, at least for the time being, the problem highlighted for this community still exists in many parts of regional Australia.

It is not surprising, therefore, that the federal government has done something about it in the last 12 months. On this issue, as with many of the issues affecting rural and regional Australia, the federal government has implemented a number of initiatives to address the problem. I remind the House that, in the 1999-2000 federal budget, some of the initiatives announced by the government included a $43 million program of retention grants to assist doctors to stay longer in rural communities. We also supported a new medical school in North Queensland and established a clinical school in Wagga Wagga in New South Wales as a means of exposing medical students to rural practices and hopefully getting them used to the idea of working in the bush. We have also funded extra training, counselling and support services for rural doctors to help them deal with the isolation that sometimes comes with a rural practice.

The federal government is committed to improving health care not only in rural and regional Australia but for the whole of Australia. Fundamental to this improvement is to ease the burden on the public health system by encouraging more Australians to insure with health funds. This bill is another successful long-term measure, no doubt, which demonstrates even further that this government does have the policies to address the issues relating to health and to private health insurance. It is also further graphic evidence of our commitment to a private health insurance industry in Australia.

I cannot believe that Labor is yet to understand the correlation between private health insurance and the saving that it places on the public health system. I repeat: $53 million was saved to the public health system in my electorate in two hospitals alone. The Lifetime Health Cover initiative, combined with the 30 per cent insurance rebate and other initiatives, should be applauded by all members of parliament as a meaningful response to this important issue. I commend this legislation to the House and call for its unanimous support.

talk.start.para: âThere is nothing more frustrating than a government which refuses to deal in the facts. The truth in the health sector in Australia is there is no crisis in private health insurance. There is absolutely no crisis in this sector. This is a government which has based its policies on propaganda about a crisis, yet this assertion is never proven, it is just repeated. This is an attempt by the government to argue via repetition and argue via propaganda.

speech.para: It has never been proven for a single moment that there is a crisis in the private health sector. In fact, this has been asserted so many times and adopted so frequently by the government that it has reached the proportion of urban myth. On this side of the parliament at least there is attention to detail and some concern for the facts, so let me give the House this statistic.
Mr Truss interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is a pretty good place to start on any matter, including private health insurance. So the member for Wide Bay, having got the reference right, might now like to consider the facts. Fifteen years ago, for every $10 of expenditure on health care in Australia, private health insurance contributed $1. So it paid $1 in every $10 spent on health care in this country. The figure today is about the same. There has been no change in the proportion of health funding contributed by private health insurance in this country. So there is no crisis on the available data, on the available facts. Nothing has changed in the relative funding share between the public and private sectors since the introduction of Medicare.

speech.para: Medicare was introduced in 1984 and private health insurance was contributing $1 for every $10 of total health expenditure in Australia. The recent figures show the number has not changed. So where is the crisis? Private health insurance is doing exactly the same job as it did 15 years ago when Medicare was introduced. It is treating the same number of patients as a proportion and contributing the same amount of finance as a proportion, yet this government says there is a crisis. That is not a crisis. That is the status quo. That is the equilibrium in the health sector.

So the government is not able to prove its assertion, its piece of propaganda, that there is some crisis in private health insurance. All that has happened is that people who have not been using the health system have decided to drop their health insurance. And why wouldn't they? Who here in this parliament would keep up their insurance if they had a low risk of using it? What sort of blind consumer are you to put your hand up on that? Do you think if you are not at risk of using a service you should pay out for insurance? No wonder the economy has got record foreign debt and a record current account deficit. These are the economic numbskulls who are running the Australian economy. They have got no risk of using a service but they are willing to dole out the insurance money for that service.

talk.start.para: âStick to the facts.

âThe facts are pretty simple, and it is a clear argument. But on your side you are saying that anyone who has no or low risk of using a service should dole out for the insurance regardless. That is not a sensible argument, and it is certainly not an argument that has been supported by the average health consumer in Australia because those Australians who have not been using health services have decided to drop their health insurance, and this is a simple calculation on value for money. Younger, healthier people who have not been using the health system have decided they have no or little need for health insurance. It is totally wrong to say that these people have flooded out of private hospitals and into the public sector. They have not been using hospitals at all.

speech.para: If you look at the statistics in the health sector, you will see that 60- to 70-year-old Australians have got the same proportion of private health insurance as they have always had. So those Australians who are at risk of needing health services and see the need for health insurance, because they use the system, have kept their membership up. So where is the crisis? Private health insurance contributes the same proportion to health services in Australia; the same proportion of 60- to 70-year-olds are in the funds. There is no crisis. All there is is a market at work. Why would the coalitionâthe party of Menzies, the party of free enterprise, the party of market forcesâthink that a market that is sorting itself out is a market in crisis? Because they have no true understanding of good health policy.

The health funds in this country maintain a strong core of older Australians in their membership; their reserves and their profits are okay. Who in this parliament can point to a private health fund that has run into a financial problem? There has been no problem. For all the protests and doorstops outside this building by Russell Schneider and his colleagues, none of the funds and none of the members opposite can point out a fund that has run into financial trouble. So there has been no crisis.
Mr Bartlett interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThere is the same proportion of total health expenditure from the health insurance funds, a solid number of 60- to 70-year-old Australians are in funds, the funds' reserves are okay and their profit levels are okay. There has been no financial crisis in any of these funds; there is no crisis overall.

speech.para: The member for Macquarie is badgering on over there. He should stand up and quote, when he speaks after me, the statistics that point to a crisis. All that has happened is that membership in the funds has fallen; their net contribution to the health system in Australia has not altered. That, my friend, does not constitute a crisis and, most of all, it does not constitute the need for public subsidisation of this industry. Size is not all that important when it comes to the private funds. The thing that matters is their contribution to health services, and that has not altered since the introduction of Medicare in 1984.

Out of this, it is totally unnecessary for this government to introduce a 30 per cent tax rebate on fund membership. It is an unnecessary subsidisation of a private sector market and this, of course, represents money that is being dragged away from the real point of need and the real point of overload in health service use: the public hospital system.

This is not a market that needs public subsidisation. It is a market that needs to do nothing more than to operate like a market. Again I ask the coalition: for all its rhetoric about free enterprise and market forces, why doesn't it allow private health insurance in Australia to operate like a market and clear itself on the basis of a proper relationship between price and costâthat is, a proper health insurance market that works on the principle that someone at greater risk of need pays a higher premium and someone at lower risk pays a lower premium? That is just a simple principle of market insuranceâthe same principle that we use for car insurance and home insurance. Why should the health sector be any different?

The government has maintained a policy of community rating, whereby all Australians pay the same premium irrespective of age and health risk. In a proper insurance market, if you have lower risk of using the services, you pay a lower premium. If you have a higher risk, you pay a higher premium. Until the Howard government adopts that fundamental principle in health policy, it will be running on the basis of urban myth rather than on the basis of facts and good health policy making. The simple truth is that younger people refuse to pay a premium beyond their health risk; and why should they? Why should someone who feels that they have low need for a service, they have low risk of health care, pay private health insurance? They are not willing to flush their money down the drain on the basis of an absurd assessment of the private health insurance market. They are making value for money decisions as health consumers. Why would anyone in this parliament think that is a bad thing? Why would you think it is a bad thing for Australian consumers to make a decision that, if the value for money is not there in private health insurance, they should not pay it. That is the decision they are making; that is the judgment they are making. We do not say in the car insurance or home insurance markets that you have to have community rating and if you have a low risk of using the service you have got to pay the same premium as those with a high risk of using the service.

This legislation is a step in the right direction. It is a belated recognition by the Howard government of some of the principles I have been putting in this debate. This legislation links premium levels to the age at which people take up their fund membership. This legislation and this principle are supported by the Labor opposition, and why wouldn't it be? The truth is that community rating was never part of the thinking behind Medibank, nor was it part of the thinking behind Medicare.

I think one piece of information needs to be placed on the Hansard record, and that is a quote from Dick Scotton's book, The Making of Medibank, page 274, where he sets out the relationship between public health insurance in this country and the community rating system that has persevered ever since. Scotton writes as follows:

A third unresolved issue is the appropriate role, structure and regulatory framework of private insurance in the context of a universal public program. In a voluntary private insurance scheme, the necessary cross-subsidies between good and bad risks can only be effected by public subsidies, distortion of the premium structure, and regulatory controls. A large part of the original rationale for Medibank was that these interventions were not only unsuccessful in achieving equity objectives but also resulted in inefficiencies in health insurance operations and health service provision.

What a wonderful piece of foresight for Dick Scotton, back in the early seventies, putting together the principles of Medibank, to say that if you have this cross-subsidy between good and bad health risks the only way you can get out of it in public policy is by huge public subsidies or you end up with a distortion of the premium structure.

That, of course, is what has come to pass, and it is quite a shame that it has taken almost 30 years for this parliament to recognise the wisdom and the foresight that Dick Scotton had in the early seventies in putting together the original Medibank scheme. Scotton continues in The Making of Medibank:

When a universal public program takes over the social function of effecting transfers between different risk groups, private insurance contracts to a supplementary role in which the need for subsidisation, community rating and anti-competitive regulation is greatly weakened.

Hear, hear to that! That is what we are now seeing in this legislation at long last. There is less need for community rating and less need for subsidisation if a universal public program is introduced and takes up the slack, takes up the tension, in the distribution of health risks. That is the true role of public health insurance. It is the effective community `rater' in our system. It takes up the tension between different risk groups and it makes unnecessary community rating and the sort of public subsidisation that these fools opposite have been ploughing unnecessarily into the private funds. Scotton continues:
In the second half of 1973, Deeble and Scotton examined criteria which should govern the operation of private health insurance in its new function of providing supplementary benefits to Medibank.
One of their proposals was:

. . . a modified form of community rating on basic tables under which the premium paid by an insured personâas in life insuranceâwould be based on age of entry and maintained at the same level (as a proportion of the premium charged to a good-risk entrant) for as long as the contributor remained insured.

Doesn't that sound familiar 30 years later? That is the principle we are legislating in this parliament tonight: the idea that the premium level is based on age at entry and maintained at the same level for as long as the contributor remained insured. What a shame it has taken three decades for this parliament to come to its senses and legislate, and hopefully enact, the original principle put together by Deeble and Scotton. Scotton goes on:

Contributors carried over from the voluntary insurance scheme would be enrolled in the new table at a "good-risk" rate, and special actuarial reserves to cover the transitional underpricing of high-risk contributors would be created by transfers from the existing reserves, which were far in excess of their post-implementation requirements.
What seemed to be an elegant prescription for the regulatory framework of private insurance in the context of a universal Medibank program did not fit in with departmental thinking of the time.

I can see departmental advisers sitting over there. I am glad their thinking has changed, because their predecessors 30 years ago were part of the obstruction that stopped the implementation of the proposition by Deeble and Scotton. Not only was there departmental obstruction, which the Whitlam government had too much to bear, but naturally enoughâthis is no great surpriseâit was held up in the Senate. For those opposite to ever complain about the Senate, look at the way in which you butchered the program and propositions of the Whitlam government. It became apparent in mid-1974 that no further Medibank legislation would be passed in the Senate. The whole thing was forgotten until this legislation came before the House tonight.

As a bit of a reconstructed `Whitlamite', holding the seat once held by the great man, I am particularly delighted to see that good public policy always pushes through and always perseveres and gets through in the end, even if in this case it has taken 25 to 30 years. So we are all learning from Deeble and Scottonâthe holy writ; the good word on health policyâ30 years later, even the member for Macquarie, who looks like he is coming to his senses, joined by the member for Gilmore and, of course, my good colleague and friend the member for Banks.

talk.start.para: âHear, hear!

âOn the subject of learning from these things, I noted a contribution by the member for Jagajaga on 9 March. She said, `Community rating of course is at the heart of Medicare.' My proposition is this: private health insurance needs to operate like any other insurance market: according to the rules of risk and competitive pricing. It should not be weighed down by excessive government regulation or propped up by huge public subsidies. Until this happens, there will always be pressure on the federal government to compensate health funds for their inability to attract younger members. The best way to support Medicare and the public hospital system is to support the phasing out of community rating. Again, I say this is a useful first step, but it should not be the only step.

speech.para: The best way to subsidise the health care of the elderly is through Medicare. Australia has thousands of aged pensioners on waiting lists for important surgery in our public hospitals. It is a national disgrace that they are not being treated. The federal government needs to redirect its $1.5 billion rebate to where it is needed most: the public health needs of older Australians in public hospitals. Why go all the way round the world with this absurd argument that if you put the money into private health insurance that takes the pressure off public hospitals and all of a sudden things are better when you can just put the money directly where the problem is? If there is a problem in the public hospital system, pour the $1.5 billion in direct. Do not pass go; go straight to the problem. That would be the sensible way to approach this in public policy, but regrettably it is not the way of the Howard government. They are not following the third way.

talk.start.para: âBut they are looking after their mates.

âThe federal government needs to put its money into public hospitals directly. Australia now has the worst of both worlds in our health system. We have an underfunded public hospital system plus a grossly inefficient private insurance market. Both problems could be fixed overnight, but political misjudgment and vested interests keep getting in the way. The member for Banks was pretty close to the mark earlier on when he spoke about this government looking after its matesânot just in concrete but also in private health insurance. It is across the board in all sectors in all parts of the country.

speech.para: This problem that we have in Australia with health policy is a bit like Australia's chronic unemployment problem: we live with it by choice, not because the solutions are unavailable to government. The solutions are there. A lot of them are in the words of Deeble and Scotton back in the early 1970s. It is long overdue for this parliament to pass those measures that were originally frustrated by woolly thinking in the department and mindless obstruction in the Senate. But better late than never. As I mentioned earlier on, good public policy always pushes its way through and gets there in the end, and I am glad to see a bit of it tonight.

talk.start.para: âThis National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 is another important step in strengthening the nation's health system. It helps improve the viability of both private health insurance and the public system. This approach stands in sharp contrast to the narrow ideologically driven focus of Labor. The coalition's approach offers choice to consumers and ensures the maintenance of a quality dual health system. It recognises the essential link between the private and public health systems, a point that Labor seems to want to overlook.

speech.para: Lifetime Health Cover is a response to an Industry Commission recommendation arising from its 1997 inquiry into private health insurance. It enhances and strengthens a nation's health system in three key ways. Firstly, it strengthens the private health sector by encouraging people to join at a younger age and by discouraging hit-and-run approaches to private health cover. If the age and health profiles of fund membership reflected that of the population generally, this measure would not be necessary.

However, a reluctance of young healthy people to join, an ageing membership profile and hit-and-run membership by the relatively healthy have created financial difficulties for health insurance funds. The necessary response over the years has been to raise premiums, thus further discouraging membership by the young and healthy and thus exacerbating the problem. By providing an incentive for younger membership, the pressure on premiums is reduced and private health insurance remains more attractive. Along with the 30 per cent rebate which commenced in January this year, this measure will stem the decline in private health cover and improve its viability.

This is a valuable equity measure. It rewards those who have been members for a long period of timeâthose who have been members throughout their lives. It penalises those who exploit health fund membership by joining only when their perceived need for health care is great, thereby shifting the burden to others. Lifetime Health Cover will operate on a threshold age of 30. Anyone joining at 30 or younger will pay the minimum base rate premium. Those joining later will pay a two per cent loading for every year they delay joining. The maximum loading will be 70 per cent above the base rate. Further measures to enhance the fairness of this initiative include a 12-month period of grace from 1 July 1999 to allow non-members to join and to receive the same benefits as existing members. It is a provision that allows anyone aged 65 at that date to pay the same premium as a 30-year-old. This is an import ant measure to protected the aged who wish to have private health cover, as many do.

The bill allows all existing members of private health funds with hospital cover to be treated as though they had joined at age 30, regardless of their current age. Further, it allows a 24-month absence from private health insurance without requiring a loading upon returning to membership. This provides some protection for people forced to discontinue due to short-term financial hardship or other factors.

In strengthening the private health system, the government is also indirectly strengthening the public system. Despite the comments of the member for Werriwa, let it be clear that a viable quality public health system requires a private health counterpart where those who can afford it and choose to can take care of their own health costs. This is a point that Labor seems incapable of grasping. It is crucial that the decline in private health insurance that has occurred over the last 15 years is reversed. For every one per cent decline in private health membership, $100 million a year is added to the cost of running the public hospital system.

Since 1983 private health insurance has dropped from 63 per cent to 32 per cent. This is stark evidence of Labor's incompetence. The decline from 63 per cent to 32 per cent during Labor's 13 years has added $3.1 billion a year to the cost of the public health system. Labor's incompetence has added $3.1 billion a year to the cost of running the public health system. That is $3.1 billion a year extra that needs to be found by taxpayers, without even addressing the extra demands of an ageing population or of rising medical costs.

If this decline had been brought about through neglect, through misinformation or through ignorance, it would have been bad enough, but that such decline was a deliberate policy of sabotage by Labor is culpable. In its early years, Labor worked deliberately to undermine the private health system. It removed tax deductibility for health insurance premiums. It withdrew the bed-day subsidy and it ceased its contribution to the re-insurance pool. These measures added to the costs facing private health insurers and the insured and thereby reduced the attractiveness to members by forcing premiums to rise. The resulting decline in membership may have heartened Labor's left-wing ideologues, but it left our health system in a state of extreme vulnerability that Labor seems to take delight in. By contrast, this government has undertaken a number of critical initiatives to address Labor's failures and to strengthen the public health system by strengthening the private health system at the same time.

Lifetime Health Cover is an important part of this process. This initiative has been supported by a number of people, including the Council on the Ageing and the Consumers Health Forum of Australia. It has also been supported by a number of independent commentators. Let me quote this comment from the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald three days after the budget:
Lifetime health cover, perhaps the most radical goal announced in this week's Federal Budget, may be the key to guaranteeing the future of Australia's health system.
It is the key to guaranteeing the future of Australia's health system. It continues:

A radical policy measure to increase the flow of premiums to private health insurers is not for the insurers' benefit in isolation because it is for the benefit of the system as a whole to have a strong private health insurance component.
It is to the benefit of the health system as a whole. The editorial continues:
This Government's bold measures to broaden the case base underpinning a reliable and comprehensive medical and hospital service are commendable.
The Herald Sun on 29 May said this:
The Federal Health Budget also contains comprehensive, practical and far-sighted solutions to problems in health that previous governments have ignored or dismissed as "too hard".
Previous governments have ignored or dismissed them as too hard. That sounds like Labor's approach to so many difficult policy issues. The President of the AMA, David Brand, said this:

Overall the Government has shown a solid and commendable commitment to health. The introduction of life time health cover, combined with the 30% rebate, means that there has never been a better time for Australians to take out private health insurance. The initiative should provide better products for patients, rewarding long term membership and providing cheaper premiums for younger members.
He went on to say:
The Government also deserves praise for its commitment to medical research, general practice, indigenous health, hepatitis C initiative, youth health and aged care.
It's also good to see funding for the AMA proposed rural scholarship scheme . . . This has the potential to form the basis of a long term solution to the problem of rural doctor shortages.

Not only is the coalition government working to address the problems of declining private health membership and to strengthen indirectly the public system; it is also putting in place other very positive initiatives to address shortcomings in the health system.

It is worth while in this context outlining some of the coalition's other quality initiatives in the area of health. Already over the past three years it has done many things. It has increased total health spending by $3.6 billion per year since the three years it has come in. That is, last year it spent $3.6 billion more than Labor did in its last year, including an extra $620 million for public hospitals. That is, last year, it spent $620 million more for public hospitals than Labor did in 1996.

It has signed a new five-year Medicare agreement with the state governments, which increases their funding in real terms by 17.6 per cent over the next five years. It has increased public hospital spending by nine per cent alone in this current financial year. There is also the introduction of a 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance from January this year. This provided a tremendous relief for all private health insurance members, including 33,000 members in the electorate of Macquarie.

The government has committed $500 million extra for mental health. It has allocated an extra $750 million for veteran health care over the next five years, including an extension of the gold card to an extra 50,000 veterans. It has introduced free flu vaccines for the over 65s and extended the seniors health card to another 220,000 senior citizens. These runs are already on the board in terms of this government's commitment to health.

In the current budget for the year 1999-2020 which was brought down last month, the coalition continued its commitment to health. It has committed an extra $614 million over the next six years for health and medical research. It has allocated funding for measures worth $228 million to improve the delivery of primary health care services to Australians, focusing especially on prevention and on providing an integrated approach to health care for the aged. It has committed extra funding to improve health services in rural and regional Australia. There is an extra $79 million over four years to improve indigenous health care; an extra $221 million over four years to increase the fight against drugs; an extra $210 million to improve hearing services for the aged and children; and extra funding for hepatitis C and breast cancer care.

The coalition government is also working on measures to address the gap. It is working to address this by encouraging negotiations between doctors, hospitals and health funds to develop no-gap and known-gap products. It is also working to introduce simplified billing.

Over the past three years, the coalition government has undertaken many initiatives aimed at improving our health system. Lifetime Health Cover is another important contribution to this. As evidenced by this program and many other initiatives over the last three years, the coalition has shown its determination to find solutions to our health problems which will allow choice, will strengthen our health system and will work. I commend this bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Melham) adjourned.

debate.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak about same sex relationships. There are a number of instances recently where the issue of same sex relationships has arisen. Firstâand it is a pleasurable taskâI congratulate the New South Wales government on their recognition of same sex partnerships. In legislation passed in May, the New South Wales government passed the Property Relationships Legislation Amendment Bill. What was particularly interesting about the passing of this legislation was that it received bipartisan support in the New South Wales parliament. The only people who opposed this legislation in the Legislative Council were Fred Nile, David Oldfield and John Tingle. I am pleased to note that both the Labor government and the coalition opposition supported the legislation.

speech.para: New South Wales is not the only state that recognises same sex relationships. There has been a recognition of same sex relationships in the ACT since 1994 when the ACT passed the Domestic Relationships Act, which provided a system for the division of property and the payment of maintenance when a same sex relationship breaks down.

In 1996 the Liberal ACT government amended the Administration and Probate Act 1929 and the Family Provision Act 1969 to provide access to inheritance for de facto partners. These amendmentsâwhich had bipartisan supportâput same sex and heterosexual de factos on the same footing by defining a spouse as a partner, whether or not of the same gender. In 1997 in Victoria the Kennett government passed changes to the Wills Act 1997 to allow family provision orders to be made for the proper maintenance and support of any person for whom the deceased had responsibility to make provision. The focus of this change is to ensure that the legislation operates in a way which is tied to its purpose and leaves out irrelevant factors such as the gender and marital status of the applicant. The Queensland government is also considering moves in this direction. An industrial relations bill introduced by the Queensland government last week proposes to recognise same sex relationships under state industrial relations law.

This is particularly significant at this time. Just last week we had a report entitled `Superannuation Entitlements of Same Sex Couples' from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Human Rights Commissioner Chris Sidoti recommended:
. . . that the legislation be amended to allow surviving same-sex partners to benefit in Commonwealth superannuation schemes.
He says in that report:

. . . in denying to surviving same-sex partners of superannuation fund members an entitlement to benefit [the relevant Acts] contravene the prohibitions on sexual preference discrimination in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Labour Organisation's Discrimination (Employment and Occupation) Convention (ILO 111) both of which are scheduled to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 .

This is a very significant report because it recognises the terrible injustice and difficulties that people such as Greg Brown have experienced when attempting to access the superannuation benefits of a partner that they have lost. At a time when those people should be able to grieve undisturbed, they are having to worry not just about money but in many cases about actually fighting legal battles as well. The Body Shop and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants are among the many organisations which have recognised the inequity of the superannuation legislation as it now stands.

These measures will increase the pressure on this government to pass Mr Albanese's private member's bill, the Superannuation (Entitlements of Same Sex Couples) Bill 1998 . That bill does not provide for special rights for gay and lesbian couples. It provides universal rights, equal rights, for those people. I urge all members to support that legislation when it next comes before the House.

talk.start.para: âTonight I want to talk about an educational centre in my electorate which has successfully implemented a Work for the Dole initiative committed to giving young men and women a fair go at employment. This program, which is run at Kings Christian Centre at Reedy Creek, has provided an opportunity for participants to develop their work ethic while putting something back into their community. It has given them the chance to take on new challenges and responsibilities.

speech.para: More than 50 young people completed the Kings community service project recently. It was my pleasure to present certificates to the participants and to meet with the unemployed youth, employers and supervisors who contributed to the success of the quality program. I found it immensely enriching to see the feelings of worth, fulfilment and achievement which resulted from this partnership between the government, Kings Christian Centre, employers and the community. It was rewarding to see young people so proud of their achievements and their contribution to community projects.

Participants were involved in broad based activities in areas such as office administration, hospitality services, extensive construction and horticultural works. There have also been projects in landcare management, working for the elderly, gardening and refurbishing, rebuilding and retailing. Participants undertook certified courses in senior first aid and security loss prevention as well as fire emergency response training. The majority of the 50 participants committed to the six-month program are now in paid employment. This is an outstanding result, in part thanks to the commitment and dedication of a team of caring people at Kings Christian Centre, which also offers King's Job Network Service matching job seekers and employers and a program for job seekers who have literacy and numeracy barriers to employment.

I congratulate centre director, Stirling Donaldson and project manager, Robert Mulligan, who have provided a catalyst for these young people to find employment. They have boosted the self-esteem and motivation of many unemployed youths and have provided them with the skills, knowledge and attitudes required to assist them in gaining full-time, long-term employment. After the ceremony I chatted with a number of the participants, including 24-year-old Peter, who had been unemployed for more than six months. Peter told me that the program had provided him with valuable work skills and enabled him to secure a job in the boat building industry. Additional training in security greatly increased his confidence with skills appropriate in any workplace.
I would like to share with you some comments made by the centre's director, Stirling Donaldson, who said during the graduation:

I wish to congratulate the coalition government in its success in substantially reducing unemployment. I believe it is through projects such as Work for the Dole, Literacy and Numeracy, and the Job Network, that we are seeing this tremendous reduction in unemployment.

Nationwide, the Work for the Dole program has benefited thousands of young people. Already more than 20,000 participants have commenced work in nearly 500 projects to gain valuable work experience. In contrast to Labor's culture of welfare, the coalition government is creating a culture of work. Work for the Dole and mutual obligation are important components of the government's employment strategy.

In his announcement recently of an extension of the program's initiatives, the Minister for Employment Services said that to date more than 40 per cent of participants have been in paid employment or further education and training within three months of leaving the program. Eighty-five per cent of participants say that this government initiative has strengthened their determination to find work. A recent Morgan and Banks survey showed that 83 per cent of employers believe that Work for the Dole improves young people's permanent job prospects. In a survey undertaken in my electorate, Work for the Dole rated very highly as a positive government initiative worthy of support, and I endorse these comments.

I am delighted that in my electorate the federal government is working with seven Work for the Dole providers to boost work opportunities for young peopleâthe Gold Coast Skill Centre, the Wheelchair and Disabled Association, Mission Australia, the Southern Gold Coast Chamber of Commerce, Phantast Cultural Music and Arts Association, Numinbah Valley Environmental Educational Centre and Twin Towns Employment Enterprises. I am delighted that the Work for the Dole program was extended by the government in the 1999 budget, doubling the number of places to 50,000 and extending the program to job seekers aged 25 to 34 who have been receiving unemployment payments for 12 months or more. It is clear that the Work for the Dole program is achieving results. This is good news for job seekers, good news for the taxpayer and good news for the communities in which we live.
