talk.start.para: âI rise to speak tonight on a matter affecting many families in all areas of Tasmania. It relates to child care and the continual battle parents are facing on affordability versus quality. In the first budget this government brought down in 1996 it abolished the operational subsidy for community based centres. Whilst this is `old news', the long-term effects of this decision are really starting to hit. The operational subsidy was removed from community based centres. Tasmania's child-care industry has a higher rate of community based centresâsome 60 per cent.

speech.para: To illustrate the effect this has had both on families and on the centres themselves I would like to quote statistics on comparisons of child-care centre utilisation rates, and so on, for 1996 through to 1999. I would like to quote these and other comparison statistics, but I cannot. You see, since 1997 the Department of Family and Community Services has chosen not to release any statistical information relating to long day care centres at all. Long day child-care centres around the country are asked annually to complete a child-care census form. This 10-page document requests specific information relating to utilisation rates, fee structure, session structure, opening hours, age of children attending, and so on.

In recent discussions with centres in my electorate of Bass, centre directors advised it took approximately 15 hours to complete the census, which has just been completed for the May 1999 period. Centres are very happy to comply with this form, and in previous years such data was made available. This is interesting, as we are still waiting for the publication of the statistics for the May 1998 period. This period covers the first year of statistics since the loss of the subsidy. These are the vital statistics required to assess the impact that the loss of the subsidy has had on Australian families. These are the figures that are unavailable.

The census provides an overall picture of how Australian families are using child-care centres. It also gives a clear picture of the services and facilities the child-care centres themselves are offering. The December 1998 Senate Community Affairs References Committee report on child-care funding recommended:

The Department of Family and Community Services expedite the processing of results from future surveys and census collections so that up-to-date information is available for policy development and planning purposes.

In requesting information to assist in addressing local issues, I have been advised that the children's services statistical report will no longer be made available. It is, instead, to be replaced by an `information brochure'. But will this `information brochure' contain the vital information required to assess child-care issues on an electorate-by-electorate basis? The best way to determine the true impact of child-care funding cuts is to ask the centres and to ask the families. However, lack of published statistical data from these sources makes it difficult to describe the effect that losing this subsidy has placed on the centres. We are then required to rely on our own anecdotal evidence.

Through contact with large and small day care centres in my electorate of Bass, it does not take long to see a common theme of problems and issues emerging. One of the larger centres is at threat of closure, with an administrator being appointed to determine the long-term viability of the centre. Whilst other centres remain open, the types of difficulties expressed by them indicate widespread problems within the industry. All centres expressed their concerns at how they had gone from having waiting lists for places in 1996 to having an average of 10 to 15 spaces available in 1999.

This is actually indicative of the effect of the higher cost of child care within the industry since the removal of the operational subsidy. All centres confirmed that they had been forced to increase their fees by an initial $20 per week when the subsidy was first removed and by an additional minimum of $5 per week per annum every year since. This represents between $35 and $40 per week more than parents had to pay in 1996. One parent who wrote to the Examiner newspaper summed this up beautifully by saying:

We have two children in full-time care, which costs us twice what we would pay if we sent them to a private school. I cannot understand the logic of the proposed increased funding for private schools when the cost of child-care is not addressed.

With a staff to child ratio for a three-year-old in a day care centre being one to five and in a kindergarten being one to approximately 20, this should not be an option parents are forced to take. Yet it was another of the common themes expressed by the centres in Bass that their three- to five-year-old room was well down on numbers due to parents having to choose the private school option. Of course, these are the private schools that this government is so quick to increase funding to whilst not supplying any additional funding to needy child-care centres.

But the real effect of this difficulty is ultimately felt by the children and their parents. The strain of having to choose a `cheaper' option of child care to remain in the work force is now a reality for many families. It is time the government released the 1998 child-care census figures. It is time the government reviewed its funding decisions in relation to child care. It is time it prioritised the needs of Australian families and considered the strain it is unnecessarily placing on parents who need to use child care as a necessity. Child care, unlike the private school education option, is a necessity for Australian families and not a luxury.

talk.start.para: âI just say in response to the member for Bass that you cannot have it both ways. Unfortunately, you cannot live in a country that is sustaining the levels of growth that we currently are and come into the parliament to, presumably, represent the people of Bass and deny reforms in transport, taxation, communi cations, government regulation and a whole range of things, including consolidating the finances of the country, on the one hand and then on the other say, `We do want a first-class and free education. We do want extremely high levels of child care and all kinds of social services provided.'

speech.para: I am rising tonight to make some comments about industrial relations policy. Whilst I consider Ms Jennie George, the President of the ACTU, to be an engaging and inherently decent person, her views and those of her dwindling union membership are inappropriate to the reality with which this nation is faced. In continuing to campaign against workplace based agreements underwritten by a safety net, freedom of association, youth wages and the repeal of unfair dismissal provisions for small businesses, the ACTU courts not only irrelevancy but also the ire of a generation that is being denied the reasonable prospect of having a job.

But I think we also need to remember that we have a practical example of what the ACTU's prescription for the problem might actually be. The Hawke-Keating Labor government signed an accord with the unions. A degree of wage restraint was achieved in return for a boost to what was to become known as the `social wage'. The latter comprised Medicare, child care and a raft of social security benefits previously unavailable to middle income Australians. But the accord actually reinforced the very settings that mitigate against employment growth. In reaching such a centralised trade-off, the ACTU implicitly endorsed weak macro-economic policies, including the budget deficits that we use to build social infrastructure and, as a consequence, high interest rates, both business and mortgage.

In the decade from 1984, when Australia averaged annual economic growth of 3Â½ per cent and 160,000 new jobs were created each year, the number of Australians without work in our country actually increased from 670,000 to 850,000. And, to complete the scenario, labour productivity was less than half of what it is today. In other words, if you sit in Canberra and make decisions in relation to the remuneration of workers or even at the level of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, you do so in a vacuum of what is relevant to the circumstances of a particular workplace, its employer and employees. In the past three years, for example, the lowest paid workers in this country have received a real increase in their wages of 7.8 per centâwith lower inflation and interest rates being a critical part of the equation. Under the ACTU-Labor government accord, they received a real reduction of five per cent.

The example of trying to abolish youth wages might appear as a fashionable crusade to young people who at timesâI suppose, understandablyâlong for the trappings of modern life. But, if it is such a `just' Labor cause to abolish youth wages, why haven't the New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmanian governments removed them from their own jurisdictions? And, indeed, why hasn't Tony Blair?

If youth wages discriminate, they do so in favour of young people. The Australian Retailers Association estimates, for example, that the abolition of youth wages would cost the jobs of 170,000 young Australians; it would add $1.6 billion to the national wages bill. Further to that, if you did what the shop assistants union put forward in its submission to the AIRC review of youth wages and abolished youth wages for those over the age of 18, you would add $360 million to the national wages bill. Where youth wages essentially have been abolishedâfor example, in the banking and major building sectorsâvery few young people are employed.

The reason why Labor governments at a state level have not abolished youth wages is that, if you want to destroy jobs, overprice and overregulate the conditions of employment. If you doubt this, when next you go into a local shopâand I say this to those on the other side in particularâsimply ask the person who owns the business whether they believe these things are mitigating against the employment of young people. As Tony Blair, shortly after moving into Downing Street, told British unions:
The only way to ensure job security for your members is for them to work in efficient and profitable businesses . . . the days of lightning strikes are over.

Rather ironically, a week later, in September 1997, Mr Beazley, the leader of the Australian Labor Party in this place, was reminding unions of the 19th century struggles on the railways in Queensland. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to praise the efforts of Kincare, a community group in my electorate of Canning. Kincare recently organised a successful forum for parents and carers of children with disabilities. Kincare was created initially by representatives of the Red Cross Society, its goal being to give parents and carers a regular forum in which to socialise together, give each other support and exchange information. Often the group invites guest speakers to better inform carers to enable them to access the assistance they need in relation to their children's care.

speech.para: In the last two years, helped through funding from HACC, Kincare has held camps in the south-west of Western Australian for carers. Members describe it as an opportunity to `regroup mentally and physically in order to face another year'. Kincare plans to work to develop a program for siblings of disabled children who experience a range of problems such as parents being away frequently if the disabled child is ill and in hospital, or being teased at school by other children because there is a child with disabilities in their family. It is groups such as Kincare that deserve more support and recognition from governments. They help parents and carers deal with the everyday stresses and problems they experience.

I spoke earlier this year about the difficulties encountered by families with Centrelink processes when their child turns 17 and needs to transfer to an adult disability pension. Recently one of my constituents had the experience of being told that she could not fill out the forms for the adult disability pension on behalf of her son and that he himself would need to attend the interview. This occurred despite the fact that Centrelink was aware that her son suffers from Prader-Willi Syndrome, a disability that affects him both intellectually and physically. He is non-verbal and confined to a wheelchair, relying on his family for all his needs. It was obvious that he could neither fill in forms nor answer questions in an interview.

This was another unreasonable stress and humiliation which the family was forced to endure in getting their son to a Centrelink office and explaining his condition yet again to the staff. The government should allocate to Centrelink the resources necessary to ensure that parents and carers are not forced to endure more forms and interviews that further complicate their busy and difficult lives.

The costs involved in caring for someone with disabilities as already described can be tremendous. This particular family required renovations to their home to make it wheelchair accessible and the purchase of a modified van, as they were no longer able to get their child in and out of the family car. The total cost was nearly $40,000. Then there are the day-to-day expenses such as the purchase of incontinence pads and the extra domestic costs and work that this problem causes.
The value and work of Kincare can best be described in the words of a mother who is an active member of Kincare and has a son with disabilities:

Many carers experience similar circumstances. Through people like Kincare, carers gain support, friendships and knowledge that other people are in similar situations as themselves. Caring can be a very lonely and isolating life. Families often break down due to the stresses of having a disabled child, leaving one parent to continue the caring role under more stress and feeling even more isolated.
Groups such as Kincare have provided a vital support for this family and many others. They are to be congratulated for the work they do. I am very pleased that there is such a resource in my area.

talk.start.para: âBefore the 1996 election when Australians were asked what were their concerns, almost invariably, the No. 1 concern was employment; it was the lack of opportunities being delivered by the former government to young Australian job seekers and, indeed, to job seekers across the age spectrum. I rise tonight with the very considerable pleasure of informing the House of the results of the most recent Parramatta job vacancy survey conducted by the Western Sydney Research Institute of the University of Western Sydney. I would like to quote a couple of sections from that report.

speech.para: Mr Speaker, you will be interested to know that, according to the report, in the last two years the Parramatta labour market has displayed buoyant growth. In 1996 and 1997 job advertisements were steady, but in 1998 advertisements expanded spectacularly and 1999 has continued in the same pattern. Total job vacancies for May 1999 as measured by the survey from the Parramatta Advertiser involved an increase of 11 per cent over the month of February. So in just two months we have had this burgeoning growth of advertised jobs for job seekers in my electorate. Since May 1998 job vacancies have increased by almost 48 per cent and by more than 100 per cent since May 1997.

I note that the Leader of the Opposition is demonstrating characteristic indifference to the aspirations and hopes of job seekers in my electorate of Parramatta. You can talk all you want about social justice, you can talk all you want about equity, but at the end of the day if there is not a job there to apply for it is nothing more than shallow and hollow rhetoric.

The University of Western Sydney is talking about a job market in Parramatta which it describes as buoyant and characterising spectacular growth. There has been a 100 per cent growth in job vacancies since the Howard coalition government was elected in 1996. That is my idea of social justice. My idea is actually giving the battlers a job to go to. You will be interested to know that there was not only a rise in casual employment, which is encouraging and good, but also a very important rise in the number of permanent jobs on offer in my electorate.

For May 1999 there were 703 jobs advertised on a full-time basis or 42 per cent of the total, versus May 1998 where only 38.5 per cent of all vacancies were for full-time employment. Casual employment is good for single mothers, for working mothers wanting to get back into the work force, for people who want to structure their family and work commitments with greater flexibility. But the presence of the offer of permanent employment is an expression of the confidence which is now filling the sails of the business community in Western Sydney and in my electorate of Parramatta in particular. We have this observation from the authors of the report:
In general advertised conditions of work seem to have stabilised, casualisation has slowed and there is an improvement in the amount of full time work on offer.

I am particularly encouraged to see a rise in the number of permanent jobs for unskilled workersâthose who previous Labor governments would have alleged that they represented, those who have not had the benefits which many Australians enjoy in terms of a tertiary education and high standards of living in their families. Sectors such as manufacturing, retail, hospitality, transport and storage have shown dramatic rises in the opportunities for new employment. Smaller rises were evident across a broad range of sectors, including, for example, agriculture, where the number of employees rose in my urban electorate from only one in May 1998 to seven in May 1999. In the wholesale sector there were 41 advertisements in May 1998 and 81 in May 1999. What we have is this extraordinary result, with a booming sense of confidence, a willingness to invest, to employ, to give young people a go. The last paragraph of the survey says:

Overall the results for May 1999 indicate a dramatic increase in jobs over the last twelve months, advertisements growing by 48 per cent. . . . While Retail, Hospitality and Manufacturing continue to be the big advertisers in the region, most industry sectors advertised more frequently this May than last. Manufacturing continues its spectacular expansion, doubling over 24 months.
I congratulate John Howard on his guts, his leadership, his willingness to tackle the hard issues that the opposition continues to fail to deal with. (Time expired)

âHe is the Michael Photios of the federal parliament.
âI note the interjection of the member for Watson, but I would have to say that I really could not comment on that.

âMr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I wish to oppose the member's comment on the member for Parramatta and his sanity. I do not think that the member for Parramatta is insane or has a mental illness and I do not like the reflection.

âI would like to comment on some events at this Monday's estimates hearings in the industry area relating to an organisation known as the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group, which is a group set up by the government some 12 months ago for improving dialogue and consultation between the pharmaceutical industry and the government. I think that is a very good idea. I note the member for Bradfield nodding. I think there is a need for improved coordination between the pharmaceutical industry and the government, because it is a very important industry. However, in questions asked during estimates hearings, what came out was the following: the actual group was set up on 23 June 1998 and its next meeting will be on 30 June 1999, making it over 12 months between meetings of this group.

speech.para: If you have got a consultative group, a group that is designed to ensure that industry and government understand what they are trying to achieve, that they are committed to working together in what is a key industry for the future of our nation, it is a bit odd when you have got a situation where the group has not met for over 12 months. Yes, there was an election, but the election was in October. There has been plenty of time since then for a meeting to occur. In fact at the estimates hearing it was suggested that a report from the APMA on the question of the economic state of the industry and the opportunities for the industry in terms of the future of Australia was actually instigated as a result of the working group. However, when we checked the APMA records we found that, in fact, that report was commissioned in May 1998 in a situation where PIWG did not even exist until June. I think the government has some very important issues to raise here.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 4.30 p.m.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 7 June, on motion by Mr Costello:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI would now like to turn to the changes to the ANTS packageâA New Tax System package. Food for human consumption is to be GST free except for prepared meals, takeaway food, restaurant meals, alcohol, soft drinks, confectionery, ice-cream and snack foods and associated products. Frankly, as a mother who battles to steer an 11Â½-year-old son to eat healthy food rather than chips, Big Macs and the ubiquitous fries, to say nothing of Coca-Cola, this is a welcome package. It is a responsible policy making decision to exclude prepared food and to focus instead on healthy home prepared food.

speech.para: As we all know, obesity amongst school children is a major concern. I notice also in the package that there is an initiative for a national child nutrition project. I think that is also very welcome. Overall I believe the changes to food are responsible ones and, for the average parent, very welcome. There is no doubt that there are definitional issues to be finalised to ensure that the package meets the design principles of the Australian Democrats, but overall the package is family friendly and common sense.

Regrettably, the response of the Labor Party has disappointed many of those on this side of the House. Chicken Man stunts and waving bags of lettuce is really not the thing to do in such a serious debate. It was sad to see the light on the hill become the lettuce and the dill because this is a matter that goes to the heart of every homeâwhat the family consumesâand is a responsible way to look at food and taxation. As I said, as a parent I am very pleased with the package in its current form.

I would now like to turn to something particularly relevant to those of us who represent rural and regional Australia, and that is the treatment of fuel and taxation. Fuel tax reform remains the multibillion dollar breakthrough. Unfortunately, the Labor Party is still espousing 43c per litre as a fuel excise. The National-Liberal-Democrats proposal will see 23c per litre come off that fuel excise, bringing it down to 20c per litre. That will apply to all vehicles of 20 tonnes or more no matter where they operate and all vehicles greater than 4.5 tonnes in regional areas. That includes goods that go to or from cities or between regional areas. Certainly we would have liked to have seen the tonnage on the 4.5 lowered but, nonetheless, it is a great deal better than what we have now. In the next while I would like to show you and other members of the House the real advantages for rural and regional Australia.
I would like to quote the shadow minister for transport and regional services in her speech on the budget on 1 June 1999. She said:
It is a shift away from any strategy designed to reduce regional inequalityâand there is a lot of inequality, both within and between regions . . .

She was referring to the budget of the coalition government. It is quite breathtaking to be proposing a fuel excise of 43c per litre and criticising those who are offering a fuel excise of only 20c per litre. That to me is blatant inequality.

I would like to share with you some examples from my own electorate undertaken by the National Truck Association. There is a trucking business in Dawson, a moderately sized family business, with a turnover of $2 million a year. Their diesel fuel bill is in the order of $400,000. On the Truck Association's figures they are going to save $132,500. On wholesale sales tax on parts, oil, tyres and so on they are looking at a saving of $75,260. So for that one small business, the total sum of the savings is $207,760âabout $200,000. That is money that will not be coming to Canberra, but will be staying with that business to be passed on to those who transport products, to be kept in the local community. Regrettably, the Labor Party opposes this.

I would now like to quote from the transcript of an interview given on 2 June, again, quoting somebody who feels aggrieved by the altered tax package. This is the national president of the Transport Workers Union, Mr Bill Noonan, who is quoted as saying, `It is a case of politics gone mad.' Mr Noonan says:

Take the situation of a large group of truck drivers located, say, in Laverton in Melbourne. If you relocate them 20 kilometres to the west, does that mean that the road transport employer could operate the business with cheaper diesel and thus put their jobs in jeopardy? I mean, they're the sorts of simple questions I think need to be answered. But, of course, the ramifications to the simple questions are quite significant.
He is quite right. The ramifications to the simple questions are significant. A ramification of this change could well be decentralisation.

I see nothing wrong with businesses moving into rural and regional areas to give their employees the opportunity to live in a cleaner, quieter, more family friendly environment, to perhaps have lower housing costs and certainly lower transport costs. It is the first real initiative that I have seen towards decentralisation, which I know is very much, Mr Deputy Speaker, one of those things you feel strongly about. It is the first real policy I have seen towards decentralisation, encouraging people to live wherever they choose, perhaps in the city, but if they choose, perhaps in rural and regional Australia.

I would like to share with you another example of savings for rural and regional Australia. This is a trucking company that operates, again, in Dawson; a very large company as it turns out. They transport chopped cane from the siding to the tram line, raw sugar to the harbour, molasses down to the VLC plant, refined sugar to the harbour. They use 2.5 million litres of diesel a year. The saving for this company, from lowering the diesel excise by 23c per litre, is $575,000. That is a lot of money. That money is going to stay in the community. I spoke to the owner of this business and he said, `Of course, we will pass it on.' And they will have to pass it on, and that is a good thing. But it will remain with farmers and small businesses in the town, and that is where it should be. That is a significant amount of money. From those two businesses, we are looking at a quarter of a million dollars, just two businesses, of money remaining in our local economy.

It is a reversal of inequality. It is tilting the playing field in favour of regional and rural Australia, I think, really, for the first time in a very long time. Those who are opposed to this measure are opposed to the bush finally getting ahead. I simply say, where is the member for Dickson? She really should be applauding this. It is a very sound measure.

I would like to mention very briefly some other aspects of the tax package. One aspect is the wholesale sales tax. It is often said by those in the opposition that farmers do not pay wholesale sales tax. If only that were true. But regrettably we do in the cane industry. Cane haul-out trucks attract 22 per cent wholesale sales tax. On every cane haul-out truckâand there are usually a couple working in a paddock through the crushâit is $30,000 extra per vehicle. That is a great sum of money for a cane harvesting contractor and his family to have to pay. That will go with the implementation of this package.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I find this package enormously exciting. I really do. I think for the first time we are going to have an opportunity to attract businesses into rural and regional Australia. If they want to move there: move up to Dawson! We would love to have you. We are going to see money staying in the community that would have come to Canberra or to the states. It is going to stay in the local community, providing jobs for others. I think it is a tremendous initiative. It really is the first time I have seen a substantial plan to tilt the playing field in favour of rural and regional Australia.

In the time left to me I would like to speak very briefly about some of the other sound initiatives in the budget. We are looking at regional impact statements which will assess the impact on regions of cabinet proposals. That is certainly an initiative well overdue, in my opinion. In so many other departments there are very sound initiatives, but they may or may not have a negative effect on a rural or regional area. I think this will properly assess the impact on our more vulnerable areas in Australia.

I welcome the regional Australia strategy to restore services to rural and regional Australia and to ensure access to those services. We are looking at rural transaction centres. We are looking at rural GPs: a retention program of $43.4 million over four years for retention payments for long-serving general practitioners. In our area we have a GP who has been in a sole practice for 13Â½ years and who is absolutely exhausted. He has been advertising for 13Â½ years to get a partner. To get a locum in our area, if they are lucky enough to get a locum, a doctor has to spend at least $3,000 advertising. It really is a labour of love and devotion in the rural and regional areas. For those doctors who choose to serve in our small towns and communities, I have nothing but gratitude. But they certainly do need to be rewarded and encouraged, and I welcome this initiative.

The Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, has already looked at a new deal with Western Australia for more rural doctors. Overseas doctors can enter into a contract which binds them to a specific rural location for a period of five years. When we were looking at Aboriginal communities in Western Australia, they found it enormously difficult; if our small towns find it hard to attract a doctor, they find it almost impossible. I think if it is good enough for overseas doctors, frankly, it should be good enough for some of ours. I know they refer to it as civil conscription, but the reality is that access to professional medical attention is the right of every Australian, whether they live in the heart of Sydney or Melbourne, whether they live in Proserpine or Bowen, or whether they live on a remote Aboriginal community.

I would like to move now to the James Cook Medical School. I notice in the budget that there are to be 60 student placesâ$6.4 million. This was an initiative of the Prime Minister, and I am enormously grateful to him. We have waited a long time in the north for our own medical school. It is going to give young rural people from our area the opportunity to become doctors. There will be five places held for indigenous students. So it is a tremendous opportunity in our area to train people from the rural areas and to see them, hopefully, come back to the rural areas.

There are so many sound initiatives in the budget, but there are some that I have to mention. We are looking in particular, from the Attorney-General's portfolio, at a national telecommunication advice and information line on child support matters. I think every one of us in our electorates has inquiries about child support. It is a very difficult and heart-rending issue for the residential and non-residential parent. This information line will be very welcome, certainly for electorates like mine where there is no Child Support Agency. That takes nothing away from the sound work that the Townsville Child Support Agency does. They are very professional and helpful and compassionate, but sometimes it is just not enough. Of course, we are the de facto child support agency office in Mackay. It does put a burden on rural and regional members, so this information line will be very welcome.

We are looking at additional family dispute resolution services and at something else that I really do think is a sound measure: conferencing in legal aid. The Attorney-General is looking at putting additional funding to that. In our legal aid office in Mackay there are eight families a week that seek family conferencing. It is a less adversarial way of resolving family difficulties. By then, of course, the marriage has broken down irrevocably, but it is a way of getting away from the confrontational approach adopted in the court system. The families that go through this conferencing find it a good way of developing goodwill. Obviously, the most important people in this whole situation are the children. If they can encounter a situation where both parents are able to work with a degree of goodwill in a family breakdown, then I think we have progressed a great deal. So I am very grateful to the Attorney-General for the conferencing arrangements and the additional funding towards that. I will close by saying that it is a very sound budget, a very rural and regional friendly budget, and I am pleased to support it.

talk.start.para: âThis afternoon I want to respond to the health part of the 1999-2000 budget. The budget does contain some useful initiatives and a much needed injection of funds for areas that have been systematically attacked by this government in recent years, particularly in the area of research. There are some important initiatives such as the additional funds for Aboriginal health. It is the case, as the minister has recognised, that Australia cannot rest while Aboriginal people are likely to die 20 years younger on average than their fellow Australians.

speech.para: As the previous speaker outlined, the imbalance between health services in the city and the country also continues to grow. I would have to say that the government's efforts so far have produced a net increase of only 12 doctorsâthat is 12 doctorsâin all of rural Australia last year. The budget does include a new round of measures and it is certainly to be hoped that these work better than their predecessors.

But overall, the budget in the health area puts the priority in the wrong areas and, as usual for this minister, fails to set any targets. He has been burnt by a previous health insurance target so he has gone off the idea of targets which would make it possible for anybody to measure whether the claims made for any of the new initiatives in health can, in fact, be tested.

The budget is being billed as a billion dollar boost for health. However, of course, on closer examination we find that most of the new programs are small pilots or, in the case of medical research, the substantive boost to funding comes only after six years. In the first year, the year we are talking about, all the initiatives amount to an increase of $164 millionâless than one per cent of the whole health budget.

These initiatives, of course, are dwarfed by the $1.7 billion, the all-up cost of the private health insurance rebate. That is 10 times the allocation for all the new initiatives in this year's budget. Yes, health spending is up, but it is mostly to pay for the private health insurance rebate. If the government had not thrown away this $1.7 billion a year, we could have afforded to fix so many of the problems that exist in our public hospitals. We could have done something substantive about Aboriginal health and, of course, we could have reintroduced the Commonwealth Dental Program.

But now, instead, we see nearly 10 per cent of the total health budget going out as a direct subsidy to the private health insurance funds. The rebate was meant to produce, in the minister's words, `a surge' of 550,000 new membersâthis was when he was interested in targetsâand to hold down premiums because of the increased number of members. It has failed on both counts. Membership is up by a miserable 57,000 people all around Australia and we saw just recently that premiums have jumped by 4.9 per cent, or $100 a year for an average family.

So what is it that has led this health minister to declare that Australia's health system is out of danger and in recovery? The most substantial claims he makes relate to a number of agreements that he has been negotiating for a cap on major areas of expenditure. At a postbudget breakfast briefing the minister said that, as a result of these agreements, two-thirds of the Medicare budget will be capped and predictable. The proof, of course, will be in the pudding as to whether these agreements work. The initial signs are certainly not encouraging.

I want now to look briefly at three areas: radiology, pharmaceuticals and general practice. Between them these represent about $7 billion a year in Commonwealth expenditure, so they are rightly subject to close consideration. Unfortunately, the agreements that have been reached have utilised a very vague concept that the minister calls a `soft cap', which means they are not very effective at controlling costs. The relevant doctor organisations certainly do not have the same view as the minister about how these agreements are to be implemented.

In the case of radiology, the agreement is now one year old. Under this agreement, the billion-dollar radiology budget was to be kept to a seven per cent increaseânot a very hard target in times of 1.9 per cent inflation. We are now informed through a Senate estimates committee that, in the first year of this agreement, there has been a $35 million blow-out and the agreement is heading towards overexpenditure of $165 million. The radiologists were expected to keep spending within the prescribed soft cap by restricting use of CAT scan and ultrasound. However, expenditure is up by 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively, and use is continuing to grow rapidly. The minister has done nothing to rein in these costs.

To lose $35 million to radiologists in the first year of an agreement is hardly world's best practice. It is time for the minister to act and he must produce a solution that does not simply transfer the cost to the patient. At a recent closed session in Sydney, the radiologists discussed how they might respond to this budget blow-out. Their recipe was simple: any cutback by the government would be passed on to the patient. This would mean additional gap payments of up to $150, depending on the procedure involved.

The trade-off for the radiology agreement was that the Commonwealth would allow Medicare rebates for privately owned magnetic resonance imaging units. This too was meant to save moneyâ$80 million over four years. But the MRI agreement is heading for a huge blow-out, with costs running millions of dollars over budget. The number of scans was to be held to 403,000 over three years but they are already running at 13,000 a month, and a number of the new machines have yet to come on line. Why is this? The reason remains clouded in mystery.

Somehow, it seems, the word got out that the minister was intending to extend the Medicare rebate to include MRI units which were only on order on the night of the 1998 budget. It has now emerged, as a result of persistent questioning by the opposition in the Senate estimates committee, that no fewer than 31 new units were allegedly ordered in the run-up to the 1998 budget. This represents a 50 per cent increase over the 62 units that were operating at the time. In a few short weeks the stock of machines which had been built up over a decade, and which the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee had reported eight months earlier as sufficient for Australia's needs, had increased by 50 per cent.

The Health Insurance Commission is still investigating whether any of these alleged contracts involved fraud or criminal activity. The minister has told the parliament that he `completely and categorically denies and repudiates' any suggestion that there was a leak from him or anyone in his office, yet he still refuses to table the dates of these contracts or to release any further information. As a start, I suggest, instead of leaving any answers to these questions to a later date, it would be a good idea if the minister came out now, gave us the dates of the contracts and cleared up some of the remaining mystery about this massive problem.

The second agreement which the minister seeks to enter concerns pharmaceuticals. In this year's budget, cuts to pharmaceutical spending are supposed to be based on agreements with doctors `to measure and share' the benefits. Over the next four years, the government proposes to save $350 million on pharmaceutical spending. The portfolio budget statements say that half the savings will be redirected to doctors but the true situationâonce again extracted via the Senate estimates committeeâis that only 22 per cent, or $78 million, will be returned to doctors over the four years. A similar scheme for pathology will save the government $134 million and doctors supposedly will get a payback of $27 million.

Payments for the pharmaceutical scheme are to be given to doctors who stay below the average for prescribing in the three designated groups of pharmaceuticalsâcardiovascular drugs, drugs for gastric disorders and antibiotics. How this return to doctors is to be organised remains totally unclear to the opposition, the department and the doctors. The payments are apparently to be made to individual doctors, but nobody seems to know how this is to be measured out and allocated or which doctors are to get it.

The Australian Medical Association has no doubts about the dangers. It has loudly condemned the pharmaceutical cuts in the budgetâcuts which were arrived at without its agreement. I certainly support measures to curb overprescribing, but it is not very sensible to proceed without the agreement of the party on whom you are depending for the implementation of a more efficient system.

This announcement has not been the right way to start. The reaction from the medical profession so far has certainly not led anybody to think that this budget initiative will be implemented smoothly. As I said, the government has been unable to spell out how these cuts will be made or how the doctors will get what the budget says is their share. We should not get to a point where a government scheme to save money prevents a doctor prescribing the correct drug for a particular patient for fear of losing a bonus payment.

The third agreement that I want to touch on underpins this year's health budgetâdespite the fact that it has not been concluded and is not even mentioned in the budget papers. The Minister for Health and Aged Care has been unable to reach agreement with the AMA and other GP groups over the new general practice agreement to put a capâonce again, a soft capâon total spending on general practice. The minister now says that he hopes for an agreement by 30 June, but many of the key planks on which the budget depends are based on the conclusion of this agreement.

A number of drafts have been leaked during the process. The drafts highlight the way that the government has slowly backed down, replacing hard targets with vague words of principle. The document has been reduced from an agreement to a memorandum of understanding, and the soft cap has numerous exemptions which now permit expenditure to increase for a wide range of reasons. Although this agreement has not been signed, the government is depending on it to deliver its major savings for pathology and pharmaceuticals. Although the doctors have not signed up yet, a total of $171 million in new incentives are offered to them in the budget. These incentives are essentially tied to this agreement. We will see how this finishes up, but it is likely that the government will concede more ground and that the interests of the patients will come a poor last to those of the doctors and to the government's efforts to cut budgets.

If the GPs do not reduce the growth in servicesâjust as we have seen in radiologyâand, as a result, the government reduces the amount paid to general practitioners, we all know who will be left holding the billâthe patients. The rapid growth in gap payments faced by patients was reported on in today's Australian. According to information from the health department, patient costs jumped by an average of $200 in the last two years for nine common surgical procedures.

In practice, the agreements I have talked about today will push the costs from the Commonwealth onto individuals. The real thrust of the minister's negotiation seems to be to increase patient costs and push doctors away from bulk-billingâyet again, another attempt to undermine Medicare. The other major flaw in the soft cap agreements, particularly the radiology agreement, is that they are continually undermined by the states. The states are taking advantage of them to shift costs onto the Commonwealth and, once again, push up the total cost of health care. In the radiology area in particular, there is strong evidence that this cost shifting is taking place directly under the minister's nose. It is negating the effect of what he publicly claims has been achieved, and yet he continues to do nothing about it.

I now want to turn to the additional money for medical research over the next six years. It has certainly been welcomed by many medical researchers. But the amount of money allocated to medical research has to cover many areas dramatically affected by previous Howard government cuts. We see in table 2 of the science and technology statement, released two days after the budget, that expenditure on research across the government will be $100 million less in constant prices than it was in Labor's last year of government. This is because of cuts to the university sector and the reduction of the tax concessions that applied to business research and development in the Howard government's horror budget of 1996.

The minister's claim that only $110 million was spent on medical research in Labor's last year of government is simply wrong. The science and technology budget papers contain the real picture in table 3. Health and medical research in 1995-96 was $163 million, only slightly less than the $165 million in 1998-99, used by the government as its base for the new initiative.

The latest Bureau of Statistics figures, released last Friday, show that business expenditure on R&D continues to plummet, with a further four per cent drop in 1997-98 due to the reduction in business R&D tax concessions. Again, the science and technology statement documents the decline.

Under John Howard, the percentage of the nation's wealth invested in research of all kinds has shrunk from 0.75 per cent of GDP to just 0.63 per cent. The build-up of funds for medical research will also be painfully slow. In the first year there is only an additional $21 million. Researchers will have to wait six years before the promised doubling of funds actually occurs. Australia still remains a very poor investor in medical research. Figures in the Wills report certainly demonstrate how far we are behind in this regard.

The government has also failed to tackle the other substantive changes that the Wills report on medical research has called for, most particularly to fix the problems where the country's capital gains tax regime discriminates against investments from overseas.
Mr Ross Cameron interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIf you had read our platform before the last election, you would know that the Labor Party demonstrated, well before the Wills report, that we intended to introduce a new tax regime that would give incentives to overseas investors in research, as part of our 1998 election platform.

speech.para: The government remains, of course, obsessed with the GST and has refused to do anything to attract overseas superannuation funds to invest in Australian science. Let us have a look at who has actually put forward the detailed policy. As I said before, having failed to meet the dismal targets the government set for its 30 per cent rebate, this minister now intends setting no targets for any of his new programs. We do not have any idea how many additional doctors or nurses he wants to get into rural areas. We are getting no idea of measures for success on medical research and no way to measure whether these additional funds will simply replace public hospital funding withdrawn by the states, or the earlier cuts by this federal government to university grants and to R&D concessions.

But, most importantly, this government once again has turned its back on two of the major problems that Australia's health system faces. Day after day, in each of the papers in the capital cities, we see the problems that the public hospital systems continue to faceâwhether it is in Western Australia, where the shadow minister for health talks about Western Australian mums being forced to endure disgraceful conditions, whether it is in South Australia with the South Australian government once again taking another $50 million out of the health system, or whether it is in Victoriaâthe minister's home state and mineâwhere we see the horror stories of things going on in our public hospitals. And public hospitals do not even get a mention in this national health budgetânot even a mention. Most of the statesârun by Liberal parties of courseâwithdraw funds, and the Commonwealth fails to keep up with the rise in medical costs and the growth in demand.

The other horrific story is that of dental care, where the waiting times for people in urgent need of dental care continue to blow out and are now between one and two years. This is the direct result of this government abolishing the Commonwealth Dental Program. Once again, there is no commitment by this government to address a very painful cut to health care that they obviously have no intention whatsoever of redressing.

talk.start.para: âI have listened to the remarks of the member for Jagajaga with, I confess, frank astonishment, in particular to her concluding remarks about economic management in Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria. The member for Jagajaga will be familiar with the economic performance of the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia. It took 10 years under the governments of Brian Burke and Carmen Lawrence to virtually bankrupt Western Australia; to reduce it to a position of penury and to subject it to absolute ridicule and disgrace because of their economic mismanagement. Richard Court is having to rescue the state from this incredible economic disaster precipitated by the profligacy of the Australian Labor Party over 10 years.

speech.para: Under Labor, a credit ranking of Western Australia by Standard and Poor's saw Western Australia's credit ranking drop for the first time. Western Australia lost its AAA rating under Labor. When Richard Court came to power, Western Australia had an accumulated debt of $8 billionâ$8 billion for a single stateâor 20 per cent of the gross state product. Under Richard Court, the AAA rating has been restored and the level of state debt has been reduced from 20 per cent of gross state product to eight per cent of gross state product.

The member for Jagajaga referred to South Australiaâand well might she slink out the door. Dean Brown and John Olsen have had to come in like the cavalry and rescue a state which likewise had become a subject of ridicule and pity by other states of the Commonwealth. With a population in South Australia of 1.5 million, the State Bank of South Australia, under Labor's economic stewardship, racked up a debt of $4 billion. The state is still struggling to pay $2 million a day of interest on Labor's debt. Labor, as a kind of core element of their philosophy, just takes the view that there is no long-term relationship between economic stewardship and social or human outcomes.

If you went to Victoria, as the member for Jagajaga did, you would know that the Kennett government was called in to rescue a state which similarly had collapsed underneath the Victorian people because of lack of economic productivity. In Victoria's situation, the governments of Cain and Kirner saw the collapse of the Pyramid group and the Tricontinental Bank. Victoria, after a period of tough economic decisions, of real economic management, now has a fleet-footed leadership and is responding to the opportunities which are being presented. Victoria is winning one major event after another, which is enabling it to pay its debt. My federal colleagues in New South Wales will identify with the frustration of hearing all of Sydney business wandering around saying, `If only we had the sort of economic leadership that has been provided by the state government in Victoria.'

If you elect Labor governments in Victoria, in South Australia and in Western Australia, you will see this absolutely consistent pattern of the states going from a position of strength to a position of great indebtedness, reduced productivity, higher unemployment and lower rates of investment. In the long run, the people who suffer are the puntersâthe mums and dads and the workersâwho find that the states have to continually lift taxes in order to fund their ever increasing expenditures.

As you wander around Parliament House you see the posters and slogans that members put on the windows of their offices from time to time; posters which are emblematic of their philosophy. One of the most popular posters among those who are drawn from the left of Australian politics seems to include this expression: `We live in a society, not an economy'. This expression is a glib one that rolls off the tongue with comparative ease and sets the maker of the expression up as being a person with a beating heart full of the milk of human kindness and compassion. But it holds within it the seeds of the destruction of any Labor government and the seeds of misfortune for any constituent or electorate which is governed by Labor stewardship. This is because it holds up the proposition that, in the long run, you can separate economic productivity from social and human outcomes; that you can somehow continue to borrow and borrow, spend and spend and shirk the hard task of economic reform without consequence. The expression somehow says that the chickens will never come home to roost; that we can eat, drink, spend and tax today and hope that tomorrow will never arrive.

The whole contribution of the member for Jagajaga is a critique of the lack of further expenditure by this government in one sector after another, whether it is R&D, pharmaceutical benefits or public health. In every sentence she is saying, `Spend, spend, spend.' If she is going to be honest, with every one of those spending commitments she should be saying where she is going to raise the revenue from. She should also be saying `Tax, tax, tax.' Of course you do not hear that from the Australian Labor Party. You only hear this milk of human kindness. You do not hear where the money is going to come from. In the words of a recent film which resonated with many of us: `Show me the money.' I say to the member for Jagajaga, `Show me the money.'

As we look at that quick survey of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, at the virtual bankruptcy of each of those states, the falling credit rating, the rising taxes, the rising rates of inflation and the rising rates of unemployment, we see this very consistent pattern which was completely reproduced with the Labor government when Bob Hawke was elected in the same yearâ1983âas Brian Burke in Western Australia and had, as it turned out, a very consistent record. We had a situation where in the last six years of the Labor government at the Commonwealth level we had a run-up of Commonwealth debt of nearly $80,000 million. That is a figure with so many zeros that my ordinary constituents in Parramatta, like me, have difficulty comprehending its magnitude. $80 billion in debt in six years. That is Labor's record of economic management.

The member for Jagajaga talks about the `horror' budget of 1996. What did she want us to do? To continue in this pattern of profligacy in which future generations of Australians were getting more and more indebted for goods and services they would never see or receive? Or did she want us to take the hard decision? Did she want us to take the right decision and resolve that we would put the Commonwealth's books back into balance? That is precisely what we decided to do.

When we came to power we had to raise $9 billion in taxes every year just to pay the government's interest bill on its debtâ$9 billion a year from the Turkish bloke in the kebab shop in Parramatta mall who is there at the crack of dawn, working in front of that hot fire all day in the most unpleasant conditions. He and his wife are in there from dawn till dusk trying to build a better future for their kids. We are having to take $9 billion from his tax revenue in order to pay the interest on Labor's debt. We said that that was not good enough. So in year 1, 1996, we did produce a tough budget and I do not apologise for it. I do not think future generations of unborn Australians will criticise us for it. They will congratulate us because we did what the former government was not prepared to do and that was take the hard decisions.

Today I want to touch on the psychological impact of this revolution in public finances which the Howard-Costello government has presided over. After seeing Australia slip further and further in virtually any international ranking you want to nameâwhether it is savings or standard of livingâwe have seen a change in the psychology in the same way that we saw this extraordinary change in the psychology of Victorians after the election of the Kennett government where, for the first time, there was a spring in the step, a returning self-confidence, a belief that Victoria had a future. We are starting to see this magnified across the nation as a whole as a consequence of the renewed prestige and status which Australia is enjoying in the international community following the extraordinary economic performance of this government.

I want to take one sentence from the Treasurer's speech when he delivered this year's budget. He referred to the fact that we had to raise $9 billion in taxes just to pay the government's interest bill. He said:
In those four Budgets, in net terms, we have not borrowed a dollar.

I want the chamber to reflect on that fact. If you say to me that Labor racked up $80 billion in debt in its last six years: how much debt have we racked up in our last three years? We have not, in net terms, had to borrow a single dollar of taxpayer liability in order to fund these budgets. In fact, on the contrary, we have actually repaid $24 billion of Labor's debt. Now that is an extraordinary achievement by any fair-minded person's estimation.

By 2002-03, we could repay all of Labor's debt and the Commonwealth could be debt free. We could begin the next century as we began this one with no Commonwealth debt, with a clean sheet and no interest bill to pay. And this is the critical sentence. We would have the chance to lower taxes and build better opportunities for our people. Surely, that is what government is aboutâbuilding better opportunities for our people. This is a simple unvarnished but clear statement of purpose from this coalition government.

If you go through the record of achievement, it could go on and on, but I want to turn now to the question: where do we go from here? What do we do now that we have achieved this new psychology of savings and a new psychology of surplus which is infecting the broader community? You see this extraordinary situation where the opposition in question time gets up each day and their principal thrust of attack is: are we going, that is, is this government going to have to dip into this miraculous surplus that it has created in order to fund the adjusted tax reform package put to the Australian Democrats? Their principal preoccupation is: are you going to have to dip into the surplus? As if it is some heinous accusation to dip into the surplus that we have created in order to fund our modernised, restructured, fairer, simpler tax package. We have fought tooth and nail at every moment for this surplus. The member for Jagajaga gets up in the chamber and continues to fight tooth and nail at every point in the budget process. Then the opposition has the gall to turn around and say, `Are you going to dip into the surplus to fund your brand spanking new modernised tax system?'

This is an opposition which is bereft of ideas, which has lost its way, which faced a critical moment after it got so crushed in the 1996 election. They took the member for Holt, Mr Evans, and said, `Okay, Gareth, you are going to be in charge of remaking the Australian Labor Party. Your job is going to be to find that spark of policy and intellectual renewal which is going to allow the Australian Labor Party to become part of the mainstream debate, to re-win its place in the hearts of the Australian worker, to take a place as a credible alternative government.'

And so Gareth went away with his colleagues and they consulted widely, chatted within their various caucuses and wrote their books. He came back at the end of the process, and to the great disappointment of many in politics, not just in the Australian Labor Party, he said, `It simply would not be credible to present ourselves as a different kind of outfit,' and that is virtually a direct quote.

Ever since, Labor has been locked in this reactionary culture that lacks innovation, in fact that tries to block innovation at every turn, where we, on the conservative side of politics, have become the reformers. We have become the idealists and the progressives, dealing all the time with the reactionary and conservative Australian Labor Party. That is the challenge for the ALP. Do they want to be part of the debate? Do they want to contribute or do they want to be locked in this eddy, in this rut, in this philosophical vacuum, which does not seem to have any future at all?

The Treasurer in his remarks said that the next decade could be a special one for Australia, and I agree. After having laid this foundation, he said that we could be looking at a step up in growth, jobs, community infrastructure, services for those in need, living standards, leading the region and in many respects leading the world.

Some people say, `You are always concerned about these economic issues; you are always concerned about economic management; you are always talking about fiscal restraint.' I want to highlight the fact that every one of our economic goals is nothing more and nothing less than a proxy for our human and social objectives to create a more prosperous and a fairer Australia. That is our objective. In that sense, I suspect that both sides of politics have more in common than separates them, but the critical difference is how you get there. Labor believes in ministers writing large cheques and glowing press releases, talking about compassion, equity and social justice, and damn the consequences for debt, taxes, inflation, interest rates and future generations of Australians.

We believe there are no short cuts. We believe it does not matter what the language of compassion is in the press release if you cannot fund it in the budget. We believe that it is not just this generation and this election that you have to be thinking about, but the next oneâthe next generation, the next century. We believe that it matters that Standard and Poor's decided in the last couple of weeks to lift Australia's credit rating from AA to AAA, because that means we can fund whatever expenditures we need more cheaply, and that means there is more of the cake left over at the end to look after those who really need it. That is the nature of social justice.

Social justice is academic if there is nothing left over at the end of the day to share around. It is academic if you can divide up the cake in beautifully equal shares, but the cake is so small that you cannot do anything for pensioners, for those who are carers of people with severe disabilities. When the Treasurer says that we can now lift our services for those in need, that is what he is talking about.

If we look at the area of disability, this is where I would love to see us do something more fundamental over the next four, five, 10 years. It is true that the Commonwealth put $1.7 billion into the Commonwealth-state disability agreement this year. That is a substantial amount of money in anybody's language. But other members on both sides of the chamber will have shared my experience of meeting a constituent who is a carer, often a parent of a child with profound disability, whether it is physical, intellectual or sometimes a combination of both. There are still over a million Australians suffering with either profound or severe disability. The carers are knocking themselves out to try to provide some sort of quality of life for those young Australians. Many of them are in very dire circumstances. They are deeply stressed.

There is a great shortage of respite care. There is a shortage of shared group housing that has been tailor built and designed for people with a disability. All over the country we know that these are not people who are trying to rort the system. There is no debate about the morals; there is no debate about the worthiness of the cause. The simple problem is that there is not enough of the surplus left at the end of the day to do for these people what we should be able to do for them. That is why a former British Prime Minister said to the trade union movement of Great Britain, `If you want a German standard of living, you have to have a German standard of productivity.' That is what we have been saying to the Australian people and the Australian economy. If we want to be able to generate the kind of surpluses that would build respite care facilities for carers of those with disabilities and for people suffering disabilities, we have to have an economy which actually generates a surplus. There has to be something left at the end of the day. That is what this budget and the three that preceded it have been all about.

There are lots and lots of things I would like us to be able to do. If you want to talk about infrastructure, I would love us to be able to more generously fund the Darwin to Alice Springs to South Australia or Darwin to Melbourne rail link. I would love to see that whole inland to eastern seaboard opened up to economic development. I would love to see that kind of decentralisation. I would love us to build the orbital route connecting the highways around Sydney to make it a more livable city. I would love us to be able to take the European carp out of Australian rivers.

People talk to me occasionally about doing the really bold visionary things, like turning the Clarence the other way and sending it inland and doing something about the 70 per cent of this vast continent which is a desert. I am not an engineer. I do not know whether it is possible or not. What I know at the moment is that we cannot afford to even take a look at it. They look back to the Snowy Mountains scheme and say, `When are we going to have a government prepared to do something like that again?'

I say that this government is now looking at a new decade, a new culture. We are looking at a new psychology: a psychology of savings, a psychology of surplus. We are looking at the opportunity to provide better services for those in need, a rise in our living standards, to lead the region and, in many respects, lead the world. That is my commitment to the Liberal Party, to this government. My view is that there is no short cut. While it is true that we live in a community, not an economy, unless the economy is productive you cannot deliver the quality of goods and services to people in need.

That is what this budget is all about. There are many other individual aspects of it which are commendable. I would like to see us, however, abolish every legislated impediment to national savings. We have got to lift national savings as we look forward, but we cannot do it if we are scrimping and saving and have our backs to the wall for every dollar that we are looking for.

I want to congratulate the Treasurer. It is an unbelievable achievement. When Keating was in power, Asia had an eight per cent growth factor and we had the recession we had to have. With Peter Costello as Treasurer and Asia in recession, Australia is leading the world in economic growth. It is an extraordinary achievement. I congratulate the Prime Minister and the Treasurer.

talk.start.para: âThank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I welcome the opportunity to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 and associated bills. It is traditional to say that one welcomes the opportunity to speak on bills when getting up to commence an address, but on this occasion it really is a valuable opportunity for me because it gives me the opportunity to highlight once again the glaring inadequacy of the government's approach to the future requirements of Australia in the areas for which I have responsibility on behalf of the opposition, that is, the areas of industry and technology.

speech.para: In these areas I shadow two ministers, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin, and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Their positions are slightly different and the response to each of them needs to be slightly different accordingly. I think an accurate description of Senator Alston is to say that he is all talk and no action. That would not be an accurate description of Senator Minchin. He is no talk and no action.

The sad thing about Senator Minchin is this, really: everybody in Australia knows he never wanted to be industry minister in the first place, and it is patently obvious he is not the slightest bit interested in the job. We all saw the publicity after the election when Senator Minchin and Mr Howard were trying to force Mr Fahey out of the Finance portfolio and put Senator Minchin in there. Probably that is where his heart really liesâin the Finance portfolio. It is obvious that it is not in the industry portfolio.

I continue to get representatives of industry and industry associations saying to me in surprise after they have been to see the minister, `He did not seem to be the slightest bit interested in the things we had to say.' It is quite common around this place, of course, that when people have been to see the minister they go and see the shadow minister. It is quite a common occurrence. They come in some amazement and say, `If you want to go and see the minister and talk about the monarchy against the republic, or the internal politics of the Liberal Party in South Australia, you will have his rapt attention, but once you start to talk to him about industry and technology, his eyes glaze over. He is not interested.' This is reflected in this budget.

When you search for the initiatives in the industry area, when you search for any action at all, you find nothing. The only thing you could bring within the ambit of industry is the extra funding for medical science research and biotechnology. My colleague the shadow minister for health dealt with the objective reality of those circumstances, but for the purpose of this conversation let me say that nobody can say it is a bad thing to spend more money on health and medical researchâand I do notâbut that is an initiative essentially driven by the Minister for Health and Aged Care within the health portfolio. In the industry area, there is nothing. On the issues of concern about industry beyond and outside the budget, we hear nothingâor, in recent times, worse than nothingâas it relates to the crucial issue of research and development.

Senator Alston, on the other hand, does tend to talk about the issues that the industry is concerned with. On 21 May he spoke to the Queensland branch of the Australian Information Industry Association about issues to do with information technology and challenges and opportunities for the new millennium. He outlined a series of challenges facing Australia's IT industry and I think he got a lot of them right. He spoke about our high communication equipment trade deficit; about the need to concentrate on growing in an export oriented Australian IT industry; about the capital gains tax; about the fact we are not extracting maximum long-term commercial benefits from Australian investment in research and development. He referred to the importance of education as a key element in a successful, high technology society, and he referred to the crisis facing the IT industry in the area of skills and recruitment.

There might be other issues you could add, but those issues are serious concerns for the IT industry and I am sure people were pleased to hear the minister outline them as his concerns. But, sadly, when you read the rest of the speech, after the outline of the analysis of the problems, and when you look at the budget, you find nothingâa lot of talk but no action.

There is a role in society for people who analyse the problems that are facing an industry. Academics do that very well and journalists often do it. The responsibility of those of us who are in public life is to go one step further, to answer the `and therefore' question. Having done the analysis, what is our response? How do we answer the `and therefore' question?

Let us look at this budget. It contains no extra funding for IT science and research to match that in the area of medical scienceânothing at all. There is no action to assist with the trade deficit or the export orientation of the sectorânothing at all. We have no action on the capital gains tax, despite the offer of bipartisan support to make changes; no action to improve on extracting commercial benefits from our R&Dâin fact, we subsequently find we are going backwardsâand no action about our education and training problems in the sector. They still suffer the burden of the ridiculous decision of the government to introduce a differential and higher rate of HECS on students in science and engineering.

It is as if the government does not believe that the market system works in education. It does not believe that, if you put up the price of something, you may deter people from buying it. Or the government does not believe education in science and engineering is important. They are the only two explanations, because the government clearly made a conscious decision to make choosing an education in science and engineering more expensive. The inevitable consequence is that we have this serious shortfall in science and engineering education.

Just last week the Australian Bureau of Statistics confirmed that, while I am concerned that in a lot of areas nothing is happening, in some areas it is worse than nothing. The Bureau of Statistics released data showing the continuing decline in business investment in research and development. The government saysâand I agreeâthat the drivers of modern economic growth are innovation and investment. For that very reason, around the world, governments are seeking ways to increase business investment in research and development. Alone in the developed world, the Australian government is withdrawing support, reducing assistance.

Why is anybody surprised that there is a continuing decline in business investment in research and development? It was the inevitable consequence of the crazy decision by the government in 1996 to cut the R&D tax concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. Once again it is as if the government does not believe in market signals, or it does not believe investment in research and development is important. You reduce the incentive; you make something comparatively more expensive; you get surprised when less of it is supplied. It was the inevitable consequence of the decision, and the ramifications of the government's short-sighted attitude are flowing through.

My message to this minister is that, if the government did not set out to achieve that outcome, it was stupid to make the decision in the first place, because it was the inevitable consequence. If the government did set out to reduce business investment in research and development, that is wantonly irresponsible and reckless, showing a lack of serious concern for the future of the Australian economy and the Australian industry.

No sensible picture of the Australian economy and Australian society in the year 2010 can be optimistic about the future without continuing improvement in business investment in research and development. We have the stunning attitude expressed on Saturday morning's AM program by the Minister for Industry, Science and Resourcesâso complacentâwhen asked, `Do you think the government needs to do anything in this?' He said, `No, we don't need to do anything.'

After 15 years of consistent improvement, thanks to initiatives taken by John Button, Australia's business investment in research and development had nearly got up to the OECD averageâwith steady improvement, from the bottom of the ruck we nearly got up to the middle. That is not exactly cause for celebration, but it is progress.

Having nearly got there, what did the government do? It cut back support so that business expenditure in research and development started to fall again. Australia's place in the ranking order of business investment in this vital area is falling. What did the government promise before it was elected? It promised to lift our place in the ranking because it was not high enough. Yet it cut the support, expenditure is falling and our place in the international pecking order is falling.

In spite of the fanfare about the improvement in expenditure on health and medical research, there is a continuing decline in Commonwealth support for research and development overall. With the cutsâcuts to the tax concession, cuts to universities, cuts in other areas of support, and the continuing attack on the Australian Geological Survey Organisationâthe net Commonwealth contribution to research and development continues to fall, while the government's policies mean that the business contribution also continues to fall.

We are at the bottom level of the OECD's scale and falling. What is the government's response? We heard it in the little diatribe of the member for Parramatta. It is an obsession with the GST. This tax is such an obsession with the government that it fails to address other vital issues for the future of our economyâissues which are much more important than whether or not we have a GST.
