If you believed this government's agenda, you would think that the most important issue facing Australia is how we tax each other. Yet the evidence from around the world does not show that enhanced economic growth is a consequence of such changes to the tax system.

Surely, how we employ each other is more important than how we tax each other. Surely, how we generate ideas, innovation and investment to create a successful, healthy and wealthy society in 2010 is more important than fulfilling the Prime Minister's nostalgic urge to achieve the tax goal that Malcolm Fraser stopped him from achieving in 1982. Yet, to achieve this goal, the government is frittering away the surplus which would otherwise be available for investing in our futureâin science, research and development, innovation, venture capital, enhancing design standards, improving education, training and infrastructureâso that we could create a more efficient, effective economy for the 21st century.

As if that is not enough, the government has failed to address the serious transition issues facing industry as a result of the introduction of this new tax systemâfor example, the serious transition issues facing the automobile industry, the housing industry and the IT industry. There are serious concerns in the IT industry about a freeze in computer hardware sales in the months preceding the introduction of the GST. Software and IT services face the opposite problem. They are currently sales tax free, so the cost of software and services will go up by close to 10 per cent because there is not much offset. There will be a sales peak in the lead-up to the GST and a drop in purchases after 30 June. What reaction do we get from the government to that? Nothing.

There are serious concerns in the automobile industry about the disruption which will be caused by these transitional arrangements. There has been no satisfactory response. There has been only a facile and inadequate response to the problems of the housing industry. Caught up in this is the question of the way that business taxation has been inadequately addressed. I refer to an article which I read recently in Company Director, the journal of the Institute of Company Directorsâand that institute is not renowned as a bunch of Labor Party supportersâwhich echoed the concerns that the shadow treasurer, the member for Hotham, and I have been expressing about the government's approach to the investment and tax trade-off. I refer to volume 15, No. 4 of May 1999 of the journal. At pages 30 and 31, it says:
We want to have a look at the costings involved. We need to be internationally competitive and get investment into this country.

That is talking about the concern we expressed that there has been no modelling and no indication of how this accelerated depreciation tax rate trade-off is going to affect Australia overall, industry by industry, or region by region. It went on to say:

The bottom line is that we want more costings to be convinced that in the interests of all our members, it is right to go 30, 33 or 36 percent corporate tax rate . . . We don't know without the costings . . .

That is absolutely correct. It is an important argument. It is a very serious thing that the government is proceeding in this way without the data. We have heard nothing from the government about modelling or about analysis of the relative benefits of the business tax models which are being put forward.
Secondly, the journal of the Institute of Company Directors put sensible weight on the need for investment in traditional areas, as well as new areas. They said at page 30:
It happens that Australia has great competitive advantage in those areasâ
of agriculture and miningâ
Therefore why devise a tax system that is going to disadvantage those areas?

I must say it is a very interesting argument for the National Party to be pursuingâpurporting to represent regional Australia and yet being caught up in a debate about a tax policy that is likely to disadvantage the great resource based industries of regional Australia. But the key element of the AICD's critique on the matter is as follows:
The reality is that we need to attract investment to all sectors of the economy; it is a matter of striking the right balance.
Then they turn, in what I consider a very intelligent and broad analysis, to say that we must recognise that the national interest is more than the sum of all the individual company interests:
Even if the majority of companies would be better off with 30 percent, that does not necessarily equate to the national interestâparticularly the balance of paymentsâbeing better served . . .
They went on:

Whether or not particular projects proceed in Australia may not affect individual companies but it will have a major impact on the balance of payments and, via the multiplier effect, on employment; all primary and capital intensive industry is critically important especially to the balance of payments, whereas there is little concrete evidence so far to suggest that a reduction in the corporate tax rate will cause additional investment to proceed in the services sector . . .

I come back to the point that the government itself says growth is driven by innovation and investment. We are lagging behind on the innovation front, and there are serious concerns about where this business tax reform might take us in the issue of investment, where we are going to get investment and how it is going to be effectively distributed. The AICD went on to say:
One of our other concerns with any tax reduction is the relationship to revenue neutrality. There are a number of other measures that we strongly endorse and these cannot always be revenue neutral.

As the Leader of the Opposition has been saying over and over again, the tax bribes and expenditure bribes associated with trying to sugarcoat the bitter pill of the GST have forced the business tax review into a straightjacket of revenue neutrality, creating a potentially adverse outcome for the long-term future of the nation.

In conclusion, I would like to refer to a very important series of comments made in a recent seminar conducted by the Centre for Australian Studies at the Institute of Commonwealth Studies at the University of London, where an Australian who was there on secondment conducted a seminar and published a book called Raising Economic GrowthâIndustry Development Strategies. The publication raises a number of important issues, but in the time available I just want to refer to two of them. The OECD Secretary-General, Mr Don Johnson, in opening the proceedings, said:
The key issue is the adjustment processes. Countries cannot avoid the pressures for changeâthey need to embrace them and seek the benefits . . .
Of course, that is true, but, importantly, he went on to say:
. . . for change to be embraced, people need to be convinced the benefits are being shared.

It is crystal clear that, the way the competition policy is being managed, the way the tax debate is being managed, the way the discussion is going on about business tax changes and the way in which expenditure cuts have been made, Australians do not believe that the benefits are being shared equally and fairly, and this is being exacerbated by changes in the industrial relations area. The government should give this issue some attention, instead of continuing to focus on tax changes for the top end of town, industrial relations changes which make workers feel more insecure, and cuts to services in regional and rural Australia and in those areas of the cities in greatest need.

Mr Johnson's theme was reinforced by the secretary to the department of industry from the country of the so-called European miracle, Ireland, who said that the overwhelming factor that underpinned the transformationâthat is, the transformation in Irelandâwas a consensus across a broad spectrum of the population about the extent of the problem and the actions required to solve them. Then he went on:
. . . the critical element was a 3 year social partnership agreement amongst the government employers and unions . . .
He further said:
. . . and the government had targeted its expenditure to transport, infrastructure, education and training and research and development.

All I can say is: there are lessons in this for Australia and for the government. There are lessons about consensus, about bringing people along with the important process of reform and change, about social partnership, about transport infrastructure, about education and training, and about a focus on research and development. Sadly, this budget shows they are not listening and they are not learning.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I take pleasure in standing before you to make a contribution, as have many of my colleagues, on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 and associated bills. I refer to the success that is the 1999-2000 federal budgetâa budget for everyone. The budget will benefit the family, the poor, the rich, the sick, the healthy, the urban dwellers and, closest to my heart, the people of rural Australia, and, more specifically, the Hume electorate.

speech.para: This budget is proof the federal coalition government is committed to continuing to reverse the savage mauling of our economy which the former Labor government created in 13 years of incompetent management. In saying the `savage mauling of our economy', I refer to the horrendous debt that the coalition has been slowly eradicating through patient commitment to responsibly managing the best interests of the country and, more importantly, removing the burden of debt from future generations of Australians. This government will halve by 2000-01 the net debt to GDP ratio, and in 1999 will repay $20.5 billion which it inherited from the incompetent poor excuse for an oppositionâthe Australian Labor Party.

I clearly remember the release of the 1995-96 budget and the revelation by the newly elected coalition that Labor's mismanagement of Australia's economy had left behind a deficit of $4.9 billion. In March of that year, the then Minister for Finance, the current Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, refused to announce updated budget figures in an attempt to hide this massive deficit blow-out. I can also recall the coalition's drastic response to this blow-out: our Prime Minister announcing that the government would have to make budget cuts to the level of $8 billion over the following two years to try to salvage what had been lost through an uncaring and economically dumb government.

Look at us now. The world has seen a huge economic shake-up with the Asian economic crisis. While figures and trends in a majority of countries have been affected by this downfall, Australia is holding its own. Here is a budget which has swung from a $4.9 billion deficit in 1996 to a $5.4 billion surplus in the budget year 1999-2000. Nobody can deny that this government is an economic success. This budget will benefit the constituents of the electorate of Hume in a number of ways, and for that I am thankful.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 5.48 p.m. to 5.58 p.m.

talk.start.para: âHowever, I am not in the business of exaggerating the triumphs of this government. Indeed, we have a long way to go. I am still concerned about regional health. I am still troubled about the percentage of people who abuse drugs and the harm minimisation thrust of groups who are assisting in the expansion of the illicit drug trade in the community. I have been concerned about those drugs for about 11 years now. Over that period of time I have made some considerable criticism about the needle exchange program.

speech.para: I was interested to read an article in the News Weekly on 13 February of this year. The article, written by Dr Lucy Sullivan, and headed `Needle exchange programs: why they fail', gives me great heart that I am not the only person concerned about this needle exchange program. The article says:

The picture of a pre-teenage boy injecting heroin in Sydney allegedly near a needle dispensary has shocked authorities into a reconsideration of drugs policy in NSW. Providing free needles to users is one program that has come under scrutinyâand not before time says Dr Lucy Sullivan .
The data, she says, prove that as far as preventing infections is concerned, the program has been ineffectual.

Free distribution of needles for injection of illicit drugs was introduced in Australia in the late 1980s on the hypothesis that it would play an important role in the prevention of HIV transmission. Statistics in the United States appeared to indicate a significant link between injecting drug use and rates of HIV, and as HIV is transmitted via body fluids there was considerable face validity in favour of this hypothesis.

Only later was the extent of confounding of injecting drug use with homosexual activity identified. At the time, Australian statistics indicated injecting drug use as a very minor mode of HIV transmission, sexual contact between men being by far the major mode, but this did not preclude sharing of equipment by intravenous drug (IVD) users becoming a major mode of transmission if the disease became prevalent among them. Needle distribution, then, was introduced as a prophylactic measure, and its advocates have acclaimed its success, in that HIV has not become prevalent among IVD users.

Free needle distribution and exchange began officially in Sydney, where both HIV infection and IV drug use are concentrated, with a trial programme in 1987, which progressed to an improved programme in 1988, with similar programmes implemented in other States over the next few years. In New South Wales the number of public sector outlets grew from 40 in mid-1989 to 250 in 1994, in which year there were also 500 pharmacies offering a similar service.

There had been, however, ample time for the IV route of transmission to develop in Australia, as it had in the US, by the time of the development of the free needle programme, if it was to occur, and something more than continued low rates is needed to demonstrate the relevance of the strategy. Given the double standard in relation to the use of illegal drugs which needle distribution presents to the public, a serious assessment of its effectiveness is long overdue in order to substantiate its continuation.

The Annual Surveillance Report of the National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research, HIV/AIDS and Related Diseases in Australia 1997 , provides no evidence to support the importance of the free needle (or needle exchange) programme, and much to indicate its irrelevance to HIV infection in Australia.

Firstly, overall trends show no sign of a beneficial impact of the introduction of the free needle distribution. Annual HIV diagnoses fell rapidly from 2,600 in 1985 to 1,700 in 1988, in the era before free needles, but thereafter more slowly to 1,400 in 1991, 950 in 1994 and 850 in 1996.
If there is any sign of any impact of the introduction of needle distribution in 1988, it is of an interruption of a rapid decline.

The number of infections are attributed to IV use, both alone and in conjunction with homosexual activity, is too small to have had a detrimental impact of this size, so that if the effect was to decelerate the decline in infection rates, then this was only part of the contribution.

The deceleration is possibly a statistics gathering effect, resulting from delay in diagnosing infections acquired earlier in the epidemic. But equally there is no evidence in the rate of decline from 1988 to 1994 and thereafter to suggest any benefit from needle distribution.

"Most cases of HIV infection in Australia continue to be transmitted by sexual contact between men. There has been relatively little transmission through other sources of exposure" . . . 95% of HIV is in men, and over 85% of HIV transmission has been through homosexual contact. 8% of all HIV cases have occurred in injecting drug users, but half of these have also engaged in homo- or bisexual activity.
The article goes on to say, in part:
The numbers for documented newly acquired HIV infections via infected drug use in the years 1991 to 1996 were: 4, 10, 6, 6, 6, 4âwith again no obvious salutary effect of the free needle programme.
Furthermore, the article continues:

If needle distribution was successful in preventing the exchange of body fluids and thereby the transmission of infection, as was hypothesised as the grounds for its introduction, then one would expect to find it effective in preventing the transmission of other infections besides HIV. The rapid and exceptional spread of hepatitis C (like HIV, a blood-borne disease) among IVD users indicates that it has been ineffective in this regard. Indeed, the contemporaneous appearance of hepatitis C with the growth of needle distribution must appear an odd coincidence.
The article goes on to talk about how we have been conned by the needle exchange program, and I thought that was worth putting on the record tonight.

Let me return to the issue of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 . I am still sceptical about the success of attempts to control the current account deficit. Indeed, only last week it was announced that the current account deficit was at a four-year long high of $8.9 billion. Although not the fault of the federal government, it is still something that we need to watch. I am convinced that, as exports pick up next year, our current account deficit will drop. To counteract this disappointing announcement, during the March quarter of 1999 the Australian economy grew by 1.1 per cent and, through the year, by 4.8 per cent.

More importantly, this government is addressing those unwelcome impediments. The government is improving the living standards of Australians. It is improving relations with other countries and it is decreasing our debt. As we all know, the government announced this budget with a $5.4 billion surplusâthe third surplus in a row. We also know that, in net terms, we have stopped borrowing, which is a vital prerequisite for the sound and responsible management of our economy.

The government has injected funding into rural Australia which will address health, transport, employment, telecommunications and educational issues. Whilst the benefits which will flow to rural people from this funding boost are significant, they need to be ongoing and backed up by ensuring that the remaining government infrastructure is enhanced and protected so that rural communities can offer services essential to future business investment. We cannot continue the economic rationalisation of government infrastructure in rural Australia. By doing so, we push our young people out to the seaboards of our country and create massive problems within rural towns affected by the mindless social and economic acts of governments of all political persuasions.

I applaud the government for its commitment to providing funding of $250 million for its regional telecommunications infrastructure, Networking the Nation. Of particular interest to the electorate of Hume is that Boorowa Shire Council has been granted $100,000 to install a base station at Mount Canemumbola, which will give mobile coverage for the town and its immediate surroundings. More importantly, it will fill a black hole of communication critical to the basic lifestyle of isolated communities. Although I am appreciative of this grant, it seems peculiar that in an age of technology in telecommunications a rural community situated just 100 kilometres from the nation's capital is only now receiving mobile phone coverage.

This is only the beginning of my concerns about telecommunications in Australia. The conversion to digital receivers for mobile phones, while a necessary evil, poses many problems for my constituents. For some people, converting to digital means no reception at present. I refer to one particular case where a doctor in a rural area could not receive calls after converting to the digital system. You can imagine the consequences of that situation.

I am impressed that the government has had the initiative to allocate $630,000 for a program to explain the staged closure of analog mobile phones. At least this will not only attempt to make the transition to digital phones a little more bearable but, more importantly, it will allow time to plan for and to adjust to the new system. These types of measures show that our government is a thinking and concerned governmentânot so much concerned about what is happening far away but about what is happening in the engine room of our great country. This government has been listening and is obviously thinking about the impacts these changes will have on isolated communities. The government is also willing to monitor its own behaviour. This comes in the form of $304,000 for the Australian Communications Authority to conduct a review of the long-term cost effectiveness of telecommunications interception.

One of the most worrying institutions in New South Wales is health, and health in rural Australia has certainly been addressed by the Howard government. Retention payments for long-serving GPs in rural and remote areas have been allocated, with a commitment of $43.1 million to reverse the alarming decline in rural doctor numbers. The government is aware that there is a severe shortage of doctors in many parts of rural Australia and it has been working very hard to address this problem. There has already been significant progress.

The number of Medicare providers in 1998 increased by 11.5 per cent in remote areas and by 2.9 per cent in rural areas on the previous year. For capital city and other major urban areas, the increase was 0.8 per cent. These trends are confirmed when you look at changes in the number of full-time equivalent doctors, with an increase of 5.1 per cent in remote areas and 0.8 per cent in rural areas occurring over the same period. These figures reflect the large increase in the provision of locum support, as well as an increase in doctors living and working in the country.

Whilst these trends are positive, there is still a lot of work to be done. The government now has to put in place a comprehensive strategy to improve access to medical services in rural and remote areas, including a number of important recent initiatives announced by the federal government. An important element in the government's ongoing strategy has been the establishment of state based rural work force agencies to flexibly administer incentives for doctors, taking into account the needs of individual communities. In the 1998 budget the government committed an additional $13 million to these agencies, taking the total funding available for them to $65 million over four years.

The number of telephone calls and letters received by my office outlining horrific tales of hospitals and communities with no doctors, or hours-long travelling to obtain medical attention, are appalling. This budget will help to alleviate some of the problems faced by my constituents and residents of rural Australia. The construction and maintenance of regional health service centres will be made possible with a $40.8 million allocation in this year's budget. On a personal level, I have been working with the government to have one of these centres constructed in Batlow, just one of a number of smaller rural communities neglected by the Carr Labor government. I trust that the New South Wales state government will reverse its contempt of rural New South Wales and join with the federal government in making this regional health service centre at Batlow a reality.

Rural women's health issues have been of huge concern to the coalition, and certainly of concern to me and my wife, who has worked tirelessly on breast cancer in women for over a decade now. This government has physical evidence that the boys club mentality no longer exists. This government has honoured yet another election promise by allocating $4.1 million over four years to support women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer. As you know, the government has also provided financial assistance to encourage people to take out private health cover.

One of the most promising aspects of this appropriation bill is the government's commitment to upgrading roads in the Hume electorate in the interests of more efficient road transport and road safety. This funding will help to duplicate the Sheehan Bridge at Gundagai and to fund the construction of four lanes of the Hume Highway as far as the Sturt Highway junction near Tarcutta. The undertakings by the government to the Bookham bypass, at a cost of $65 million, and a $45.2 million injection into the $100 million upgrade of the Federal Highway south of Goulburn clearly demonstrate its commitment to reducing the road toll on our major highways.

Better roads mean fewer accidents, quicker trips between towns and cities and more efficient transportation of goods and services. I have a good relationship with local councils in my electorate and I can say with confidence that local government have been winners in this budget. The sum of $388.3 million in untied grants has been allocated to local governments to improve the quality of roads in their area. I know that local governments in Hume will have no trouble using this funding. As someone who spends a lot of time travelling, I can say that the road system in rural New South Wales is in need of continual upgrading. The inability of councils to maintain these roads follows the Carr Labor government's reduction of the 3X3 state levy allocation percentage to rural New South Wales from 60 per cent to 40 per cent since it was elected in 1995. Local government in New South Wales is to receive over $408 million in Commonwealth financial assistance as a result of this 1999-2000 budget.

The most talked about impending change in economic history has escaped comment from me up until this point, and there are reasons for this. Firstly, the government's proposed tax reform, while an important step to alleviate many of the burdens to the taxpayer, and which has already taken effect in this year's budget, is only part of what is truly an astounding budget. Secondly, no matter how we, as coalition members of the House of Representatives, try to explain to other parties the merits of the GST, the Australian Labor Party will continue to play an obstructive, negative and selfish role, rather than taking a sensible bipartisan approach to making our country the envy of the rest of the world. Thirdly, I have to add that the Labor Party's attempt at a scare campaign by suggesting that the diesel fuel credits will be open to rorting and that there are uncertainties in relation to the proposal was nothing short of a spineless and futile attempt to discredit the government's commitment to assist rural industries in becoming more realistically competitive, both domestically and internationally.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence. I am proud to have entered federal politics in a term which can boast economic credentials including a reduction in debt, a $5.4 billion surplus and a boost to rural health, roads and education for this great country of ours.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker Quick, I apologise for mentioning one of my local clubs in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 . You may think it is inappropriate, but I have been wanting to make this contribution for some time. I am referring to the St Mary's District Band Club and, in particular, to a competition that they have been running for some 25 years nowâthe Ern Keller Memorial Trophy for soloists.

speech.para: This year the competition was held on Sunday, 21 February. I must say that I was very pleased to again be there. In the history of this trophy, two competitors have won it three times: New Zealand's Errol Mason in 1976, 1978 and 1981, and Victoria's Christina Bowden in 1987, 1988 and 1994. I congratulate the club because I think it is a tremendous effort to promote music in the western suburbs of Sydney. They have done a fantastic job. Ten years ago there was a band competition as well.

I am very proud to stand here as a federal member from the western suburbs of Sydney. If you do not come from Sydney's west you perhaps do not understand why I would say that to you with such a feeling of pride. The western suburbs of Sydney has 11 federal electorates. With the redistribution, it is likely to have 12 federal electorates; there is likely to be a new seat created in Sydney's west. The population figures are, I think, very interesting. I shall quote the figures. In 1999 in the greater west we have a population of 1.7 million people. In the rest of SydneyâI have to say `the rest of Sydney' because statistically that includes Gosford and Wyong which is, I think, inappropriateâexcluding Gosford and Wyong there are 2,039,000 people. By the year 2017, western Sydney will be bigger than the rest of Sydney. It is projected that the population will be 2,541,000 and that the population of the rest of Sydney will be 2,438,000. As each year goes on this difference will become more pronounced.

You could say, `So what?' If you were to shift western Sydney west, you would have a great case for making it a state because of its huge population. The GDP of western Sydney is today $34 billion. In 2011, it will be $46 billion. Indeed, I am one of those great optimists in western Sydney who believe we can do a lot better than what we are doing and that we can better those projections, but we could certainly be a state.

I am not allowed to be seditious. I would be quite happy to lead a secessionist movement. I feel that, like a number of causes I embrace, it might not be too successful. But I need to remind the House that, really, in a whole variety of ways, western Sydney is a huge area and a unique area. Whilst I am very proud that, at the state level, the Australian Labor Party has wall-to-wall cabinet ministers who hail from Sydney's west, Sydney's west is in dire need of winning federal Labor seats, yet we have only one shadow minister, which is, I think, a disappointment. That is not to reflect on Laurie Ferguson, who is a good friend of mine and does a sterling job. But if we are serious in saying that western Sydney is our heartland, our homeland, then I think that needs to be reflected a little bit better.

I did not want to have to digress to some of the contributions by Mr Ross Cameron, the member for Parramatta. For example, I think the Australian people are really sick and tired of when government members say, `Oh, yes, you left us with a deficit of $10.8 billion,' and then we retort, `Yes, but in 1983 that was $9.6 billion, worth $25 billion today.' I do not believe that the public thinks that this adds constructively to the debate. I guess there is one figure I thought I should quote to the honourable member for Parramatta. There are a few economic indicators I think we can be proud of. There is no doubt that breaking that cycle of inflation has happened and that it has been continued by the government. I think they certainly deserve a lot of credit for that, and I hope it will continue as a bipartisan policy.

But there are areas of real concern. The national debtâthat is, what we owe overseas peopleâis a huge problem. It has absolutely jumped in three years. It is $241 billion. I do not think it is necessarily a fair way of portraying it, but I must say that, when in opposition, Mr Howard always used to say, `This means, under Labor, every man, woman and child owes. . . ' Well, let me give you the figure. It is $13,056.40. Every man, woman and child owes that amount. If you want to extrapolate that into an electorate like Chifleyânot one of the densest, that is, most highly populated, areas or electorates; I think I have about an average enrolment and that the non-enrolled people are not significantly differentâlet me tell you what it is. It is $1,809,708,434.80. That is a lot of dough. In one electorate, that is what it means. I invite honourable coalition members to extrapolate the population figures of Australia, the national debtâget the figure that ABS are usingâand do the sums. As I said, this was something that the now Prime Minister, then leader of the opposition, did. I do not think it is a particular helpful thing to do, but it does highlight that we have a major problem.

I know the honourable member for Port Adelaide is in the House. He will recall that when we were in officeâand figures do bounce aroundâwe certainly racked up some current account deficits. But the pleasing thing that we were able to do was to really work at what is now called international trade or merchandised trade, and that is that we used to either have a balance of trade there or rack up surpluses. What happens is that when you add dividends going overseas, interest and a whole variety of other things, you run into a current account deficit. But in terms of merchandised trade, in terms of international trade, the term that is now used, that was basically either in balance or in surplus. It is massively now into deficit, alarmingly into deficit. It is one quarter's figures. I said alarming but I should say disturbingâthat is a more accurate description.

For Labor, the heart and soul of economic policy is really savings and investment for us. Ironically, the coalition put national savings on the agenda when they were in opposition. I think one of the proudest things that we did was to introduce superannuation, a significant way of adding to private savings and helping national savings.

When we are talking about the tax package and what we are going to give back to Mr and Mrs Australia, you need to remember a couple of things. Not one dollar has been returned in three years of bracket creep, not one dollar. For me that is disappointing. I think that a national superannuation policy is so important and I wish it were one area where we could put aside our political differences and work towards policy development which neither side would seek to overturn. No matter who was in government, we would be working together because it is so important.

But the promised $3.2 billionâI think it wasâgoing into national superannuation for every working class Australian from the federal government was not delivered. It is true it was a forward commitment of the Labor government. It is also true to say that Mr Costello, before the 1996 election, said that he would honour it. But he did not and that has made a huge dent in superannuation.

The question I am asking is this: in three years what happened to bracket creep? The government kept all the dough. The government had a commitment to give $3.2 billion back to Australian taxpayers into their individual superannuation funds and accounts, making themâand I concede thisâcompulsorily save for their future. What happened to that? It was clawed back: not given; not honoured. A great disappointment.

National savings is so important because it fuels and funds investment and it is from investment that we get jobs. I suppose another area is in research and development. If you are spending money on research and spending money on commercialising products of that research, you are really talking about what you are generating into the future, and that is jobs. It is like a long-term investment plan, if you like. You have to do it today to reap the benefits tomorrow and, of course, that was cut back. But it is investment that fuels private enterprise. It is investment that will deliver us the jobs.

The record to date has been disappointing. In fact, if we are looking at, sayâand it is a difficult barometer, I admit thatâthe long-term unemployed, there are now more long-term unemployed people, not fewer, after three years of a coalition government. Of course, everyone involved in dealing with and trying to meet the needs and aspirations of long-term unemployed will tell you that the longer you are out of the work force, the harder it is to get back. That is why, in a sense, you need to spend so much money upfront, investing, if you will, in the long-term unemployed to get them back into the work force. That is a very alarming figure.

There were a few other things that I was hoping to raise. I found it amusing that the honourable member for Parramatta, whom I have a regard for, was concerned about a phrase that is being used currently, that is, that we live in a society and not just in an economy. He was affronted by that. We on the Labor side do not diminish the arguments about the need to stimulate and run a sound economy but, at the end of the day, it has to serve the people and it has to serve all of the people, not just some. Perhaps that is where we have a real philosophical difference. On the coalition side, I suppose they see it in terms of winners and losers and if you ain't a winner, tough. We say that to have a meaningful and stable society, to have individuals participating with a sense of self-worth and decency, then everyone has to be a winner and actively involved. We cannot cut out any one person from our concerns as far as the economy is concerned.

I would have thought it could be shown in a very real way that by and large, over those 13 years, in a period of some turbulence, Labor did not do too bad a job in managing the economy. There are some things we could have done a lot betterâno argument about thatâbut we were an innovative and an adaptive government in those 13 years.

I do not apologise for saying that I am one who very much wants to embrace the notion that we live in a society. Yes, the economy is very important, but at the end of the day it needs, like everything else, to serve the peopleâjust as this parliament needs to serve the people. It is not an end in itself. We want the very best things to happen in this parliament, but that is not an end in itself. It gains relevance only to the extent to which all people benefit from it. I say to the honourable member for Parramatta that perhaps I can understand his difficulty with it but there would be many of my constituents who would feel very strongly the other way and would rejoice in the notion that we live in a society and just not in an economy.

The honourable member for Parramatta was saying that he just loved infrastructure projects and he thought the Snowy Mountains was a wonderful project. I think it was, indeedâand I apologise for scoring a fairly cheap debating point, as I have tried to suggest others should not doâbut the Snowy Mountains scheme was bitterly opposed by the then conservative opposition. The great irony is that the Chifley Labor governmentâwhich I hope honourable members would understand is close to my heartâhaving instituted the program, it was the Menzies government that executed the scheme over so many years by means of the work of so many people 50 years ago. I offer my sincere congratulations to them.

I need to say a few things about the GST. In the promotion of the GST package there is talk about a fiscally neutral proposal. That is, notwithstanding all the money that is going to be raised by the GST, what is going to be given back is going to cost the forward estimates an additional $17 billion. Now, with the Democrats supporting a changed taxation package, there is an additional cost of $3 billion. I have pulled out figures for what is being collected in personal income tax, capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and customs and exciseâin this budget leading to a surplus of $5 billion. It is pretty hard to argue that this is a basket-case taxation system and that it is not functioning, not working, and has economic hardening of the arteries. I do not think that that is the case.

I regret particularly the way that this package is progressing, in that the real area of reformâbusiness taxation, where a number of things need to be addressedâlooks like being compromised or, alternatively, being strictly revenue neutral: `Give something up and we can replace it with something else.' People might say that that is fair enough, but at the end of the day we on this side of the House feel very strongly that savings and investment are important but it is actually the business community that we need to ensure is driving through to the future and creating jobs.

If we can make constructive changes in order to reform business taxation, that will lead to greater investment, greater efficiency and more jobs. I am 100 per cent for that, and Australia may be the poorer for our not being able to do it.(Time expired)

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.35 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 . I would like to address a few other subjects, with your concurrence, while I am on my feet this day.

speech.para: In the budget recently announced a couple of weeks ago there were many good news stories for regional and rural Australia. There were especially good stories for people who live in the seat of Parkes. One of the more pleasurable things I had to read was the number of dollars provided to the Royal Flying Doctor Service to fund their base in Dubbo. This funding was to the tune of $4.5 million, with $2 million as a capital grant to start off the program, followed by $500,000 per year for four years after that.

This service is enormously welcomed by the people in my electorate and in neighbouring electorates, especially in the towns of Bourke, Cobar, Wanaaring, Weilmoringle and Brewarrina. The benefit to these communities is absolutely enormous. The services already provided by the Royal Flying Doctor Service in the far west of New South Wales, Western Australia, Queensland, Northern Territory, South Australia and Victoria are already widely known for their professionalism and efficiency. There are many towns in my electorateâfor example, Tibooburra and White Cliffsâwhere the medical service provided by the Royal Flying Doctor Service is held in greater esteem and viewed as far more satisfactory than the medical services provided to towns much closer to the larger regions nearer Dubbo. Some of these towns also do not have a resident doctor, but they do not have the facility of a fly-in medical service.

Having the Royal Flying Doctor Service operate out of Dubbo will provide enormous benefits in the retrieval of sick patients. The hour after an accident is the most critical time. In many cases for a severely injured person that hour means the difference between life and death. We will be able to get people to hospital more quickly than by calling an air ambulance from Sydney, or by having the flying doctor fly from Broken Hill to Bourke, for example, to pick up a patient and then fly on to Dubbo. That is the most important time for the likely survival of the patient.

As far as the ongoing running costs of the Royal Flying Doctor Service go, having a base in Dubbo makes true economic sense. It will save an enormous amount of down time where the plane is in the air on its way to an accident or its way back to base from retrieving a patient. By having the base situated in Dubbo, the plane is able to fly from Dubbo out to Bourke, Walgett or Brewarrina and back and then, if necessary, to Sydney. This will be a lot more favourable to the flying doctors' budget than having a plane fly empty from Broken Hill to Bourke, pick up a patient, deliver them to Dubbo or Sydney and then fly empty all the way back to Broken Hill. Having the base in Dubbo is great not only for the patients but also for the ongoing benefit of the Royal Flying Doctor Service itself. The money that the service will save by not having so much wasted time in the air will mean that it can deliver more effective services to people.

But, aside from the actual service of retrieval provided by the flying doctors, a big plus from having a base in Dubbo will be the outreach services that can be provided to remote towns such as Bourke, Cobar and Brewarrina, especially if those towns are not serviced by a GP at the moment. If these towns do have a GP, the Royal Flying Doctor Service will be able to provide relief to the doctor working there. I know a lot of GPs are under constant pressure from working seven days a week, on call 365 days a year. They feel they do not have the ability to leave their town because of the gap that will be left. Having the flying doctor presence in Dubbo will provide a backup so those doctors will be free to travel away and have a much needed break. The opportunity to do this, in turn, will make the town a far more attractive place for doctors and their families to live in the west of New South Wales.

Another service that is provided by the Royal Flying Doctor Serviceâa service that was announced in the budgetâis the fly-in fly-out female GP service. This service is enormously welcomed by women in my electorateâthose who live in outlying areas. Some of them do have a GP in their town, but many of them do not. Those women who do have a GP would prefer a female GP to a male GP for many of those ladies type problems: breast screening, cancer screening, et cetera. So, in these regional areas, it is a luxury to have the fly-in fly-out female GP service. It is a luxury that many of the women in my electorate appreciate. The other big thing about having the Royal Flying Doctor Service operating out of Dubbo is that I believe it is the beginning of Dubbo becoming a medical hub.

A further great aspect of the budget that I warmly welcome, although it does not apply to my electorate, is the announcement of a clinical school to be established in Wagga Wagga. This clinical school will go a long way towards providing medical services to people in rural and regional Australia by exposing university medical students to the positive experience of living, working, attending lectures and working in the hospital there. I am sure that this will result in a lot of potential doctors staying in the country who might otherwise not have had that experience and therefore would have returned to the city or stayed in the city when they had finished their training.

I believe Dubbo also has a future as a medical hub in a different way from Wagga. I encourage the ministers and deans of the various universities to look more closely at establishing some form of clinical school, perhaps not in the same vein as that in Wagga Wagga but perhaps starting on a smaller scale. Dubbo already does medically service many of the towns in the surrounding areasâfor example, Cobar, Bourke, Brewarrina, Goodooga, Walgett, Gilgandra and Coonabarabran. All of those places focus their medical attention on Dubbo. The trouble is that we are in great danger of losing many of the specialist services that are already provided in Dubbo. We do not have the right number of obstetricians and gynaecologists, and we are losing anaesthetists. If we lose anaesthetists they will quickly be followed by surgeons. Our physicians in Dubbo are also reaching the stage where, in a few years time, they may think about retiring as well. Having a focus on a regional town as a provider of medical services will encourage a culture that will be attractive to specialist services. That in turn will attract GPs to the area, because they will feel that they have the backup that they need.

Having an Outreach post or a department of rural health from one of the universities will go a long way towards improving the standing of Dubbo as the professional centre by attracting senior people who will be able to lecture students and maintain a healthy and enjoyable professional practice. Success in attracting doctors will breed success. Dubbo's success will breed success in providing medical services to many outlying areas.

May I also congratulate the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business on the program he has announced for Aboriginal employment. My electorate has a great number of Aboriginal people, and $100 million over four years, specifically targeted, sensibly, at Aboriginal unemployment, is most welcome by all the communities in my electorate. The encouragement for them to invest in small business, the $4,000 paid to employ disadvantaged Aboriginal people, the encouragement for Aboriginal people to get off CDEP programs and into other real jobs, instead of just maintaining or being trapped in the CDEP program, is enormously welcome.

May I also congratulate the government in another areaâthat is, the $31.8 million funding for the capping of bores. The Great Artesian Basinâwhich I understand holds 22,000 times the amount of water contained in Sydney Harbourâcovers a big area in the north-west of my electorate. It is vital for the areas that rely on that water for irrigation purposes and watering of stock. Some of the natural springs have stopped flowing in the past, and bore water is wasted as it flows from uncapped and unpiped bore drains and meanders slowly across the plain, causing an artificial environment which feeds feral pigs and kangaroos and causes them to flourish in an area in which they do not naturally flourish. This has been a sad thing for me to see while driving around the electorate. By capping and piping the bores, this government has, along with the funding that it provides through West 2000, made it a very real option for farmers to preserve and maintain their water. This will cause a rejuvenation of natural springs and restore an ecologically natural environment.

Another area I would like to comment on is the kangaroo meat industry. I call on the government at this point to assist the kangaroo meat industry because they have, I believe, been unfairly penalised. The situation at present is that if providers of kangaroo meat for human consumption want to get their industry off the ground by providing the meat for exportâat a rate in the order of $12 per kilogramâthis will provide enormous export dollars for Australia. However, there has been a concerted war waged against these people by the animal welfare lobbyists. These lobbyists produce, manufacture and create false newsletters and videos that give a very adverse impression of what happens in the real kangaroo meat industry. The irony of it is that, in the kangaroo meat industry, licences are only issued to shooters who are accredited. These shooters can only shoot a kangaroo with a head shot and every kangaroo is monitored, tagged and accounted for.

These are the people that the lobbyists are trying to close down. They do not pay any attention to the culling of kangaroos by farmersâwho, I admit, also have to get special permission and tag their kangaroos. But because farmers are not experts, they might put three, four, five or six bullets into a kangaroo, which might hop off into the bush and die a slow and painful death. The bodies of these kangaroos cannot be used; they are just left to rot. However, the animal welfare groups specifically target those who are trying to get the kangaroo meat industry off the ground and treat the kangaroos in the most humane manner.

I would ask the ministers responsible for these areas to help defend these industries when they are under threat because they will provide jobs and huge export dollars for Australia, given a fair go. But at the moment they are very loath to invest any sort of money when there is a strong likelihood that a concerted public relations campaign will be waged by welfare lobbyists. These people have far more money to spend than do the business people who are having a go at getting the industry off the ground, providing jobs for Australians and creating export dollars for us. This is a vital industry for western New South Wales, especially in the Wilcannia district in my electorate, because there are many roo shooters, abattoir workers, exporters, packers, et cetera who will benefit if the human consumption kangaroo meat industry gets off the ground.

Finally, I would like to think that I can speak fairly quickly now because I do not want to appear hypocritical in what I am about to say. One thing I have found since I have been in this place is that there are many members on both sides of this parliament who have been here for so long that I believe that they have totally lost touch with what the real people in the real world think of politicians. We are all very quick to defend ourselves when people decry our behaviour or decry the way the parliament is run, yet when I sit back in question time and look at the behaviour of members, on both sides, I can see we do nothing whatsoever to convince the general public that their perception of us is not correct. I would like to see the standard of behaviour in this parliamentâand obviously at question timeâraised to a level that might at least be appropriate for a well-behaved year 6 class. I have nothing against robust debate or even against clever interjection, but the constant noise and constant slamming of people on both sides of the House is, I think, beneath the dignity that this place deserves.

The other housekeeping matter I would like to quickly touch on is the length of time that people speak. There has been some comment, most recently in the mediaâand, as a coincidence, I was thinking of speaking along these linesâabout the way the debates are conducted, or not conducted, in this House. I believe that if you cannot say what you want to say in a debate in 10 minutesâand I am very cognisant of the fact that I have already spoken for more than 10 minutesâthen perhaps it is not worth saying. The personal contribution of many speakers is minimal. Regurgitating the figures, phrases and arguments of ministers is something that anyone can do, and this serves to take up time to the magical 20 minutes.

I will admit that it is only an observation from someone who has spent very little time in the parliament and perhaps my perceptions are wrong, but I think not. Perhaps we could address these problems by making it compulsory for anyone who wishes to speak on a bill to sit in the House throughout the whole debate. This would make sure that both sides of the argument are heard. At the moment, most members will listen with one ear to their television while other speakers are speaking in the House. This way, if a speaker was making a worthwhile contribution, he could seek leave from his colleagues who are sitting in the place to continue for a while longer.

I should say now that there are occasions when an amendment proposed by one side is accepted by the other, and that there is many a committee where recommendations made by the committee are accepted and welcomed by both sides of parliament. I do not know why this is not translated into the normal debate. I can hear it now: cries of `naive', `doesn't understand the way of government'. Well, maybe the people do not understand the way of government. Or is it that the government does not understand the way of the people?

talk.start.para: âBefore turning to the points that I want to make, I would like to make a few remarks about the comments in the latter part of the honourable member for Parkes's speech. I hope that he would not think it too patronising when I say that I understand that he has made those remarks with great sincerity. I do not believe that he is naive. I have some disagreement about his conclusions. But I believe that many of us who have been here longer than he are very acutely aware of the way in which we are perceived outside. I believe that sometimes that is coloured by people's perceptions and observations of question time, and it disappoints me that perhaps that is the only impression that people have of this parliament. I, in turn, am not so naive as to say I understand why that is so. But I would think that, in a way, the debate in this place, whether it be down in the main chamber or in this committee, would be heightened if, in fact, people paid more attention to itâthat is, people other than members.

speech.para: I believe that he is correct, that there should be a greater interchangeâthat is, true debate between the contributions that are made. It disappoints me that, from time to time, people make set speeches that do not relate to what is going on and to the spirit and the environment in which the debate is going on. One of his National Party colleagues makes interesting observations about the tensions and heat of question time when he describes it as `the parliament's safety valve', that a modicum of the release that is question time enables us to get on with the type of robust parliamentary democracy we have without fisticuffs or bloodshed.

Having said that, I know that there is a fine line. Madam Deputy Speaker, because of the time you do in the chair, you would appreciate that, for those of us who have to listen to the debates, they are a mixed bag. Often the contributions are well worth while; often they are very forgettable. But the point is that this is a parliamentary democracy which has served Australia for nearly a century now. With the differences that are bound in the political scene, we are a parliament that acts in the national interest. Having got to the national interest, I will probably turn to my partisan contribution, but I think the honourable member for Parkes should not give up hope. He should proceed; indeed, I would not want to dissuade him from having some idealistic views about the way in which we should carry out our duties in the parliamentary sense as well as outside, with the many facets that there are to our representation.

I come to the subject that has dominated public and parliamentary debate over the last week or two, and that is tax policy and the GST. It was only on Thursday, 13 August last year that the coalition launched their package entitled `Tax reform: not a new tax, a new tax system'. Two weeks later, the Labor Party launched its package entitled `A fairer tax system with no GST'. Some three days after the Labor launch, on Sunday, 30 August, the Prime Minister announced the election date.

Of course, the election was held on Saturday, 3 October 1998 and the Howard government was returned with a substantially reduced majority and, I make the observation, without even securing half of the two-party preferred vote. I do not dwell too long on that but just state it as I understand that, of course, the government won the election; the opposition lost. But I think that, in the events that have occurred since that date, that is something that perhaps the Prime Minister should have kept in mind.

My concern is that the Prime Minister believes that this period between 13 August, when he launched his tax policy, and 3 October was a period in which the public at large, in coming to a conclusion on election day, was able to dissect and properly understand the GST package. I do not believe that that is the case. I believe that, since the election and the events that have been carried out, there is a better understanding of what was proposed. There is a better understanding of the things that are important that we should be looking at if we wish to improve our tax regime.

Between December 1998 and April 1999 a number of Senate committees inquired into a new tax system. The evidence that was collected by these committees was quite interesting and a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate. At the conclusion of the committee inquiries, the Prime Minister still held the view that in the period between mid-August and the election there had been sufficient debate and he tended to ignore the evidence and the discussion that was created by the Senate committee inquiries.

On Friday, 14 May 1999 Senator Harradine announced in the Senate chamber that he could not support the GST-inspired new tax system. After that there were about 10 days of frantic negotiation and discussions between the coalition government, which at that stage comprised only the Liberal Party and the National Party, and the leadership of the Australian Democrats. On Friday, 28 May, the Prime Minister and Senator Lees announced that they had reached an agreement on a new tax system, mark 2.

In the subsequent days, of course, there have been a number of questions and discussions of what is contained in that package. Of course, we do not know the fine detail and that will be produced, it appears, next week to be discussed in the parliament over the next few weeks. I suppose in that detail we will really see what is the mark 2 new tax system to be presented to the parliament.

In trying to look at the goods and services tax, which basically is the main plank of what is being proposed by the government, I am yet to believe that I have been incorrect in seeing it as being an unfair tax. I do not think that the mark 2 version agreed to by the Howard government and the Democrats is any better. I think that the exclusion of some food items and the inclusion of other food items, and the different way in which the as yet to be finalised diesel concessions work, increases in mark 2 what was already a compliance nightmare for Australian businesses in the mark 1 of the tax package.

There are other things that we do not really know until we have a fuller discussion of what might be the overall impact. The planned removal of the state taxes has been largely abandoned. Only a couple of the bed taxes in two of the states are being abandoned in the first instance, and then there is a staging of the abandonment of other taxes, with a whole swag not to be abandoned but continued.

More importantly, my concern not only with the tax package but with the budgetâwhich seems so long ago and not really the central part of our discussionâis that nothing is being done for jobs. In the revised GST package of the new Howard-Democrats coalition, no mention is made of jobs. The great concern is that, over the past few months, more and more evidence has been found that the GST is a job destroyer. At the present time the European Union is looking at the extent of the negative effect of its VATs, value added taxes, on jobs and employment growth.

The Democrats, earlier in the discussions about this package, set certain hurdles that they thought needed to be crossed in order to meet their requirements for employment. They indicated a cut in payroll tax, zero rated food, replacement of the first home buyers scheme with a GST rebate, zero rated inbound tourism and a reduction in the taper on unemployment benefits, amongst others. This new package, produced by the Howard-Democrats coalition, fails to deliver on these parts of the Democrats' original package. One must come to the conclusion that, according to the Democrats' own yardstick, the package they have signed off on fails to deliver jobs.

Let us look at the extent of compensation in the new package. It has to be remembered that the compensation that is offered in this new agreement between the Democrats and the coalition government is less than half what was offered to and rejected by Senator Harradine.

We have measures, much vaunted by the Democrats, to do with the environment. Yet, as the days go by, there is an increasing understanding that the environment package would have been put in placeânearly in its entiretyâwithout this agreement between the government and the Democrats.

The Democrats committed themselves in a very spectacular way to having books GST free, to avoiding greater taxation of education, to addressing a whole swag of tax loopholes and to preventing erosion of the surplus through the GST package, yet many of these have not been delivered in this package.

The tax package should not be all that is considered. There are many things that we need to address that are not addressed either in the tax package or in the budget which these appropriation bills are about. That is the concern. I am worried that the government has stalled and has now clouded its judgment because it has a plan for a new tax only. This might appear to be simply a piece of rhetoric from our opponents, but to judge by the actions of the government it is where we are at at the moment.

We need to look at a whole swag of other things that are important. Coming from a region where about 15,000 people are unemployedâand nearly 4,000 of those are long-term unemployedâI am disappointed that we are confronted with a budget in which the government seems to admit that it has given up on the reduction of unemployment. Stating that unemployment will remain at 7Â½ per cent throughout the next financial year does not give great hope to those who are unemployedâeven worse, those who are long-term unemployed, many of whom are now part of a growing phenomenon within the Australian labour market: second or third generation unemployed people.

I have always been an unashamed supporter of government interventionânot overall, capital `i' government intervention, but acknowledgment of an obligation to many sectors of the community not to rely just on the market forces. Whilst I might not think that the market forces really result in much benefit, large portions of the community miss out on anything that can be seen as of benefit from the way in which a market operates. That is why I have been one who has been disappointed that the government seems to have stalled in support for unemployed people, and a pseudo labour market program under the title of Work for the Dole will not offer anything else.

I am on the record as saying that I cannot support Work for the Dole in its present fashion. It is not due to the fact that people are asked in return, as a form of mutual obligation, to do certain things; it is the nature and quality of the experience that they are offered. It is not simply that I do not believe that people should not be given the opportunity for a work experience. I believe that many of the people that shouldâand couldâbenefit from a program of the ilk of Work for the Dole will have a better experience if there are added things, and if there are proper skills training and proper welfare support, because those are the things that we really need to see.

I know that people like the honourable member for Deakin, who is following me in this debate, are great supporters of Work for the Dole. I know that large numbers of people have participated in that Work for the Dole scheme in his area. I know that he will have testimonies from a number of participants who have had a worthwhile experience. But in the nature of the labour market in the area that I represent, there are not as many people in a state of readiness to have the same and equal positive experience from a program that merely gives the opportunity to turn up and participate in a job. It needs a lot more.

When we have the minister responsible decrying a local government unit like the Brisbane City Council for not participating in the scheme, he has to understand that others make judgments that it perhaps does not go far enough. If we are looking at mutual obligation, it should not be in just simplistic terms. It can be a lot more complex. In variations, the notion of mutual obligation is not just the creation of the Howard government. It is a creation that had some genesis in the previous Keating government but there the type of obligation seen was very much a two-way obligation. I note that the Treasurer, in a change of rhetoric about Work for the Dole, briefly mentioned in his speech that it was a two-way thing. But the Labor government under Keating as Prime Minister saw that the obligation not only went for the income security that the unemployment benefit gives, but also should go to the government giving an undertaking that they try to ensure a definite outcome by way of positive training as well as just the outcome through the work experience.

The other feature about Work for the Dole schemes that I do not understand is this: if they are worth funding under Work for the Dole, why are not the outcomes achieved by the people who work in these schemes worth funding through programs? No matter what they are doing, why do we not as government bite the bullet and understand that, if we do not as small `i' intervention provide the resources to ensure that these types of job opportunities exist, unemployment will remain at 7.5 per cent?

We will be putting hundreds of thousands of Australian people in the difficult position of long-term unemployment, not just a transitory period on the way to a full-time or more successful form of paid employment. We will have more and more people stuck in a cycle of unemployment, with their families stuck in that cycle, whether they be in the suburbs of Melbourne, such as in the electorate of Scullin, or in some of the rural areas, such as in the electorate of the member for Parkes. We potentially have generational unemployment of a grand scale. I think that we need to be looking at ways in which we can ensure that we look above the type of scheme that Work for the Dole is and look for things that will have a longer-term benefit not only for individual unemployed people but for their families and the communities in which they live.
I have, in the past, quoted from John Kenneth Galbraith's book The Good Society. He says:

In the market economy the natural focus of power is the employer, most often the business firm. The rights of workers to join together and assert countervailing authority must be central and accepted.

One of the things that I would implore the government to understand is that there needs to be a mutual effort between large sections of the community, whether they be government, employers or, legitimately, trade unions acting on behalf of the workers, to ensure that we continue to see opportunities given to people for long-term employment, whether that is part time, casual or full time. If we see that form of cooperation and generosity of spirit, we will have the future in our grasp.

talk.start.para: âGiven the hours we spend in this building, there would not be too many members in here who have not borrowed a couple of dollars from a colleague to purchase that emergency cup of coffee. I did just that in budget week and was reminded that I had just borrowed more than the Australian government had borrowed in three years. This is perhaps one of the greatest unsung achievements of this or any government. Certainly, no Australian government in the past 80 or so years has been able to rely entirely on its own resources. For most, it has been a case of borrowing more and repaying interest, a routine that is very familiar to those opposite.

speech.para: That all came to a crashing halt in 1996: Labor lost, electoral sanity was restored and economic sanity returned. Four times now, on behalf of the Australian government, Treasurer Peter Costello has delivered a budget that has given Australians a financial blueprint for greater prosperity. This is a departure from the economic fumbling in the dark that defined the Labor years, years that were defined by high interest rates that forced the closure of so many businesses and the default of so many home mortgages.

No longer does Labor make any contribution to the political debate. They moan, they point fingers, they feign concern, but in here, where they have the chance, they contribute very little. As was aptly put by the Treasurer, they are `stunt driven, not substance driven', and the people of Deakin know it. In defiance of the public will and the public interest, they have ceded the mantle of opposition to the minor party in the other place.

After a look at the fourth coalition budget, Labor was probably wise to have walked away. Once again, we see that, for the fourth year running, Australians will be paying back some of Labor's debtâin fact, $20.5 billion in the next financial year, representing the biggest single reduction in our history. This is quite an achievement, though I must say that it is just short of the $23 billion that the member for Brand produced in budget deficits in his two years as finance minister. That we have the resources further to rein in debt with targeted spending cuts and not increase taxes is a tribute to the modest and steady approach displayed by the coalition since we came to office in 1996.

Since last year's budget, we have seen the continuing economic crisis in Asia. Australia has not only held firm, but has continued to grow, thereby enhancing our reputation in the financial world. More importantly, it stands us in good stead to take advantage of a stronger Asia in the years ahead. Australia is growing, and the rest of the world is sitting up to take notice.

The strong economic performance is making a difference at the grass roots. Ordinary, hardworking men and women in Deakin are beginning to benefit from the coalition's policies. With unemployment levels in the area pushed down to around five per cent, with rock-bottom interest rates assisting 12,000 home buying families and 19,000 home owning families in Deakin, and with inflation in check, there is now more opportunity than there has been in decades.

Families who struggled to keep their heads above water because of Labor's crippling interest rates and inflation are doing a lot better, and they know the reasons why. One can only wonder what economic morass we would be in now had the Australian public not exercised their good sense and backed the coalition in 1996 and again last year.

There are several features of this budget package I would like to touch on because they will be of great benefit to the people in my electorate of Deakinâas they will be to the people in the electorates around the country. This budget is as much about the young as it is about economic stability.

Our young people are among our greatest resources, and this budget assists them on a number of different levels. One of these levels is education. The new arrangements for the funding of non-government schools will provide more choice, promote more competition and make private education a possibility for a greater number of children. These changes are supported by schools and peak bodies alike as being fair and an all-round better deal for those institutions which are reaching out to offer educational choice to those who are less well off. I have already been in touch with the 11 non-government schools in my electorate to discuss the improved arrangements with school principals. One of those principals has already written back, and I quote from his letter:
Your government is to be commended for its commitment to principle and for delivering outcomes that enhance the choice of working class families.

Not the well off, but the working-class families. This is not a Scotch College or a Wesley College; this is a suburban based independent school in my area that is coping with many working-class families. Despite what we are bound to hear from that most self-centred of bodies, the teachers union, we have not turned our backs on the government system. I am a product of the state system and my two school-age children attend Laburnum Primary School where teachers, parents and the principal, Victor Byrdy, are committed to the delivery of quality education.

The Commonwealth continues to provide significant resources to schools run by state and territory governments, and over the next four years funding to this sector will increase by nearly $1 billion. This is hardly walking away from government schools, as the member for Prospect recently claimed. Nor is it part of a GST-fuelled plot to hand over government schools entirely to the states. State governments, after all, provide most of the funding now and naturally exercise control in that area. Rather, put simply in black and white, it is a funding increase for government schools. With an extra $131 million available for literacy and numeracy, $90 million extra for Asian languages and $78 million for teacher development, there is a demonstrable commitment from the coalition to better educate our younger Australians and prepare them better for life's challenges.

Another feature of this budget is extension of Work for the Dole. The principle of mutual obligation is understood and applauded by the vast majority of Australians. The only group to criticise the program and the much lauded employment outcomes has been the ALP, which would rather see the safety net become a hammock than the trampoline it needs to be. As the member for Scullin mentioned, I do have Work for the Dole projects in my electorateâand, may I say, very successful ones. Recently, I visited a Work for the Dole project at Clifford Park Scout Centre. There the scouting camp has been transformed and renewed by a team that includes quite a number in mutual obligation schemes. These young people have the opportunity to utilise their own skills, to learn other skills and to meet potential employers. The community groups sponsoring projectsâin this case, the scoutsâreceive the lasting benefit of work that could not have been done at regular commercial rates. I appeal to non-profit organisations in my electorate to continue to back the scheme to give our younger Australians a better chance of being job ready.

Another aspect of the budget which delivers to the young as well as the general public in my electorate is public and private health care. After many years of attempting to find a better balance between the two sectors, this budget delivers an initiative that will lead us down that path. Younger people are being encouraged to join private health funds with the coalition's latest plan for lifetime health cover. Encouraging young Australians to join private funds and to stay in private funds will ease the pressure on public hospitals and, ultimately, the public purse. A program such as lifetime health cover is in line with the wishes of many of my constituents who have been in schemes all their working lives and found it increasingly difficult to remain members due to soaring premiums caused by falling membership numbers. Once again, this is a move that has met with approval in all corners, except that of the Labor Party, who of course promote the idea that government should be a cradle to grave guardian for us all.

One area where there is most definitely a place for government is in the area of youth homelessness. This budget allocates another $60 million towards a problem that has been growing each year. As family breakdown has become more prevalent, increasing numbers of our young have chosen to flee the family home. Many of these have had nowhere to go and end up on the streets in the cities and inner suburbs. The eastern end of my electorate has been identified by this government as being an area of need, which underlines the importance of organisations such as Ringwood Extended Family Services to this program. Under the energetic and professional leadership of Bruce Argyle, REFS offer counselling and advice to family members, and help in the restoration of strained relationships and in many other valuable services. Their model of early intervention was successfully trialled as part of the Prime Minister's youth homelessness pilot projects. I am delighted that REFS will continue to play a vital role in the next round.

The real victims in family breakdown are inevitably the young. I am happy to see that the 1999 budget makes greater provision to help those in danger of finding themselves without a roof over their heads.
