The new $39 million suicide prevention strategy will impact too on our young people, who are the group most prone to taking their own lives.

The special assistance required to see a greater work force participation for people with a disability is recognised with the introduction of the new trial funding arrangements. Ten million dollars will go to this in 1999-2000. Disability employment assistance is a special area of interest to me. During the last parliament I headed a task force inquiring into the possibility of implementing a program similar to the Javits-Wagner-O'Day scheme that has operated successfully in the United States of America. I was aided on that committee by Frank Harris, a tireless worker for those with a disability. Frank is the manager of NADRASCA, based in Nunawading, which assists nearly 350 clients and employs 120 workers. I have not given up on recommendations of that report being incorporated into a future policy announcement to assist the unmet needs in the disability employment sector.

Another major area of this budget that will benefit our younger people is the provision of an additional $221 million for early intervention and diversion initiatives to fight drugs. There is no longer a typical drug user or addict. Drugs are in every suburb and across every socioeconomic group. They are causing pain, suffering and death to families all across Australia, at an enormous social and economic cost to all of us. In the past five years we have seen a new diversity in approaches to fight this menace, yet there is little evidence to suggest that we are winning this fight. Given the unseemly profits available to the dealers, and the bargain-basement prices at which they can sell their poisons, there is no likelihood that they will close down their operations voluntarily. We must attempt to close them down.

The most vulnerable to the approaches of these pushers are younger, perhaps school-age, children. We must pull out all stops to ensure that temptation is minimised. For those who are sucked into the vortex of drug despair, we must provide the means to help those who want to get clean. The war against drugs is as much about challenging our own traditional values and beliefs as it is about fighting narcotics and those who push them. Things that we might have seen as unacceptable a few years ago are today seen as necessary, though, in most cases, just as regrettable.

Recently I had the opportunity to visit Switzerland and talk with both proponents and opponents of the heroin trials. There are many arguments for and against these trials. There is even a variation in the versions of the official independent report on a trial by the World Health Organisation handed out by each side. My initial feelings tell me that heroin trials ensure that the dosage is cleaner and somewhat safer, though it appears to me that this experiment contributes little to getting people off the drug.

However, what impressed me about the Swiss model was its fourfold approach to drugs: law enforcement, prevention, therapy and harm reductionâsimilar in theory to our approach but vastly different in its application. Our preference, of course, is that people do not begin to use drugs at all. Recently I sponsored a drug forum in connection with a non-profit group called Focus on the Family. On a cold Monday night nearly 200 people, mainly parents, came out to hear from a series of speakers on the range of drug services available in the area, from education and prevention through to treatment.

Focus on the Family itself runs a program rather ambitiously titled `How to drug proof your kids' which encourages greater communication and openness between parents and children. I congratulate all involved for their continuing fight against drugs in the community of Deakin. I look forward very shortly to announcing the make-up of the Deakin Drug Advisory Council which will help me be apprised of the state of play regarding enforcement, treatment and education.

This coalition government has achieved a great deal through its development and promotion of community partnerships. I am very pleased to see the new arrangements for the taxation treatment of property donations to charitable institutions which is part of the effort to encourage a high level of corporate philanthropy. This is a good thing. Governments cannot be expected to do the job on their own. The mutual obligation principle extends to the business community and they must provide assistance to the churches, the welfare organisations and the thousands of Australians who volunteer their time to help those in need.

The realities are that we cannot truly help the poorer in society without economic growth. Growth will be a spur for business and provide jobs and opportunity for all who are seeking work. There are many Australians who are not currently sharing in the nation's prosperity, and this government, with its principled reforms, is attempting to right that imbalance.

The Hawke government put power ahead of principle, according to ALP stalwart Clyde Cameron. We have not fallen into that trap, and just as well. Political populism does not translate into good government. I am sure the leader of the party known as the opposition knows this, but he is a desperate man, brandishing cans of soup, tossed salads and chicken wingsâagain, stunts rather than substance. As we all know by now he lacks the ticker.

Certainly he lacks the courage of Senator Lees, who has risked her leadership on tax reform because it was the right thing to do. In response to Senator Lees's desire to achieve something positive for Australia's future, what did we see from Labor? The best they could offer was an attempt to create division amongst the Democrats. Senator Stott Despoja, who never saw a camera she did not like or a media opportunity she did not take, apparently will now vote with Labor. That says very little for her commitment to a cleaner environment, which this tax package delivers as a result of some healthy negotiations between the coalition and the Democrats. So much for her commitment to Australia's young, who will be saddled with an increased tax burden if these reform attempts fail.

If there is a danger to her political career it will not come from any imagined jealousy within the Democrats' party room. Rather, it will come from the people of her state who realise that they do not share her view that politics and government are merely infotainment. Despite her grandstanding and that of the Labor Party, which has been steadfast in saying no to every major piece of legislation we have introduced, the coalition has managed to stop the rot and has begun to make substantial progress. We could make a lot more headway if only the Labor Party began acting in the national interest. To do so will be in their own self-interest as well.

I note with some interest the comments last week of Whitehorse mayor, Peter Allan, who believes that change in the tax system will benefit the council to the tune of $230,000 per year. I welcome Peter's endorsement, particularly as he was a Labor candidate for Menzies at the 1998 federal election. It is too bad some of his ALP mates are not as forthcoming with the truth. Given the campaign waged against taxation reform by the Labor Party, it is not surprising that people are scepticalâeven scared. No-one, bar the Labor Party, likes taxes, but some are sadly necessary. The benefits of the tax reform package will be realised soon after the changes take effect, when all Australians will have more money in their pockets from income tax cuts and increased benefits.

Given the particular needs in my electorate, in the rapidly growing areas to Melbourne's east, there is a pressing need for greater funding for highways. Topping the wish list is the Scoresby transport corridor, a vital link between Melbourne's east, Ringwood and the Mornington Peninsula. While I realise that there are ever-increasing transport needs around Australia, I reiterate the importance of this link. I hope that the stable economic conditions will allow appropriations for the building of the Scoresby corridor before too much longer.

That said, this is a budget which indicates once again that Australia is in safe hands. Together with the new tax package, it allows a greater number of Australians than ever before to share the dividends of a stronger economy and to look forward with confidence to the challenging and exciting years ahead.

talk.start.para: âI could not let the contribution of my friend and colleague the member for Deakin go without a couple of brief reflections. Really, Clyde Cameron! Clyde Cameron is a great Labor figure from another generation and many years gone by. I would have to say that quoting Clyde is very much like quoting Billy Wentworth or, for that matter, Billy Hughesâfor either side. Beyond that, however, I do not know that it is really a valid contribution in terms of the political circumstances we face as a country today or of this budget.

speech.para: I would like to make a number of comments with respect to the appropriation bills, relating particularly to the health area and some aspects that have come to light since the budget. I will start off with the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group, which was set up some 12 months ago by the government, with the agreement of industry, with the intention of improving dialogue and coordination between industry and government around the question of the pharmaceutical industry. It was a good ideaâno doubt about itâand I certainly do not have a problem with the concept.
The first meeting of the group was on 23 June 1998. A press release issued jointly by the then industry minister, John Moore, and the then and current health minister, Dr Wooldridge, states:

"The Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group was established to consult on key issues facing Australias pharmaceutical industry," Mr Moore said. "The Government wants to work with the Industry to encourage more investment and growth in Australia.

"Our aim is to develop the right environment for companies to confidently invest in the discovery, development and manufacture of safe and cost-effective medicines, which in turn will improve the quality of life for all Australians.

"The Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group will help the Government deliver high-quality health care within budget, while maintaining a vigorous and innovative pharmaceutical industry. It will assist in developing a clear, positive policy framework to take the Australian pharmaceutical industry into the new millennium."

It is a good idea and something that we should all encourage and applaud. It comes after the current government gutted the Factor F scheme and replaced it with PIIP, which provides significantly less money and significantlyâ

talk.start.para: âWhat, PIIP?

âYes, PIIP. Don't ask! It provides essentially less money overall, which has certainly given industry the pip. That may well be a reason for the establishment of the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Groupâwhich is sometimes known as PIWG or `PIG', I might say. When we look at the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group, we find an interesting issue. Its first meeting was on 23 June 1998 and, guess what, its second meeting is due on 30 June 1999. Happy anniversary.

speech.para: Here we have a consultative group, a body designed to improve coordination and dialogue between industry and government in a key industry, an industry that both ministers in their press release have applauded for its major role in the development of Australian industry into the new millennium, yet it has only just managed to meet once more, probably, before the new millennium. This was raised in the consideration of estimates on Monday, when Senator Conroy asked what was actually happening with the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group.

In response to those questions, a number of points were made regarding the lack of meetings. There had been difficulties around the question of the election only eight or nine months ago now. They are very busy people in the pharmaceutical industry. There is no doubt about that. They are major companies and very large corporations. But it has been a long time. It was asserted in the context of those hearings of the estimates that through PIG, the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group, there had been a report commissioned by the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, the APMA, with respect to the economic state and opportunities of the industry.

That is very interesting. I will just refer you to APMA's annual report last year, which said that they commissioned this report in May of 1998. As I hope honourable members will remember from my earlier contribution, the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group was not established until 23 June 1998. So we had a situation where there was considerable confusion from both the minister and the relevant public servant over the question of what this group had done. In fact, upon discussion and reflection, it was discovered that not much had actually been done.

The minister suggested that this was not the role of the group. It was not a decision making body; it was a dialogue body. It was a body designed to improve an understanding. I am not quite sure how you develop and improve an understanding through silence, because that certainly appears to have been the government's role with respect to this industry in the context of this working group.

I think the Pharmaceutical Industry Working Group is a good idea. It is something that government ought to embrace, and I am sure the industry does embrace it, but I think that it takes more than embracing. It takes a situation of some communication. The fact that there is a meeting coming up on 30 June is a good thing and I applaud that. It is about six months too late. I think in the circumstances that is something that hopefully we will not see into the future, and we will see a situation where this group, which is supposed to meet twice a year, does meet twice a year, does consider some of these issues that are of importance to the industry and will consider these issues into the future, in order to ensure that the pharmaceutic al industry, which is a crucial industry for the nation, does get a fair go in government policy into the future.

I will turn to another issue which relates to the budget papers and the health budget in particular. It relates to the major proposed cut out of the budget in the health area, which is a component headlined `Quality initiatives for prescribing pharmaceuticals'. It is in Budget Paper No. 2. It relates to cuts over the next four years of prospective expenditure expected on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in terms of medicines being prescribed. It tallies over each figure: for example, for 1999-2000, there is minus $28.3 million on the forward estimates; for 2000-2001, minus $38.9 million; for next year, minus $55.5 million and following on to minus $64.7 million.

If you add those figures up, you work out that you are talking about a cut over four years of about $187 million. That is very significant. There is no doubt that this is a difficult area for government in the context of the continually rising costs of pharmaceuticals. But $187 million is still a pretty significant cut in the estimates. I would refer people to the minister's media kit fax sheet 8, page 3, which talks about the fact that these savings are net of the incentive payments to doctors which will commence in 2000 and 2001. This is a program where it is proposed that incentives be given to doctors in order to improve prescribing practice and, in that way, decrease the cost to the budget of and the need for prescribing of pharmaceuticals. On the face of it, that is not a bad idea, but there are several issues here that need to be considered.

One is the fact that it suggests $187 million, but that is because, in the figures for those years, something like $78 million of proposed payments to doctors are not shown there. When you look at the actual figures, which were received from the department several days later upon questioning, there is a cut of about $259 million from the forward estimates in terms of PBS costs and some $78 million over that period back to doctors, with that increasing into the following year, and a situation where the figures that are in the budget are misleading.

As I understand it, it has been said elsewhere through estimates again that these sorts of figures were provided but were not included in the budget papers at the end of the day. That is a disappointing thing. Accrual budgeting is something that I support as a concept and as a practice to go forward into the futureâas did my colleague the honourable member for Fairfax when we were together, and we are now again, on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. We are both very supportive of the concept of accrual budgeting, as first commenced under the government that I was proud to be a member of and continued under this government. But, when we look at what was provided in some of the budget papers in the concept of forward estimates, there are some concerns that need to be looked at for the future. There ought to be a line item of some $78 million in the forward estimates around the question of payments going to GPs. When there is not, there ought to be a proper figure around the question of the expected cut to PBS costs of some nearly $260 million. It is not there, and that is not a good thing in terms of clarity and certainty around what the budget actually contains.

On from thatâand why I say that this is an issue which needs to be looked at very carefullyâthe whole issue of the question of prescribing processes and behaviour of GPs is a difficult one. We would all agree that, where we can, we should be trying to ensure that people are given the medicine they require and the medicine that will do the best for them in the context of their particular illness, but it ought to be medically related in terms of the choice.

The concern hereâand I am not saying that this is what will happenâas to what could happen is that, if you have an incentive scheme which is designed to ensure that doctors both improve medical prescribing and at the same time save the budget money by prescribing less, there is a danger around what that will mean with regard to prescribing behaviour. Will it become budget related because there are incentives there? This is certainly a concern that the AMA have about how this scheme may work, and they have put that out in press releases. They are concerned that an incentive program, as proposed, of which we have no detail as yet, could in fact lead us to a situation which is really quite dangerous in terms of prescribing practices in this country.

The detailârather, the devil in the detailâis still unknown. Upon questioning, the situation with respect to the department is that we cannot really ascertain too much detail. It is a projected figure that has been worked out through a range of formulas in the context of the budget process, which provides them with a base on which to suggest this is what they suspect the saving could be in a scheme they would implement. However, they really cannot give us any details at all about that scheme. In fact, they did agree two days after the budget to provide to the opposition details of formulas, and have since reneged on that proposal on the basis of budget confidentiality.

The fact is that, until those details are available, there will be a lot of questions raised about the nature of how such an incentive system would work and what it means in terms of GP practice. For example, how are these incentives going to be paid? Are they going to be paid to individual GPs? Will there be some overall organisational approach, or regional approach? Is it going to be in a situation of looking at the previous practice of prescribing and whether there are cuts in the levels of prescribing from particular doctors or particular groups of doctors? How are they are going to safeguard a situation where it is not seen as being a cash incentive scheme where a GP can look at it and say, `I will not prescribe because I can get the money back from the government in the context of this.' That is certainly not what I would expect from GPs; I have a lot of respect for GPs. But the fact is that, once you have an incentive scheme which is economically based, you have real dangers around the question of what would be the clinical outcomes. Hopefully, the government have that concern, but I am concerned that at the moment we are expected to just trust them and wait and see when it comes to detail.

We have asked a range of questions through estimates to try and get some of those answers and find out what is really being proposed in this cut. But certainly there are issues there. There is the question of its presentation within the budget papers and what that shows about this sort of issue and this sort of change in the process of the operation of the PBS. There are also the questions of what it means for GPs, and what the clinical outcomes will be for their patients.

I would like to briefly talk about the situation with the goods and services tax, the deal that has been done between the Democrats and the coalition on pharmaceuticals and the current state of play. The current state of play is, to an extent, characterised by confusion. There is a good deal of confusion in this area as to the end result. A number of different peak organisations have raised with me the question of the treatment of their particular products in this agreement. They say that their attempts to get clarification from government, from the Democrats and from the relevant ministers in this area have been very difficult and, in fact, most frustrating. To give you an example of the sorts of concerns in this area I will quote from an article that was in the Herald Sun recently and which said:
Up to 2500 chemists will have to spend $25,000 on computerised point-of-sale systems to help administer the GST.
Most of these are small businesses in rural areas or owned by the elderly.
The Pharmacy Guild of Australia said the Democrats had "stuffed up" a chance for tax reform.
The guild's Victorian rural liaison officer, Bruce Robertson, said supermarket owners had to deal with food on two levelsâwith a GST or without.
But pharmacists had a three-tiered problem.

He said products, such as prescribed medicines, would be delivered to chemists GST-free and be sold over the counter GST-free. In other cases, the wholesaler would apply a GST on products, including cold tablets, then the chemists would sell them without a GST.
Thirdly, products such as perfumes would have a GST on them before arriving and when leaving the pharmacy.
"It's going to cause a lot of trouble and cost a lot of money," Mr Robertson, a Wangaratta chemist owner, said.

The fact is there is a great deal of concern. There is an argument developing around this issue, and included in the argument are the questions of the actual clinical value of a medical good, the therapeutic value of particular goods and their treatment with respect to a goods and services tax.

The proposal from large components of the complementary health care industry related to the treatment of all products that are registered under the ARTGâthe Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. It recommended that they be treated as GST free because there was a recognition through that listing that there was some therapeutic value in what they do. However, I might add that that was also the position that was embraced by the Democrats as being a proposal that they saw as being of merit. They moved amendments to that effect within the Senate in the earlier consideration of the new tax system bills. However, the circumstances of the deal that has been done between the Democrats and the government are that they have chucked that out of the window. They have made an extension in relation to schedule 2 goods but they have not considered a range of other goods. They have created a situation where there is even greater confusion about what is covered and what is not.

There are examples, and they have been raised in the parliament and outside the parliamentâthings such as Strepsils. Most Strepsils are subject to a GST, but Strepsils Plus are not. Mr Deputy Speaker Adams probably needs Strepsils in this weather we are having in Canberra at the moment, and certainly I had one just yesterday. But I advise the Deputy Speaker that he should attempt to get Strepsils Plus if he wants to ensure that the product that he purchases and uses is not GSTed. There are other products such as Mylanta, that absolutely does have a therapeutic value, which will be GSTed. There are a range of products that have very similar activities; one happens to be schedule 2, others are not. In fact, some are GSTed and some are not.

It does not make a lot of sense in terms of therapeutic value or health value. Basically, it is more a question of the arrangements being made to get a deal. We have a situation where the Democrats have backtracked on what they saw as being a major consideration in their earlier amendments. But I guess it is a bit like books: only a couple of days ago there were Democrats who said they read books; now they do not seem to read that much. They do not see the need for a situation where those things are covered.

What I would say is that, when we look at the question of the GST with respect to health care and a range of other areas, there are inconsistencies and there is confusion from within the government about what is affected and what is not. There are also concerns about consistency in terms of policy in this area. There is still a lot of detail that needs to come out. But the concern I have, and I know others have, is that that detail is not there now and that it does not seem that either party really understands the nature of the issues they are dealing with in this area.

We could go to the question of recipes for bread, or salads, or soups, or a whole range of other goods. But the fact is that this whole process has been messy and is starting to unravel to a degree which should be of great concern to the government. I note the members for Wannon and Eden-Monaro are here. Although I am sure the member for Wannon will return at the next election, the member for Eden-Monaro ought to have real concerns about this issue in terms of how it plays out at the next election. Although that is some time to come, there are issues there for the government to have real concerns about. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am certainly pleased to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 , which is a result of the 1999-2000 budget. It is an excellent budget, and excellent for rural and regional Australia, which I represent. The seat of Eden-Monaro, being very much a rural and regional seat, has done very well out of this budget.

speech.para: It is interesting that with federal budgets rather large figures get bandied around, and I think sometimes they go over the top of people's heads. We talk about surpluses of $5 billion. We talked about deficits when we came into government of over $10 billion. When you start to talk in billions, people tend to turn off and they really do not appreciate the extent of those sorts of figures.

Something I have done over the last few years, since I have been in parliament and part of the government, is to try and relate national figures back to something that the ordinary person can understand, and to make some comparison with something that they might be dealing with in order to get some sort of measure of the actual extent of the figures. For instance, a good comparison is if you can drag down an aspect and relate it, first of all, to a small business. My electorate is made up of small businesses. From a business point of view, we do not have large corporations throughout the electorate. It is predominantly small business that employs people, so doing some sort of relative comparison of the national budget with a small business area helps people understand the sort of problem that we had when we came into government and the sort of situation we are in now. The other comparison is to relate it to a family income.

I did this with some figures a couple of years ago. I have duplicated it with this budget to see how we are going when you relate similar sorts of figures to a small business and a family. In 1995-96, we all know, we had a deficit of over $10 billion that we took over when we came into government. We were told the budget was in surplus and when the figures came out for it we were actually in deficit by over $10 billion. I have related that back to, first of all, a small business and then to a family. To make it easy I have called the small business budget $1 million. That is not an enormous small business. Depending on whether it is a retail or a service one, it might employ anything from 10 people up to maybe 30 or 40 people.

So let us say a small business had a turnover of $1 million. That budget that we inherited when we came into government would be the equivalent of that small business losing over $80,000. There are not too many small businesses of that size that could cope with an operating loss of $80,000. If they continued at that, the bank would be stepping in pretty smartly. Also, if that business was carrying a debt equivalent to that of the federal budget, it would have had a debt of nearly $800,000 to service. A business that turns over $1 million with a debt of $800,000 to service is in big difficulties. That is the equivalent of what we inherited in 1995-96.

From a family point of view, that is like saying that if a family with an income of $35,000âwhich, in fact, would probably be a high family income for a lot of parts of my electorate of Eden-Monaroâoperated in the way in which the federal budget that we inherited in 1995-96 operated, it would have spent $3,000 more than the $35,000 that it earned plus have a bankcard bill of just under $28,000. Somebody earning $35,000, overspending by $3,000 in the yearâthat means they have to go out and get another personal loan, but they also have to service a $28,000 bankcard billâis in great difficulty. That is the sort of equivalent that we inherited back in 1995-96.

I will jump two years up to 1997-98. That million-dollar business now has a turnover of $1.12 millionâso they have increased their sales. They have now turned that $80,000 loss into a $9,000 profit. So in two years what we have done with the federal budget would be the equivalent of a small business that had been turning over a million dollars and losing $80,000 becoming one that turned over $1.12 million but actually made a $9,000 profit. And they had reduced that $800,000 debt to just under $700,000, so they are actually making inroads into it.

The equivalent for a familyâjumping those two years forwardâis that they have now worked very hard and have got a promotion; their family income is now a bit over $39,000 and they are square. They have actually got $300 left over from the year. So instead of spending $3,000 more than they were getting in income, they had, in fact, $300 over and they had reduced their $28,000 bankcard bill down to $24,000âso they were starting to make headway. That is the equivalent of what we have done in a federal budget equated to a small business and a family.

We now come to this year's budgetâjump another two years forward. I have got the figures for the in between years, but time moves on quickly, so we will jump up to the current budget. That $1 million business that we bought in 1995-96 is now turning over $1.28 million, so it has increased its sales quite well and is making $43,000 a year profit. The equivalent of the federal budget is that we have increased the revenue; we have looked after our expenses and we are, in fact, into surplus. That million-dollar business is now turning over $1.28 million with a $43,000 profit, and they have reduced the debt down to a bit over $400,000âso from the original $800,000 down to $400,000. That is the sort of equivalent reduction in debt that we have produced in the federal budget.

Take the family. This year the family has been working very well and has been well regarded by the employer. Their family income is now almost $45,000. They have really done well as far as income is concerned and they have $1,500 left over out of that almost $45,000 a year income. They have reduced the bankcard debt to a bit under $15,000, so that is not a bad move. If we continue with the sort of budgeting that we have shown over the last couple of years, that family in a couple more years will have even paid off that bankcard bill. So that brings us a bit better comparison as to what is happening with that federal budget when you compare it to an ordinary small business or a family situation.

Let me say a few words about the purpose of the budget. Often all sorts of politics get played with the federal budget and I am concerned that people look at a federal budget only to ask how many dollars are going to their town or area. The federal budget really is all about making sure the overall economic situation is right, that the climate is right for business to invest. If business is investing, the economy is growing; if the economy is growing, people are being employed; if people are being employed, we have a better standard of living. And that is really the responsibility of the federal government.

A variety of allocations are made to ensure that those sorts of things occur, rather than saying that this or that area can have so many tens of thousands. Some specific budget allocations have to be made which end up in a particular region of Australia, but it is not necessary that every single area gets allocated certain dollars from the budget. In the past, too much politics has been played in an attempt to appease various areas.

The budget contained a series of excellent moves to benefit regional Australia. In the health area we have provided quite some additional funding: over $40 million to establish 30 new regional health centres; $4 million for regional Australia specifically for women being diagnosed with breast cancer and related issues; $19 million to put in additional Medicare Easyclaim facilities; $43 million to keep rural GPs in the bushâand I could go on. All rural and regional areas will benefit in some way from such budget allocations, even though there is no specific statement, initially, of where every dollar is going. Certainly my area has benefited from a number of those things already. Quite a variety of additional Medicare Easyclaim outlets have gone into small towns in my electorate. That is a great plus. We have had them go into Bungendore, Moruya and Eden, and I am opening one in Cobargo in a week or so, also Tathraâa lot of the very small towns.

Some of the local people have been working very hard to improve the health services. Often it is a case of attracting doctors, and although we have a variety of incentives there, I think the local people in a lot of the towns can play a big part in convincing doctors that it is good to be a GP in the bush. In that sense, I should congratulate the people of Narooma, who have been working very hard to get an additional doctor. Before I continue, I should acknowledge the former member for Eden-Monaro, who has been in the gallery for a while but is now leaving.

Narooma is a beautiful place to live, and the people who own one of the shopping centres there, Hans Baer and Bill Anderson, have for a couple of years been trying without success to attract a doctor into their shopping centre area. Then the town as a whole, through the chamber of commerce, made a really big push to get that to occur. They were lucky enough, not long ago, to get a major article published in either the Sunday Telegraph or the Sun-Herald about Narooma and the need for an additional doctor, and they now have an additional doctor in that town. That was something that the town itself has brought about, outside of government providing all sorts of incentives to move to the bush area. Government incentives are there as well, but the actual community contains the best people to sell the attractions of the community.

Additional money was provided also for the rural assistance program, with $40.8 million for a regional assistance program. This is administered by two area consultative committees in Eden-Monaro: the South-East New South Wales Area Consultative Committee covers all the coastal area and the mountains, and the Southern Tablelands-ACT Area Consultative Committee covers part of Canberra, the Queanbeyan and Braidwood area of my electorate, and also up into the southern tablelands. Both those committees do a great job in identifying potential new projects and enterprise for the regions, and now the Regional Assistance Program will be in place.

Recently I launched a couple of projects funded out of that Regional Assistance Program down on the coast. One was a planning exercise for sending directions for the aquaculture industry in the south-east. That has enormous potential. There was one also for development of a value-adding timber industry in the south-east. We have to use our timber in a lot smarter way than we have in the past. There is now less of it available and we have to make sure that we get the maximum dollar for the timber before it leaves our region.

One of the other projects I also launched was a report on the social and economic effects of developing Moruya airport. There is the potential there for a great development near Moruya airport, for conference facilities and those sorts of things. A proper study is being done as far as that is concerned.

Rural transaction centres were also funded in the budget at $70 million over five years. This is bringing those services such as phone, fax and banking facilities and Medicare Easyclaim back into small areas where they do not exist. That will be an added boost of services in many of the smaller towns throughout my electorate.

Telecommunications as well got a big boost in the budget. In recent days, through the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fundâthe RTIFâwe have got a number of excellent projects happening in my region, particularly on the coast, to set up a broadband infrastructure for telecommunications. With the advent of e-commerce and other matters, there is enormous scope for improving those infrastructures, which will encourage many more businesses to set up in those regions.

In the time I have left, I just want to touch on a couple of other things particularly related to unemployment. We have outperformed just about every other part of the world, despite many people who have kept claiming that Asia would knock us off over and over, and we have continually outperformed even our own estimates. But although the economy overall is going superbly well, there are still some inequities within Australia. Rural and regional Australia is not doing anywhere near as well as many of the major cities.

It is very sobering when you really look at some of the figures. Unemployment figures are a good guide as to which areas are doing well and which are not. If you look around my electorate, things have certainly improved, but they have a long way to go. In the Bega Valley, the unemployment rate over the last year has gone from 14Â½ per cent down to 12 per cent; in Bombala, it has gone from 10.1 to 9.2; in Cooma, from 5.2 down to 4.7; in Eurobodalla, from 19.3 down to 15âso the unemployment level is still very highâand in Queanbeyan, from 8.8 down to 7.2.

When you take all of the shires together, there has been a fall of 15 per cent in unemployment in my electorate. The total unemployment in March 1998 was 6,688. In December 1998 it was 5,677, so it is coming down, but we have a long way to go. When you put it all together, you are talking about an unemployment rate of about 8.5 per cent throughout the electorate of Eden-Monaro. The national figure is 7.4 per cent. In New South Wales it is 6.9 per cent and in Sydney it is 5.5. There, in stark contrast, is that difference between the city and the bush. There is a 5.5 per cent unemployment rate in Sydney and an 8.5 one throughout my electorate, although it goes between 2.8 up to 15. It is a sobering point which shows that there is still much to do in that respect. Certainly, the overall budget is directed very much towards helping rural and regional Australia.

Before I did not talk necessarily about how specific things are budgeted for in a particular area. Two things in the budget were of particular interestâand specifically when we talk about unemployment. The first was $3Â½ million for work on the proposed armaments complex in Eden, a multipurpose wharf which will open up all sorts of new possibilities for that region. I was pleased that the $3.58 million was in the budget, so the environmental work can get moving and some decisions can be made on that, hopefully by the end of this year. The second was $1.65 million through the RTIF for a call centre in Cooma. Cooma has undergone some major changes and problems because of the five years of drought and changing commodity prices. Cooma is looking to that call centre to provide something very new in a technology sense that will give it scope to develop all sorts of technology based industries.

We need to look at that in a number of areas where traditional agriculture has really changed dramatically. With the sort of telecommunications type infrastructure that we have, there is no reason why many of these new technology based industries cannot be sited in rural and regional Australia to replace many of those jobs that are lost. I will be looking forward to both those major projects being progressed over the next year, as it will help the coastal area of my electorate and the mountain part of it as well.

Tax reform is clearly the other major encouragement needed by rural and regional Australia to improve its export competitiveness. My electorate is very much export orientated, and that will be a major boost for it as well.

talk.start.para: âI am told that four weeks ago today the Treasurer, with great rhetorical flourishâsome might say great rhetorical flourish; I would not describe it as such, I do not thinkâdelivered the budgetâ
âA Clayton's budget.

âAs my learned friend said, a Clayton's budget, because here we are, a mere four weeks later, discussing in detail in this parliament how the fundamental premises underlying that budget will be altered as a result of changes to the tax package which it proposed.

speech.para: That is no surprise to us, because those of us who have been involved in public life in this country for some time have known all along that much of what was being said about the GSTâboth prior to the last federal election and subsequent to itâby the government just did not ring true. I want to make it very clear that, in discussing the government's tax proposals, the GST, I am doing so from the perspective of someone who lives in a regional part of Australia, someone who lives in a remote area, someone whose electorate has a very dispersed population. As you would know, my electorate is 1.3-plus million square kilometres, so it is a pretty big joint.

The issues canvassed during the course of the election campaign in relation to the government's tax proposals, which were a foundation of this Clayton's budget brought down four weeks ago today, were issues where the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister asserted that fuel pricesâpetrol pricesâwould go down in regional Australia. I will come to that again shortly. They made other quite extravagant claims about what the impact of their tax proposals would be.

What we have learned, of course, is that, once exposed to scrutiny, the claims they were making were false. That does not seem to have stopped them continuing to make those false claims and telling lies about what it is that can be achieved under their tax package. We had them in the Northern Territory talking about the questions of housing costs, transport costs and the tourism industry. I raise the tourism industry and the housing industry because they are two of the largest employers in the Northern Territory. I vividly recall that, in the lead-up to the election, the membership of the Housing Industry Association said that there would be a negative impact on the housing industry as a result of a GSTâthat prices would go up.

It will not come as any surprise to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, to know that the person who is opposing me as candidate of the Northern Territoryâand the relevant government ministers, including the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and anyone else who could get near a microphoneâclaimed that there would be no negative impacts on the tourism industry or the construction industry as a result of a GST.

I do not claim to be the world's greatest economist, but I do read material and I do take the advice of industry specialists when they discuss the impacts and the potential impacts of these sorts of arrangements on their industries. During the course of the election campaign I, as you would expect, ran the contrary view and said that the impact of a GST as proposed by the governmentâand still proposed, despite the deal which has been done with the Democratsâwould be catastrophic for employment in the construction industry and in the tourism industry in the Northern Territory. I am not pleased to say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that industry experts now acknowledge and reaffirm the view that that prognosis is correct, despite the protestations which are made by the government that there will be no negative impacts as a result of this GST.

It has got to the point where, in the context of the tourism industry, a report was released in February by the tourism industry task force which claimed that 2,000 tourism industry jobs would be lost in the Northern Territory as a result of a GST. Even if you said that is an extravagant claim, even if you were to assert that the calculation was out by 25 per cent, you are still talking 1,500 jobs. But the government is trying to lay claim to the fact that somehow or another the GST proposed in the budget would be a job generator. In my electorate the GST will cost many jobs.

If you take out the Commonwealth government outlays to the Northern Territory budgetâ80 per cent of the Northern Territory budget revenue emanates from the Commonwealth governmentâon top of that there is additional expenditure as a result of decisions made by successive governments, particularly in relation to the build-up of defence infrastructure. What is important is that, if you take out the public sector, and you ask where are the small business private sector employers in the Northern Territory, the answer will be that they are primarily in the tourism and construction industries. The other important industries in the Northern Territory are not large employers. The large employers in the Northern Territory are the retail sector and the service sector, generally; not the pastoral industry, not the mining industry. They make significant financial contributions to the Northern Territory gross product, but they are not large employers. The large employers, the engine room of private enterprise in the Northern Territory, are in the tourism and construction industries and the retail sector.

Which three industries do the experts tell us will be most adversely affected by the impact of a GST? The tourism industry, the retail sector and the housing industry. I do not know how advocates of the government's position can consciously walk into a community like Darwin or Alice Springs or Katherine and sit down and claim, as they have done, that jobs will not be lost. They are being fundamentally and basically dishonest. They are lying to the community. They make no bones about it, but if you criticise them it is like water off a duck's backâthey take no notice at all. They continue to drive these absurd notions and make these outrageous claims which they know are dishonest. They continue to make themâeven to this day. Today in the parliament the Prime Minister had the gall to say, during the course of question time:

We believe in a taxation system that will take $10Â½ billion off business costs in Australia. We believe in a taxation system that will dramatically reduce the price of fuel in rural and regional Australia.

Well, ho ho hum! What we know, despite the ignoramuses who sit opposite, is that the current price of fuel in Alice Springs is 89c a litre. You do not have to be Einstein, but, if you understand how your GST works, you will know that the bottom line is that if you take the calculation based on 7c reduction in the price of fuel and add on a 10 per cent GST, the price of fuel will go up.

It is $1.25 a litre at Rabbit Flat. It is 90-plus cents a litre on the Barkly Highway. And these clowns come into my electorate, go into north-west Queensland, go into Western Australia, go into South Australia, where they know the price of fuel is 89c, 90c, $1 a litre for petrol, and they know that the impact is going to be an increase in fuel prices, yet we have got the Prime Minister standing up in this parliament today and claiming that there will be a lowering of fuel prices in the bush. He is being dishonest. We had the Deputy Prime Minister coming into my electorate at the same time, during the course of the election campaign, and subsequently, and making the same claims. No-one believes them. They do not believe themselves.

Then we have this issue about diesel. Let us just talk about diesel. May I not use my words, Mr Deputy Speaker, not even use the Prime Minister's words, not even use the Deputy Prime Minister's words, but use the words of that paragon of Liberalism, the Premier of Western Australia.

talk.start.para: âRichard, baby.

âRichard. What does Richard say about the little deal on diesel which has been procured for him by this great negotiatorâI do not know if it was Mr Anderson, or if it was the Deputy Prime Minister, or the Prime Ministerâwho negotiated this great outcome for rural and regional Australia on the question of diesel rebates? Let me just say to you what the Premier of Western Australia says about that little deal. I will tell you what he says. This quote is from the Hansard of the Western Australian parliament of 2 June 1999:

speech.para: I take exception to a Federal Government bringing about changes which will trigger greenhouse emission controls when they have nothing to do with this tax debate. Similarly, the changes which will affect power generation in remote areas are unbelievably politically stupid.

I will then quote, if I may, Mr Deputy Speaker, his coalition partner, Mr Cowan. Now, Mr Cowan is even more forthright and honest about the implications of a GST on regional and remote Australia, because what does he say? I quote from the same Hansard :

Some other issues have been identified by the Leader of the Opposition, which are a downside. One is the additional cost of compliance. It will create enormous difficulties for small business, especially those selling processed or fresh food. That aspect must be worked through and I can assure members that it will be difficult, but many people have underestimated the degree of difficulty associated with the compliance requirements for wholesale sales tax in this country at the moment.
I disagree, and I will explain why in a moment. He goes on:

I am disappointed that the diesel fuel credit has been reduced by 2c a litre, and it will be selectively applied. I find it difficult to accept that those people who have no other recourse but to use diesel for power generation, must now pay the full level of taxation on diesel, whereasâ
and he goes on to say that other industry sectors do not.

Let us stop the rubbish around here. Let us start to understand and be honest about the implications of this GST for regional and remote Australia. I want to use some examples of what it will mean for families in my electorate who live in the bush. These Einsteins opposite reckon they know about the bush. I can tell you, you know nothing about the bush. I know that the Deputy Prime Minister knows even less about the bush. If he did he would acknowledge a survey which was done by the Northern Territory Department of Health based on 45 community stores in the Northern Territory last year. What this tells us is the exorbitant price of food for people who live in rural communities, primarily Aboriginal people as it happensâbut that would not matter to the government, of course.

Let me just give you an example of the cost of this basket of goods. These are not my figures; they are the Northern Territory Department of Health figures. The cost of a basket of goods across the average of all capital cities in Australia is $301. The average across all of the Northern Territory districts of these 45 stores was $484â$301 as opposed to $484. That is a 61 per cent increase in the price of food that you and others buy at major capital cities around Australia. What income level do these people have?

talk.start.para: âIt comes on a truck, doesn't it?
âThe member for Blair is being quite disruptive and I ask him to desist.

âHe is just a clown; I wouldn't take much notice of him. What income levels are we talking about here? We are talking about large sections of the community that are either on the Newstart allowance or on CDEP, that is, the equivalent of Work for the Dole. What sort of money are the people in these bush communities earning? When you pay $301 for a basket of goods, in one area of the Northern Territory they have to pay $525. That is, they have to pay 74 per cent more for the same basket of goods than you have to pay in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Canberra, Perth or any of the other capital cities.

speech.para: What do they earn? What is the magnificent Newstart allowance that they live on? If they are single, 21 years and older with no children, it is $325.70 per fortnight. Give me a break! You do not have to be too smart to understand that these people are going to be penalised by this GST. We hear about the issue of freight and I am glad that it has been raised. In the context of the election campaign, the issue of freight and freight costs was made much of by the government. Of course, those people who are advocates for the trucking industry did not agree with them, because they said in the Northern Territory that they did not expect there would be any decrease in freight costs as a result of the GST. But, more to the point, whatever you might say about a GST, what we do know is that freight will suffer from a GST, that every item of food bought in a remote area store in the Northern Territory will have a freight component in its cost which will be GST applicable. The GST will apply.

talk.start.para: âWhat rubbish. What absolute rubbish!

âThese guys do not understand, nor are they aware of, the conditions which exist in remote and rural Australia. What this government is doing in proposing this GST in the way in which it has been done is penalising people who live in rural and remote communities. It is going to cause job losses in the Northern Territoryâof that there is no doubtâand it is going to penalise the most impoverished section of our community: people that this government says that it cares for. I do not think it cares for them and I do not think it has done anything that demonstrates that it does. I have already explained that we can anticipateâif you use the tourism industry's own figuresâthe loss of up to 2,000 jobs.

speech.para: I do not know what these people opposite think about people losing their jobs. I do not know what they think about the fact that there are many people who live in these remote communities who already, because of the higher costs of food, will have to suffer as a result of a GSTâand they often do go without food. I do not know what they think about that but I think it is a very serious issue. These people laugh it off. They come in and they are fundamentally dishonest. They make dishonest claims about the impact of a GST on rural and remote Australia and then they expect people to support them. We have seen what level of support they have as a result of the latest Newspoll survey. You would be worried about it, brother, and you are worried about it because you know what it means in your community. Despite the way you sit here and boast that somehow or other this is some enlightened tax journey we are having, you know that it is not supported in your community.

I know it is not supported in my community, and for a very fundamental reason: people know it is not good for them. People know that this will mean a loss of jobs. People know that it will undermine their standard of living. People know that if you live in the bushânot in some Western District of Victoria but in the bushâyou understand the implications of this GST proposal. I am surprised at our friends in the National Party, particularly those who represent remote Australiaânot Mr Entsch; I am not sure what he believes in but he will not be here much longer. I am surprised that the member for Kennedy, for example, has not come out and railed against this GST proposal and supported the views which have been represented by the coalition's friends in Western Australia, Mr Cowan and Mr Court. Let there be no doubt about it: this GST, if it passes, will be a disaster for Australia. We are committed to opposing it. We will oppose it and I hope we defeat it. If we do not, all of Australia will be penalised.

talk.start.para: âI am sure the Northern Territory will benefit a great deal through the diesel rebates that are going to be provided as part of the tax package. This is the first year that the federal budget has been brought down under the system known as accrual accounting. The change is long overdue. This is a system that acknowledges the full allocation of funding to a particular budgetary item. The old cash system recorded expenditure only when a transaction occurred. Accrual accounting means that, in accounting terms, there is emphasis on outcomes, not on processes. It is the system of accounting used in the private sector. Under this system the budget answers the question of what will be produced, not of how we are going to produce it. At last we are doing away with systems that value the process rather than the outcome. It took the Howard government to do it.

speech.para: I doubt that accrual accounting would ever have been introduced under Labor. I know that the public service and commentators have talked about the need to introduce accrual accounting from time to time. Unfortunately, the value of accrual accounting is that it is so much more transparent than the old cash system. Labor, in power, proved it did not care for the public having too great an understanding of the state of the nation's finances. Certainly, when in power the Leader of the Opposition ran up a $10 billion deficit, while all the time maintaining that the budget was balanced. The fibs he was telling would have been all too apparent if, at the same time, he had been required to live up to the principles of accrual accountingâthe same principles that apply to small businesses all over Australia.

Another point worth considering is the way in which a tax system based on a GST appears when presented in accrual terms. In the context of the wider tax debate, it is worth considering how GST revenue and expenditure would appear on paper under this transparent system, compared with the way in which the current wholesale sales tax system would present. The fact is that, without a GST or some other effective source of growth funding, the budgets of various states, and certainly the Commonwealth budget under Keating or Beazley, would be revealed as being full of holes. Without a strong source of growth money, accrual accounting would reveal that, in many cases, budgets have been delivered with revenue insufficient to fund basic needs like hospitals and schools, certainly in the outyears.

For many years, under the cash system, the Queensland governmentâwith which I am most familiarâhas funded just the first year of its commitments. It puts off the question of funding in the outyears until the crunch comes, often in the Expenditure Review Committee. This razor gang has the task of finding sourcesâsometimes one-offâof revenue to meet the annual shortfall. Accrual accounting would reveal this little charade. Across Australia a multitude of sins would be revealed. We would see hospitals and schools on the drawing board but with no existing way of paying for them.

If governments, particularly Labor governments like the one headed by Peter Beattie in Queensland, were to be denied the GST as a source of growth funding, accrual accounting beyond one or two years would be an embarrassing nightmare. Accrual accounting would quickly reveal the fact that, each year, residents face the unheralded increases in taxes and charges, asset sales and other unpopular imposts just to keep the wheels of government turning. No wonder Labor premiersâPeter Beattie, Bob Carr and Jim Baconâwere at the head of the queue waiting to sign up for the GST. Speed cameras, toll roads and user-pays charges are other examples of unpopular, unheralded changes that have been dumped on state taxpayers to fill budgetary holes carefully hidden under the old cash accounting system.

By comparison, accrual accounting measures would reveal many of the natural advantages of a tax system based on the GST. Primarily there would be a source of growth revenue so important capital projects could be funded in their entirety. There would be no need for annual tax hikes or other one-off impositions. Other more regressive taxesâfor example, payroll taxâcould be wiped out in time. This way we will create jobs and turbocharge the Australian economy. Accrual accounting is accurate. It is rigorous. There is no opportunity to hide something as basic as a $10 billion deficit in a budget presented in this way.

That prompts me to ask the rhetorical question: what do these transparent accounting principles reveal about the Howard government's 1999-2000 federal budget? The statistics read something like this: total final demand is three per cent, down from 4.25 per cent; GDP is three per cent, down from 4.25 per cent; business investmentâno doubt finally influenced by the Asian downturnâis zero per cent, down from two per cent; the CPI is two per cent, up from 1.25 per cent; unemployment is to be 7.25 per cent, down from 7.5 per cent; and we see the current account deficit will be 5.25 per cent of GDP, down from 5.5 per cent of GDP. Revenue of this year will be $162.8 billion and the surplus will be $5.4 billion. All in all, given the times and the fate of many nations less well prepared than our own, to quote somebody, these are a great set of numbers.

The commentators have said it all. The budget has won accolades from one end of the planet to the other. Again, in the context of the wider tax debate, it is interesting to note that in this budget the forward estimates accommodate the impact of the GST. Believe the Labor Party and the member for the Northern Territory, and you would suspect that these figures would reveal a massive new tax slug, courtesy of the GST. Believe the Labor Party and you would expect something like 10 per cent on top. But what does it show? In fact, it shows just the opposite.

In this budget it is revealed that, as the GST is introduced, total revenueâthat is, all money raised by the government from taxpayersâwill actually fall as a percentage of GDP. It will fall from 26.3 per cent in 1999-2000 to 22.9 per cent in 2001-02. This is significant. Once again, this transparent system reveals the value of the GST. Thanks to the GST, we will see a 3.4 per cent drop in the proportion of gross domestic product required to fund government activity. The Bills Digest makes the point that these figures will change as a result of the amended package accepted by the Democrats, but the change in the percentage will still be downwards. It would be just the opposite if we followed the do nothing prescription of the Labor Party and stayed with the existing ramshackle tax system.

Tonight we are discussing appropriation under three separate pieces of legislation. Under Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 , $36 billion will be pumped into the Australian economy. That is 25 per cent of the expenditure of Commonwealth agencies. The rest of their budgets come from special appropriations and income receipts. Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1999-2000 provides $5.7 billion for capital expenditure, grants to states and territories, and administrative expenses that are new.

Finally, the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1999-2000 provides $159.2 million. This includes $27.8 million to run the House of Representatives, which is up from $25.1 million; $31.4 million to run the Senate, which is up from $27.9 million; $41 million for the Joint House Department, down from $42.7 million; $42.2 million for Parliamentary Reporting Staff, up from $36.4 million; and $16.6 million for the Parliamentary Library, up from $14.9 million. I am sure members of this House would agree, when reviewing these figures, that it seems ridiculous to spend more reviewing legislation than we do developing it. Nevertheless, that is the current state of play. The Senate does cost more to run than the House of Representatives and surely only Sir Humphrey could tell us why.

The Parliamentary Library is always the first source of information for members researching bills such as this. On this occasion, it has produced several good articles analysing the impact of the budget. I have read what the authors from the library have said, after synthesising media and expert commentary on the budget. I also heard what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had to say the other night about his views on the budget. Not surprisingly, you would think they were discussing two different budgets altogether. However, in this case, one comment comes from the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party and the other from the independent, well-respected commentators retained by the Parliamentary Library. I know who has the greater credibility on this issue.
The Parliamentary Library's commentator, John Kain, summed up the main thrust of the budget very well. He wrote:

The `99-2000 budget maintains the Howard Government's long standing strategic objective of striving for maximum possible economic growth and the maximum possible rise in measured living standards taking account of key economic parameters bearing on growth, in particular, the rate of inflation and the size of the current account deficit. The achievement of such economic growth is seen as the key to further substantial reduction in the rate of unemployment.
Mr Deputy Speaker, he is correct: unemployment is the number one issue in the electorate of Blair and around Australia.

The coalition government has a credible policy to reduce unemployment; Labor does not. It has a numberâI think it came up with something like five per cent last. The extent of its planning is that Labor believes that five per cent is a good number for unemployment. Dur! That is what I would say to that. What a policy! The collective minds of the Labor Party have figured out that five is a smaller number than 7.5. That is a stunning development, a real thriller. They understand their preschool number facts, but that is the extent of it. In parliament they are doing everything they can to physically oppose policies that will actually reduce unemployment.

Let us take a couple of these policies as examples: unfair dismissal legislation, Work for the Dole and now tax reform. All of these offer greater opportunity for new jobs. For example, the unfair dismissal legislation supported by Labor would be the biggest disincentive to employment currently in existence. The coalition has actively pursued amendments to make the dismissal of staff a more balanced process and to encourage more employers to take up the challenge of employing people.

These laws are anti jobs. Any TAFE small business course warns small business men and women of the deadly difficulty that these laws can pose to an unsuspecting employer. Participants in these courses work on business plans and discuss issues from marketing to accountancy. But the biggest warnings are reserved for the unwary in relation to unfair dismissals. The legal danger of a dismissal being deemed unfair makes it just not worth the trouble of hiring someone in the first place.

Work for the Dole is a successful measure that is improving the self-esteem of the unemployed, improving their skills and preparing them for the workplace. It is no more or less than recognition of the principles of reciprocal obligation. Mr Deputy Speaker, Aboriginal people in remote communities have been working for the dole under Labor and the coalition through a range of CDEP schemes for many years now. A few minutes ago you would have heard the member for the Northern Territory say that CDEP is the equivalent of Work for the Dole. He said it: CDEP is the equivalent of Work for the Dole.

talk.start.para: âVoluntary.
âSure, it is well nigh impossible to get a job in a remote community, but why should Aboriginal people work for the dole when other unemployed people do not?

speech.para: The member for the Northern Territory referred to it as an equivalent scheme. I cannot imagine the Labor Party recanting its position in support of the CDEP, so I fail to understand why it so vehemently opposes Work for the Dole. Across Australia, it has Labor Party controlled councils and governments standing in the way of ordinary Australians wanting to work for the dole while actively encouraging Aborigines to do the opposite. How can the principle of mutual obligation, providing physical labour in return for money received from the taxpayers, be good for black people but unacceptable when applied to everyone else?

talk.start.para: âTalk to us about skills.
âThat brings me back to tax reform.
âI would prefer that the member for Port Adelaide did not talk at all.
âOnce again, the opposition is talking about creating jobs while doing just the opposite.
âI'm helping him.
âHe does not need your help. Carry on, member.

âThey are destroying jobs. By opposing the government's tax reforms and taking cheap shots for short-term political gain, they are betraying the interests of small business and those who rely on the small business sector for work. Tax reform is about helping small business to create more jobs. This budget is about helping small business and creating more jobs.

speech.para: In closing, I have a challenge for the member opposite. In the past fortnight I have heard all members opposite complain that more should be done for pensioners. Well, they know how they can fix that. They have complained about tax complexity, and they can fix that too. They want more done for the bush, and that is another item that rests in their hands. They want more for the environment; same again. They can do all those things if they will only participate in the tax debate. But, of course, they continue to do nothing. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend this budget which lights the way ahead for Australia and I condemn the opposition because they will not let go of the past.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Office of the Employment Advocate: Polling
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 443)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 17 February 1999:

question.para: (1) Will he provide details of polling being conducted on behalf of the Office of the Employment Advocate including (a) who is conducting the polling, (b) the questions being asked, (c) the methodology used and (d) the financial cost.
(2) Have funds been allocated for future polling; if so, what is the budget.
(3) Does the polling referred to in the preceding parts constitute push polling.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Office of the Employment Advocate has contracted the Wallis Consulting Group Pty Ltd to conduct surveys on behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia.
(b) The questions being asked relate to freedom of association.
(c) The surveys will consist of two elements:
- a survey of 1000 employers conducted by telephone and mail questionnaire; and
- a survey of 1000 union members conducted by telephone.

The employer survey will be in the form of a self completed mail survey returned by mail or fax. Prior to the surveys being mailed out to 1000 employers, telephone interviewers will call a sample of business establishments (1500 employers) selected at random from the Yellow pages and Dun and Bradstreet's commercial listing to establish the most appropriate person in the company to undertake the survey. Establishments will be chosen to fit industry and size criteria (Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification 1993, industry codes excluding agriculture, forestry and fishing; 400 small establishments, 300 medium establishments and 300 large establishments). Companies employing one or two people only at a site will be excluded from the study.

The union member survey will be conducted by telephone with such employees at their homes and will be run at the same time as the employer survey. The telephone survey method was selected in this instance because postal questionnaires raise issues in regards to literacy and understanding of questions which may present difficulties for some employees (eg, less educated or those for whom English is not their first language).
